PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SECOND PARLIAMENT
The Senate, on 27 May 1982, adjourned to 17 August 1982, unless the President fixed an earlier day of meeting.
Pursuant to the Resolution of the Senate passed on 27 May 1982, the Senate met on Tuesday, 17 August 1982, at 3 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 3 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, consequent upon the retirement of Mr Keith Bradshaw, Mr Alan Cumming Thom was appointed Clerk of the Senate as from 16 July 1982.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATHS OF FORMER MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is my sad duty to report to the Senate the deaths of four distinguished former members of this Parliament. I refer to the Honourable Norman Makin, the Right Honourable Sir Philip McBride, the Honourable Sir John McLeay and Charles Edward Griffiths. I seek leave to move motions in respect of each of the deceased members.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE N. J. O. MAKIN, A.O.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 20 July 1982 of the Honourable Norman John Oswald Makin, A.O., a Member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Hindmarsh from 1919 to 1946, Speaker from 1929 to 1931, Member for the Division of Sturt from 1954 to 1955, Member for the Division of Bonython from 1955 to 1963, a Minister of the Crown during the Second World War, Ambassador to the United States of America from 1946 to 1951, and President of the Security Council of the United Nations in 1946 and 1947, and places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Norman Makin was one of nature's gentlemen. He was a man literally for all seasons. Those who knew him knew him to be a man of quality and of particular dignity. He was fortunate to live a long and very full life. He was born on 31 March 1889 and he died on 20 July of this year, so his life spanned nearly a century. He was educated at Broken Hill Central Public School. He was president of the South Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party from 1918 to 1919 and, as I have said, he was elected to the Federal Parliament in 1919 as member for Hindmarsh. He made his maiden speech in March 1920 when he spoke about wartime profiteering and the dangers of sectarianism in politics.

He had wide-ranging experience. He was temporary chairman of committees and was elected Speaker in the period 1929 to 1931 when the Scullin Government ceased. He was Minister for the Navy and Minister for Munitions during the war years. He was Minister for Aircraft Production from 1945 to 1946. He was a member of the War Cabinet from 1941 to 1946. He resigned in 1946 to become Australia's first Ambassador to the United States of America where he remained until 1951. He was the first President of the United Nations Security Council and served in that post with the support of all those involved. He returned to national politics in 1954 as member for Sturt and transferred to the seat of Bonython in 1955, which he retained until his retirement in 1963.

He served his country and the movement which he loved with a great deal of pride. He was active over the years, over the almost century of his life. We are the better for his life. We are the poorer for his going.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion moved by Senator Sir John Carrick. I want to add a few brief comments to the remarks made by Senator Carrick, which I endorse and support. Norman Makin was 93 years of age when he died. He held a highly revered place in the hearts of members of the Australian Labor Party. Probably no one man was more respected in this Parliament and no one better displayed the qualities of courage and doggedness that enabled him to rise above adversity to some of the highest positions which this country has to offer. He emerged from a poor background to become Speaker of the House of Representatives, a Cabinet Minister, the first President of the United Nations Security Council, Ambassador to the United States of America and Chief Australian Delegate to the United Nations. He spent 36 years in this Federal Parliament. It is interesting to recall that he was Speaker 53 years ago , during the term of the Scullin Government.

SPEECH.PARA: He was, as an individual, renowned for his gentility and courtesy. He once confessed publicly that he was never confident in any one of the positions of high authority which he held. That is an expression of humility which is rarely made, either in this chamber or in the House of Representatives. I think that he drew great comfort from his life-long adherence to the Methodist Church, of which he remained a lay preacher until the end of his life. His lack of belligerence and his courteousness to all people were a by-word amongst all those who knew him.

I conclude by saying that he was a man whose life spanned a great and significant period of Australian history. He was an observer of and a participant in some of the great events of this century which concerned this country, not only in a national sense but also internationally. It is perhaps important to recall that during his periods as a representative of this country overseas he established very close relationships with people such as President Truman, Dean Acheson, Lester Pearson, Averell Harriman, and Eleanor Roosevelt. It was a great and a long life and a great contribution to this country. I have pleasure in seconding the remarks made by Senator Sir John Carrick.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want briefly to support, on behalf of the National Country Party and personally, the motion that is before the Senate. Norman Makin, at 93 years of age, had seen a very long and distinguished career, both as a politician and indeed as an ambassador. He was quite distinctive in that field, having been the first Australian ambassador appointed to the United States of America. Norman Makin had, as the previous speakers have indicated, a long career in the Parliament. He certainly left his mark in this institution and, indeed, in the annuals of Australian history. Perhaps we will remember him most because he was a quiet and relatively conservative man-I think there is a real message in that. The Honourable Norman Makin served this nation well. I certainly extend the sincere sympathy of my party to his family on this occasion.

—I would like to associate the Australian Democrats with this motion of condolence. When I entered the Parliament in 1960 as a callow youth Mr Norman Makin greeted me, as he did all inexperienced persons, with kindness and a spirit of helpfulness and generosity. He was a gentle man and a gentleman. He had a kindly word for everyone. I have never believed that there was that mythical creature, the classical old-time Labor man. But if there was, Norman Makin was it. All of us, as we go through life, meet many people who profess to be Christians but who sometimes behave in a manner of which one would think Christ would have been ashamed. Norman Makin was one of several people I have met who professed to be Christians and behaved in all aspects in a manner of which I am sure Christ would have been very proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to join with the previous speakers in this motion of condolence for the late Norman Makin. Norman Makin, as we in the Australian Labor Party all know and as members of the other parties have said in this place, was one of the real greats not only of the Australian Labor Party but also of Australian politics across a very wide spectrum. He was a Labor man from beginning to end, with great courage and high ideals second to none. During his long political career he held practically every important position in the party that was so dear to him. He enjoyed the complete confidence of Labor Prime Ministers and all Labor leaders. He served his country and in particular the State of South Australia with dignity and ability in many capacities as a member of the House of Representatives and later as Australian Ambassadsor to the United States of America. Norman Makin was one of the very few politicians who retired from active politics to take up the duties of an ambassador and then, on completion of those dities, return to active politics. Such was his intent and desire to help his fellow man that he stood for the marginal seat of Sturt on his return, was successful and went on to represent that seat with great distinction. He maintained an active interest in his party until shortly before his death. The Labor movement in South Australia, in mourning his passing, places on record its highest possible tribute to the late Norman Makin for his services to it and to the nation. He set us all a very great example. We will long remember him. The South Australian members of the Labor Party in this chamber extend our very deepest sympathy to the surving members of his family.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE SIR JOHN McLEAY, K.C.M.G., M.M.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 22 June of the Honourable Sir John McLeay, K.C.M.G., M.M., member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Boothby from 1949 to 1966 and Speaker from 1956 to 1967 and places on record its appreciation for his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Like Norman Makin, Sir John McLeay's life spanned a great period-almost 90 years of crowded public activity of great merit. He died on 22 June. He was born in Port Clinton in South Australia in 1893. He was educated at Port Clinton, Unley Central School and later took a commercial course at Muirden College. In 1915 he enlisted in the 1st AIF and served with distinction as a stretcher bearer with the 13th Field Ambulance. He was awarded the Military Medal at Villiers- Bretonneux. He maintained a life-long interest in exservicemen. He was a past President of the South Australian Legacy Club and a board member of the South Australian Branch of the Returned Services League.

He was always interested in public life. Before entering Federal Parliament in 1949 as the member for Boothby he served on the Unley City Council from 1925 to 1946 and was Mayor from 1935 to 1937. He was on the Adelaide City Council in 1941 and was Lord Mayor from 1946 to 1950. He was the member of the South Australian House of Assembly for Unley from 1938-41.

He made his maiden speech on 8 March 1950 and spoke of the problems of local government and of the need to ensure that legislation passed was in the interests of the nation. He served on a wide number of committees-Privileges Committee, Standing Orders Committee, Library Committee, House Committee and the Joint Committee on Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings. He was elected Speaker in 1956 following the death of Archie Cameron and he held that post until his retirement in 1967, his 10 1/2 year term being a record. He was almost an institution in the chair and was well respected by honourable members on both sides of the House. He represented Australia at the tenth anniversary of Ceylon' s independence in 1958. He led the delegation to the meeting of the Papua New Guinea Legislative Council in its new chamber in 1960. He attended the 53rd Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference in Copenhagen in 1964. He visited the United Kingdom in 1965 to attend the Commonwealth Speakers' Conference and celebrations for the 700th anniversary of the Parliament of Simon de Montfort and the 750th anniversary of the signing of the Magna Carta.

The members of the McLeay family have given much service to the national Parliament. Sir John's brother, George, as we all know served as a distinguished senator and Minister. His son John succeeded him to the seat of Boothby and served as a Minister before his appointment as Consul-General to Los Angeles. This is a life of dedication and of great service. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion which has been moved by Senator Sir John Carrick, who has dealt with the main and very distinguished features of the life of Sir John McLeay. I would add only some reference to the unique position the members of the McLeay family have held in South Australian politics and, indeed, in national politics. One might be doing this, if we may elevate ourselves for a moment, in the House of Lords context because it almost seems to be hereditary amongst the members of the McLeay family in respect of their contribution to national political life.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to make some brief comment about Sir John McLeay himself. I speak, of course, from hearsay but I am told that he was regarded by both sides of the Parliament as being a Speaker of the House of Representatives of great tolerance and fairness. He had a jolly sort of personality and he was renowned for his sense of humour and his ability to mix with members on both sides of the House in the easiest possible way. It was said of him on one occasion that he was not only one of those people who are capable of a good after dinner speech but he was also capable of being witty before lunch which, of course, is a rare attribute for politicians and one for which he will no doubt be remembered as he will be for the very distinguished service that he and members of his family have offered to this country. I support the motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of my party, I too want to support this motion. The contribution that Sir John McLeay has made in his particular field in this country has been evidenced over a very long period. He had distinguished military service, distinguished parliamentary service and, as I understand it, he was a very basic, down to earth Australian. I read one fellow's comments on Sir John McLeay which suggested that he was loyal, down to earth and wise. I suppose one could hardly put together three more important adjectives if one were describing any human being. I extend the sincere sympathy of my party to the relatives and friends of the late Sir John McLeay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats wish to associate themselves with this motion of condolence and to express sympathy to the loved ones of the late Sir John McLeay. I was privileged to serve in the House of Representatives when he was Speaker, and I do not think he or any of his loved ones would mind if I said that he did not have an intimate knowledge of the Standing Orders. He will never go down in history as being the Speaker who knew Standing Orders better than any other Speaker, but when things became tense in the chamber he seemed to have that unique knack of making a funny remark, of cooling things down, quietening things down. He had that capacity to which Senator Button referred of being able to mix with members of all parties. Therefore, he will go down as one of the good Speakers of the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I associate myself with this motion because Sir John McLeay's son, Jack McLeay, has been a personal friend of mine for many years. Together with Senator Chaney' s father and several other distinguished then members of the House of Representatives, he was a member of the famous Mushroom Club. Recently I had the privilege of enjoying John McLeay's hospitality in Los Angeles. I express my personal sympathy to him and to Sir John McLeay's loved ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to identify myself and my family with the motion of condolence on the death of Jack McLeay. My association with him goes back many years to the days when my father went to the Unley Central School with him. They lived as neighbours in the Unley district for many years. However , I had no personal knowledge of him until the 1966 Federal election, when I sat on the same platform as his son when I was candidate for Grey. I found myself elected unexpectedly to the House of Representatives and I sat with John McLeay in that House for three very happy years. One of the first people who telephoned me when learning of my victory on that occasion was Sir John McLeay, and I remember his words of wisdom very well. There was never an occasion when I needed his advice that he did not come forward with very sound and wise words from the depths of his great experience.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from his service to the Parliament to which reference has been made, I think of Sir John McLeay as a man who was interested in the common enjoyment of people in his electorate, in his State, and in Australia. For many years, of course, he was President of the Sturt Football Club, with which I am associated. In fact, he was President of that club for 14 years, patron for 20 years, and a life member for more than 25 years. That says a lot for his interest in young people and their recreational habits. I often called in at John McLeay's home after the football to recapitulate some of the incidents he had seen on television during the afternoon. I want to identify myself and my family with this condolence motion and to extend our sympathy to his sons, daughter, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the condolence motion in respect of the late Sir John McLeay, who at the time of my entry into Parliament in 1962 was the Speaker of the House of Representatives. As the Leader of the Government (Senator Sir John Carrick) has said, Sir John occupied that position for about 10 1/2 years. Indeed, for some of the time he was Speaker I had the honour of being a member of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, over which Sir John McLeay presided at that time. During the time I was a member of that Committee under the chairmanship of Sir John McLeay I came to respect him enormously. As has been said, he was a highly popular Speaker and was well regarded by members on both sides of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, during the time that he was Speaker, he had great professional parliamentarians with whom to contend-men such as Eddie Ward, Les Haylen, Reg Pollard and Fred Daly, all of whom firmly believed in the philosophy of the Labor movement, were men of great intellect and were colourful personalities. Indeed, I think the task that Sir John McLeay had as Speaker in those days was probably much more difficult than is the task of the Speaker today.

As the Leader of the Government in the Senate has said, Sir John McLeay won the Military Medal for gallantry during the First World War. I know that, although they were of different political persuasions, because of their joint service in France in the First World War he had a particular affinity with Reg Pollard and Les Haylen. He had a tremendous sense of humour. He was a man of great dignity. He was a great Speaker, a great Australian, and a great parliamentarian. Those who knew him well will mourn his passing.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE RIGHT HONOURABLE SIR PHILIP McBRIDE, P.C., K.C.M.G.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 14 July 1982 of the Rt Hon. Sir Philip McBride, P.C., K.C.M.G., a member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Grey from 1931-37, a Senator for South Australia from 1937-44, a member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Wakefield from 1946-58 and a Minister of the Crown for 11 years; places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service; and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Mr President, today we are paying tribute to very distinguished Australians indeed-to Australians who lived, as I have said, full, long lives. Sir Philip McBride, whom, like the others, I was privileged to know, lived 90 years-and they were full years. Born in 1892, he was educated at Burra Public School and later at Prince Alfred College in Adelaide. He entered the House of Representatives at the 1931 general election as member for Grey. He was re- elected in 1934 and in October 1937 resigned his seat to seek election to the Senate to fill a casual vacancy. He successfully sought re-election in 1938 and was defeated in 1943. His ministerial career began in the first Menzies ministry . He was Assistant Minister for Commerce from April 1939 to October 1941. He was Minister for Supply and Development and Minister for Munitions from 1940 to 1941 . He was a member of the War Cabinet and the last surviving member of the first Menzies ministry. He was very highly regarded by the late Sir Robert Menzies.

In 1946 he was re-elected to the House of Representatives as member for Wakefield. He retained that seat until his retirement from politics in 1958. He resumed his ministerial career in 1949 as Minister for the Interior following the return of the Menzies Government. Sir Philip was a leading figure in the establishment of the Liberal Party and was Federal President from 1960 to 1965. He was created a KCMG in 1953 and a Privy Councillor in 1959. He had a lifelong interest in pastoral circles. He was, for a time, President of the Stockowners Association of South Australia and represented that State on the Australian Wool Growers Council.

I think of Sir Philip McBride as a man of gentle dignity and great courtesy, a man who had immense interest in his fellow men, a man devoted and dedicated throughout his life to public service, a man who would serve quietly and with great dedication wherever he was appointed. It is with sadness that I move the motion of condolence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion moved by Senator Sir John Carrick. I have nothing to add to that motion except to acknowledge on behalf of the Opposition the distinguished public service which Sir Philip gave to this country and to express our regrets to his family on his death.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support the motion of condolence to the family of the late Sir Philip McBride. He was, as we have heard, one who gave very long and distinguished service in the Parliament to this country and, indeed, he gave long and distinguished service in the pastoral industry in which he was a leader in organisation and as a breeder. As I understand it, Sir Philip McBride was distinguished by the fact that he was not seen ever to be a flamboyant politician. He had a great grasp of matters and problems that related to all people. On behalf of my party, I very sincerely support the motion before the Senate.

—I join the Australian Democrats in this motion of condolence. I never met Sir Philip McBride and therefore did not know him personally, but during my years with the Liberal Party of Australia I was reminded on many occasions of the great service he gave to that party and to the country. I join with other speakers in paying respect to him and in sending our sympathy to this relatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to identify myself with this expression of regret at the passing of Sir Philip McBride. I knew Sir Philip for over 30 years, largely because he was a very close friend of my wife's family. Naturally I found myself inhabiting the houses of my wife's relatives and frequently Sir Philip and Lady McBride were present. Sir Philip McBride and the McBride family are well known pastoralists in South Australia and are very highly regarded by the South Australian community. It is worth recording that no other South Australian representative in Parliament has held as many portfolios as Sir Philip McBride. As mentioned by, I think, Senator Sir John Carrick, Sir Philip's positions ranged from Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, through eight portfolios until finally he was Minister for Defence for eight years. I simply record my regrets at his passing and wish to pass on my condolences to his family-in particular to his wife, Rita, his sons, his sister, Mrs Pat Taylor, and his brother, Jim McBride.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative. honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF MR C. E. GRIFFITHS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 17 May 1982 of Charles Edward Griffiths, a member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Shortland from 1949 to 1972 and places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Charlie Griffiths-as he would want to be known and as everybody in the Newcastle area knew him-lived some 79 years. He was very much a part of the community in which he lived and served. He was typical of the type of Australian who faced the difficulties of the coal fields area. The people he served came to know him and to respect him. On leaving school he joined the New South Wales Railways. He became actively involved in union matters. He became a State councillor of the Australian Railways Union and served as State Secretary from 1940 to 1952-a very significant role indeed in a very great Australian union. He was first elected to the House of Representatives at the general election in 1949 and so by an odd set of circumstances, leaving in 1972, he was always in Opposition. He always sat on the Opposition benches. He served on the Printing Committee and the Public Works Committee. He was a member of the Australian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly in 1964, member of a fact finding mission to South East Asia in 1966 and member of a fact finding mission to Hong Kong, Japan , Korea and Taiwan in 1969. I think Charlie Griffiths would want to be known for his service to the trade union movement. He served it well. He was a distinguished trade union official. He would want to be known for his representation of the Shortland area and his association with very vigorous and typical Australian people. They will remember him for the life that he led and the work that he did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion moved by the Leader of the Government. Senator Sir John Carrick has indicated the major points of Charlie Griffiths's public career. I want only to add something to that and say that, quite apart from the respect he enjoyed here and in public life, he was very widely respected in the Newcastle area because, apart from being a parliamentarian, he was a great battler, if I can put it in those terms, for many important social causes in the Newcastle district. It is said of him that thousands of his constituents would not have received the assistance and benefits which they got from Government programs and so on without the work which he put into pressing their causes with both the bureaucracy and Ministers in government. He was a family man who did not in a political sense seek the limelight. He was a respected member of the Uniting Church in Australia and was very much a contributor to his local community. Senator Carrick mentioned that he came into Parliament in 1949 and went out in 1972; that is, he came in with the Menzies Government and went out at the same time as Billy McMahon's Government. That he never sat on the government side is said to have been one of the great regrets of his life. Even in the Australian Labor party, if we are here for a few years, we have a reasonable chance of serving in government. He spanned that very long period in Opposition and did not have that opportunity. It was a source of great regret to him. In expressing to his family our regrets at his passing, we are also in a sense saying something for the people of Newcastle and the people of the trade union movement in New South Wales, who greatly respected his life and career.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to support the motion that expresses condolence to the family of the late Charlie Griffiths. Indeed, as has already been said, Charlie Griffiths served in this Parliament for a very long time-23 years-and I do not doubt that he served it extremely well. When I was looking at some material on Charlie Griffiths I noted that he was educated at the Bribbaree Central School. That is about 40 to 50 miles from my home. The conclusion I came to was that anyone who had the good fortune to be educated in those pleasant fields and among those gum trees would have a lot of common sense. I am sure that Charlie Griffiths, in his long service in this Parliament, exhibited just that on behalf of the people he served. He had a conviction which I am sure was evident in the things he said and did. I certainly join in extending my sincere sympathy to the family of Charlie Griffiths.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the Australian Democrats with the motion of condolence and add my personal message of sympathy to the loved ones of Charlie Griffiths. I was privileged to know Charlie very well and for many years. He was a tenacious battler, as Senator Button has mentioned. I found that out to my cost when I was Minister for Customs and Excise and Charlie was pursuing a complaint by one of his constituents about a relatively small matter. I think that number of visits to my office that Charlie made personally, until he got justice for his constituent , was about 14 or 15. He was a remarkable battler for causes in which he believed.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall never forget how, only a couple of years ago, he came into my office, still as the tenacious battler. Someone who had been an officer in the Army and who Charlie knew only slightly had been killed in a crash at an intersection. It seemed as though the officer had a heart attack going through a red traffic light, crashed and died. Although Charlie knew the fellow only very slightly, and although he knew that he belonged to a different political party, he believed that this person's death was due to war service and should have attracted the repatriation pension. I think that Charlie personally saw about 15 or 16 members of parliament about the matter. He journeyed to Melbourne at his own expense, at the suggestion of his good friend and my good friend Hec McIvor, and spent two and a half hours of his time on the matter, bringing three or four suitcases of files with him. He confided to me in passing that he had already spent $3,000 of his own money in pursuing this one case to get justice for the dead person's family and that he was prepared to spend his life savings to get justice.

That was the kind of man Charlie Griffiths was. I am pleased to be able to put that little anecdote in the Hansard record so that when, as I understand is the custom, a record of these speeches is sent to his relatives, at least that anecdote can be read and treasured by his loved ones.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse all the sentiments expressed by honourable senators. Charlie belonged to the same union as I. I know that Charlie took up particular social security cases of retired union members in the Lake Macquarie area of New South Wales. He had a lengthy trade union career before he entered the national Parliament. Senator Carrick referred to Charlie's union activities. They were typical of him. He probably could have come into Parliament earlier, but at the start of World War II the Australian Railways Union had some turbulent leadership problems, and Charlie played a notable role in cooling people off and getting the union on an even keel.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point, as Senator Chipp mentioned, was that Charlie had a remarkable memory in relation to social security decisions. He worked for the New South Wales railways where one got that no man's land in regard to eligibility when people are in receipt of certain railway superannuation payments. Tenacious advocate as he was, he would persist with matters. I think that Senator Grimes would agree with me when I say that, looking back on Charlie's career and considering the research facilities available today in regard to social security matters, Charlie Griffiths and his contemporary Allan Fraser would spend an immense amount of time going into the field to collate facts. Once they established the precedent many other people also got the benefits.

The people of Newcastle and the Australian Railways Union should be proud of Charlie Griffiths. I am sure that they are. He gave his all right up to the last . There were no half measures. He was a fierce advocate in caucus, but if he lost on an issue there was no malice; he had done his best. That was the way he liked to be regarded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in supporting the motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Sir John Carrick. No one worked harder for his constituents than did Charlie Griffiths and his wife, Jess. There was no one in his electorate whom he did not know, and no one could have represented the people of his electorate better than Charlie Griffiths. Everyone, particularly people in the Labor movement, knew of his dedication to assisting the under-privileged section of the community. Indeed, only last Sunday, when I was returning from a meeting of my party in a country area north of Newcastle, I met people who had been constituents of Charlie Griffiths. They spoke of him in very warm and glowing terms.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp mentioned the name Hec McIvor. Charlie would have liked me to mention that he was a very close associate of the then member for Gellibrand, Mr Hec McIvor. I think that they served in the Parliament for about the same length of time, and they and their wives, Lorna and Jess, were inseparable companions. Both were very great members of the Labor movement. Charlie Griffiths served not only his constituents and his union with distinction but also the Australian Labor Party. As Senator Mulvihill would know, for some years he was a member of the Executive of the New South Wales branch of our party. He gave the people of his electorate outstanding representation, and his memory certainly will live on in that electorate for many years.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATHS OF FORMER MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly take this opportunity to refer particularly to my three former colleagues and friends from South Australia. I refer to the late Norman Makin, who served in the Federal Parliament for many years, including periods as a senior member of the Ministry and also as the Speaker of the House of Representatives. After retirement Norman Makin was appointed Australian Ambassador to the United States of America and later Australia's chief delegate to the United Nations. He was also the first President of the Security Council. All this was quite an achievement for one man in his span of lifetime. Norman Makin was, as I describe him, a very gentle man within himself. He was an outstanding Australian who gave great service to the Parliament, gaining the respect of all with whom he worked, both inside and outside the Parliament. I join in extending to his family my sincere condolences on his passing.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sir John McLeay was a very close personal friend of mine and had a long and distinguished career. As has been stated, he served in World War I and was awarded the Military Medal. Later, in public life he served as Lord Mayor of Adelaide and then as a member of the South Australian Parliament. Finally, he served for many years in this Federal Parliament, where he was the Speaker of the House of Representatives. He served in that capacity for a great number of years until his retirement, and still has the record for the term in that office . During this period Sir John won the respect and esteem of a wide range of people. As I said earlier, he was a very close friend of mine. We enjoyed many friendly chats, which always included the activities of the Federal Parliament- incidentally, may I add that that included the activities of both chambers-in which he took a very keen interest. He was a most avid listener to the parliamentary broadcasts. To the McLeay family, to his sons John and Peter and their families, and to his daughter Barbara, I join in extending my sincere condolences.

Sir Philip McBride was closely associated with Sir Robert Menzies. He served in his party, both in government and in opposition, over a period of some 30 years. He was a member of the Senate as well as a member of the House of Representatives. He was the only South Australian this century to be created a privy councillor and was one of only three persons to have held that honour. He also served for a number of years as a senior Cabinet Minister. For many years- in fact, some 50-odd years-he was the chairman of the well known family pastoral firm, A. J. and P. A. McBride Pty Ltd, a name which is held in high esteem in Australia, particularly in the pastoral and the wool industries.

Sir Philip always had time for a friendly chat. He encouraged many people, and I add on a personal note here that he gave me great encouragement in my youth to take an active role and participate in Parliament. He made a great contribution as a true Australian and I again join in extending to his family my sincere condolences. I also join in the condolences to the family of the late Charlie Griffiths.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHILDS

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 706 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef water is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that:

'The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.'
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MACKLIN

It will further restrict the entrance of low income earners, women and mature-aged students into research.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MACKLIN

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 113 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 109 citizens ), Scott (from 122 citizens) and Peter Rae (from 44 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ARCHER; BAUME; CARRICK; CHILDS; DURACK; GUILFOYLE; JESSOP; MESSNER; SCOTT
PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: We the undersigned citizens of Australia:
Concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown:
Convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making a divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and
Believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and the Marriage Act to be amended in order to
1. Reject any moves towards divorce by post;
2. Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close by blood or marriage;
3. Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will;
4. Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependant children of the marriage;
5. Encourage counselling towards reconciliation; and
6. Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of ( i) intolerable behaviour, (ii) desertion for two years; (iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 70 citizens), Peter Baume (from 118 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 93 citizens), Childs (from 23 citizens), Durack (from 319 citizens ), Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 10 citizens), Jessop (from 147 citizens), Messner (from 9 citizens) and Scott (from 67 citizens).

That currently discrimination in provision of work, in appoint ment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sex;

made it increasingly difficult for many Australians to contemplate study at a university or college of advanced education.
reduced the resources available to groups with particular needs such as our Aboriginal and Ethnic communities.
seriously jeopardized Australia's ability to keep pace with and contribute to technological developments in a whole range of areas.
reduced the quantity and quality of community education programs offered, especially in rural colleges.

forced universities and colleges of advanced education to cut back on the numbers of staff available to each existing courses endangering the quality of education offering and narrowing the range of courses available.

ensure that levels of government funding for education are at a level that will enable all Australians to undertake the higher education of their choice regardless of their potential financial circumstances.
provide all students, present and future, with adequate financial assistance by way of allowances and scholarships.
will make a firm commitment to oppose the re-introduction of any tertiary fees.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.

(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,

The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Manual Assistance Telephone Exchanges
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to close the manual assistance telephone exchange at Lithgow will place in jeopardy the existing services to telephone subscribers in the district by:

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
