DEBATE.TITLE: HIGH COURT OF AUSTRALIA RULE OF COURT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, 12 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the High Court of Australia rule of court amending the High Court rules, contained in Statutory Rules 1982 No. 77 and made under the Judiciary Act 1903, be disallowed.
I seek leave to make a statement relating to the notice just given.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the rule of court which is the subject of the notice of disallowance is to fix a rate of interest on judgment debts. The rule of court stipulates that every debt entered into before 21 April 1980 shall carry interest at the rate of 5 per cent per annum, while all subsequent debts shall carry interest at the rate of 10 per cent per annum. Prior to 21 April 1980, the rate of interest on judgment debts was prescribed under the High Court Procedure Act 1903, which specified a rate of 5 per cent. That Act was repealed on 21 April 1980 by legislation which empowered the High Court to make rules specifying the rate of interest on judgment debts. On 17 March 1982, the High Court made a rule which doubled the rate of interest retrospectively from 21 April 1980.

SPEECH.PARA: On 5 May 1982, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances wrote to the Chief Justice of the High Court, indicating its concern at the retrospectivity of the rule and seeking advice on two matters: Firstly whether there were any special circumstances which led to the delay in making the rule; and secondly, on what basis the rates of interest under the rule had been determined. The Chief Justice indicated that 'no question arose in practice with regard to interest until the matter was brought to notice by an inquiry in one case in which the successful party intended to include interest on his taxed costs', and that 'those responsible for the administration of the High Court Procedure Act and the Judiciary Act did not invite the attention of the Registrar of the Court to the fact that the repeal of the former of those Acts and the enactment of Section 77N of the Judiciary Act necessitated the making of a new rule of court'. He also advised that 'steps were thereafter taken to amend the Rule'. The Chief Justice indicated that the new rate chosen by the High Court was fixed after regard was had to the rates of interest allowed on judgment debts in the various superior courts of the Commonwealth.

The Committee has had further correspondence with the Chief Justice in relation to the matter, and wishes to consider the most recent response from the Chief Justice in more detail before reporting to the Senate. As today is the last day on which notice of disallowance may be given, I have given the notice to permit the Committee to complete its examination of the rule.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in my name and relating to a proposed reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether the Prime Minister, in the 1977 election campaign, said:

QUESTION.PARA: We have ended the big tax rip-off. From February 1 further tax cuts will come in for every Australian wage and salary earner.

Is it not a fact that those 1 February tax cuts lasted for only seven months, until the 1978-79 Budget, when the so-called temporary 1.5 per cent surcharge was added to taxpayers' burdens? Can the Minister give me an assurance that any tax cuts in the Budget to be presented tonight will have a little more staying power than those announced in 1977 prior to an election? What reason will the ordinary taxpayer have for believing that any tax cuts proposed in tonight's Budget will not be purely temporary and a further attempt cynically to manipulate the Australian electorate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the question, I suggest that Senator Button should contain himself until 8 o'clock tonight, when I believe all Australians will agree that the Government's Budget is one that approaches, with a sense of justice and equity, the problem of taxation and the taxation burden in Australia, and that the program itself-
—You would have to be a mug to believe it.
—The question of believability is this: In 1975, 1977 and 1980 the people of Australia, by substantial majority, showed that they believed in the performance of the-
—They don't believe Fraser now, though.
—Order! Let us start off with a bit of peace, love and harmony. I call Senator Sir John Carrick.

—I repeat: I was asked whether the actions of the Government will be believable and whether on the basis of the 1977, 1978 and 1979 results they will be believable. Let me simply say that the only jury in Australia that matters-that is, the electors at the ballot box-looked at this Government and decided that it infinitely preferred this Government to the government that occupied the Treasury bench in 1973-75 when, in fact, there was enormous inflation and an enormous rip-off. If everybody wished to get more tax equity, the Opposition would co-operate with the Government in seeking to bring about restraint in the upward pressure of prices which in themselves have the basis of a wage upsurge throughout Australia which last year was 17 1/2 per cent . Mr President, the fact is that if we have wage upsurges of that kind we will have inflation and that will mean of course there will be higher taxes and there will be less equity in the tax distribution. If all honourable senators wish to have tax equity in this country they will no doubt join this Government in its very significant campaign at this moment to bring about wage restraint and therefore tax equity.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer the Attorney-General to my requests to him to assist in securing the production of and delivery to the Thai court of the alleged original statement said to have been made by Mr Wiliam Sinclair, an Australian citizen, and used against him in the prosecution of drug allegations in Thailand. I remind the Attorney-General that on 25 June 1982 he referred me to the New South Wales Government as the purported statement which Mr Sinclair maintains is a false and concocted one was produced by policemen under the jurisdiction of that Government, that is, the New South Wales Government. Is the Attorney-General aware that my correspondence with the New South Wales Premier remains without substantive answer? Is he also aware from tapes produced by me and other sources that the New South Wales Police Minister, Mr Peter Anderson, displayed on 5 August 1982 the alleged original statement on a Channel 10 program entitled The Reporters? In the light of these developments, will the Attorney-General now exercise his good offices to persuade the New South Wales Government, firstly, to produce for inspection and tests by Mr William Sinclair and his legal and forensic advisers the alleged 'original' document; and, secondly, thereafter produce such document to the Thai court where a photostat rather than the original was presented, despite assurances to the contrary by the same police officers, so that the rights to justice by this Australian citizen in a foreign court can be properly preserved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not aware of the matters that have been raised by Senator Missen until yesterday when he did give me some information concernng the problem that he has run into with the New South Wales Government. He had taken up with me a number of matters concerning the appeal that has been lodged by the Thai Government in regard to an acquittal of Mr Sinclair by a court of appeal in Thailand which occurred recently and requested, I think, my assistance in the obtaining of a number of matters in aid of the defence of Mr Sinclair. My view was that most of the matters-I think all except one-were really not within my jurisdiction or indeed that of the Australian Government. One of those matters certainly comes within the responsibility of the New South Wales Government, and I pointed that out to Senator Missen. I am pleased to note that, as one would expect, he has taken up that matter assiduously. He does not seem to have been able to get anywhere with the New South Wales Government, which is disappointing , to say the least, and perhaps surprising also.

ANSWER.PARA: I will look at the matter he has raised to see whether there is anything I can do. Certainly it is not within my power to do anything, except insofar as we might try to obtain documents for transmission to Thailand through the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs. I will follow up the question to see whether there is anything further I can do.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I acknowledge that the Governor-General's Speech to the Parliament is prepared by the government of the day. I ask the Minister whether the Governor-General, in his November 1980 Speech referred to 'the economic recovery now underway'. Was there in fact an economic recovery under way? If so, what has happend to it now?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact of the matter is that the whole world knows that Australia was being recognised by overseas countries, including the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, as a country that was making better progress than other countries towards overcoming the difficulties of an outside world recession. On the evidence available it would have been the right thing to have so assumed. Indeed, Australia's performance justified that. What has happened, and every economic commentator has noted it, is that the world outside Australia has gone into deeper recession, has withdrawn its-
—But they have lower rates of inflation.

—I will come to that in a moment. I might invite Senator Gietzelt to co-operate with the Australian public-people in overseas countries have done this-to overcome inflation. What has happened is that overseas countries, because of a lack of foreign exchange and because of recession, are buying less and paying less for primary products and, particularly, for minerals. Australia, therefore, is moving towards recession. I remind Senator Gietzelt and his colleagues that those countries which had higher inflation rates than Australia have all adopted wage restraint, to a point where wage restraint has been taken as a significant weapon in getting down inflation.

ANSWER.PARA: What has happened is that overseas as wages fell so inflation fell, whereas in Australia wages rose. What we are saying now to the Australian people is that if they wanted to be able to restore their place in the world trade then they should adopt the general tactics adopted by overseas countries, and I include governments which are not of Liberal faith, and co-operate generally throughout the nation to get costs down. This can be done primarily by exercising wage restraint and, secondly, by reducing the incidence of industrial action in Australia, which forces up costs, causes great harm to the reputation of Australia and results in the loss of trade.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and relates to the Bureau of Statistics and to a question which appeared on last year's census form. The results of that question have created some concern, particularly amongst members of the County Shire Councils Association of Western Australia. The question to which I refer stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Where is your usual place of residence?

Most country shires contain a large number of people such as school teachers and contractors who may spend several years in a country area and draw upon the facilities provided by the local government but who respond to that question by giving a metropolitan address. The implication of this matter is that the West Australian Grants Commission allocates 70 per cent of local government tax sharing-element A- on a weighted population basis to the possible disadvantage of country people. I ask: Will the Minister request the Bureau to produce adjusted population figures which will give more accurately guidance to the States Grants Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether there is any great magnitude of error in those statistics along the lines suggested in the question . If there is any great incidence of change in relation to those who have used an address as a usual place of residence, in contrast to some other address, I assume that the statistics are weighted accordingly. However, I could ask the Treasurer to refer the matter to the Bureau of Statistics. If it is one of some importance I assume that local government has made representations to the Commonwealth Grants Commission, as would be competent for it to do. However, I am not aware of the size of the problem and will see whether I can get any information in regard to it.

—I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question concerning a matter about which I asked him on 18 May last in regard to Argentina and nuclear weaponry. Is the Minister concerned that Argentina is not a party to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, has not ratified the Treaty for the prohibition of nuclear weapons in Latin America, yet trades in nuclear technology with countries which have nuclear co-operation agreements with Australia and which, presumably, can buy Australia's uranium? Is the Minister concerned that 'full-scope' International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards do not apply to trading in nuclear technology between West Germany, which has been notorious for selling nuclear secrets to Argentina, and Argentina? Can the Minister outline the efforts his Government is undertaking to ensure that Argentina's nuclear facilities will come under legally binding IAEA safeguards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Chipp has indicated, he asked me a question on this subject on 18 May. I partially answered the question then and said that I would seek further information, not only from my own sources, but also from other departments concerned. Today I have given him a very detailed answer by way of a letter running to four pages, the text of which will be incorporated in Hansard. If Senator Chipp examines carefully-as he will-the details of that letter he will find, in fact, specific answers to what he is asking. First, not only has there been an expression of concern by Australia but also actions have been taken by it in regard to that concern. It is true that Argentina is not a party to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and does not meet the minimum requirements for nuclear co-operation with Australia as such. Australia's fissile material will not go to Argentina-
—How can you be sure of that?

—I accept Senator Chipp's interjection as expressing a very valid question. The Australian Safeguards Office has the absolute responsibility of monitoring the progress of every kilogram of yellowcake that leaves Australia, including its change into various forms as it is procecessed- whether it is upgraded, enriched, made into fuel rods or reprocessed, indeed wherever it goes. Therefore, we are able to indicate that it will not be used for the benefit of others who are not signatories to the NPT. That is the role of the Safeguards Office. It is one that as Senator Chipp will understand, we are endeavouring to strengthen. Indeed, only recently in Vienna I had fairly lengthy talks with the International Atomic Energy Agency on exactly these matters, on how we could tighten to the nth degree what we are doing. So in keeping with its policy, the Government is paying close attention to Argentina's nuclear program and to safeguards arrangements which apply to nuclear items supplied to that country.

ANSWER.PARA: A number of countries have supplied nuclear items to Argentina under separate IAEA safeguard arrangements-I repeat, under separate IAEA safeguard arrangements . They include Canada, the Federal Republic of Germany, Switzerland, the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I have no knowledge at all that West Germany's trade with the Argentines is other than within the strictest terms of the International Atomic Engergy Agency's separate arrangements.

Australia made suggestions for strenghtening the safeguards arrangements for these facilities in discussions of the Board of Governors of the IAEA in Vienna last year and in consultations with other governments. We made the various suggestions that I have set out. Australia called attention to the fact that in the case of a country such as Argentina, which has not accepted the legal obligation to apply full scope safeguards, the resulting safeguards coverage by a number of separate agreements resulted in fragmentation. So we are active not only in expressing concern but also in our role in the governing body of the IAEA in trying to get an upgrading of the safeguards. The Government would welcome a legally binding agreement by Argentina to place all of its nuclear facilities now and in the future under IAEA safeguards, and the Government will continue to direct its efforts towards this objective. I will underline to our representative on the governing board, Professor George, that it is imperative that we try to achieve these goals.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Resources and Energy. During the winter recess the Government gave considerable attention to the urgent matter of Australian water resources, and in particular to the good management of the River Murray system. I ask the Minister: Is the restructuring now complete in regard to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation research units concerning ground water, salinity and water resources generally; is the new River Murray Agreement now also formally complete; and, finally, is the national advisory body to the Commonwealth Government fully established and working?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks the Government-I in particular-has been very active in regard to water resources in Australia. Some honourable senators will know that I spent the last three days of last week on a very detailed inspection of the River Murray, from mouth to source, in which course of time some honourable senators joined me. We received something like 30 deputations, both written and verbal. I am happy to say that the River Murray Agreement has no obstacles in its way. The Victorian Government has announced its willingness to sign and the signing is proceeding, from the Commonwealth to the six States. I believe that the signing should have taken place within the next week or two. The legislation is drafted and it should be possible for it to be in this Parliament and in the State parliaments in the immediate future. So it is good news on the River Murray. Work is being done particularly on strengthening quality control for the River Murray.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator asked about the CSIRO. He will know that the Government asked the CSIRO to look at all the various water resource activities throughout its very big organisation and to determine whether it could get co-ordination, in terms of both ground water control and water quality. My understanding is that that, at least in concept, has been finalised and decisions have been made that that can be done. I should add that it has gone further than that: We have determined that there should be a complete link between the CSIRO and its facilities, the Bureau of Mineral Resources in its water activities, the Bureau of Meteorology and the Atomic Energy Commission. We are pulling the whole of the act together. Some time ago the ministerial council, the Australian Water Resources Council, made a series of recommendations, one of which was that there should be a national water research council of a kind similar to the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council. I announced this last week and I announced that we will be setting up its actual membership in the very near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was done to head off Ralph Jacobi's Institute of Freshwater Studies, wasn't it? That's the whole purpose of it. It's second best.
—I remind the interjector who said it is second best that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources said that this would be best and that a freshwater institute would not be.
—When did it say that?
—In the Standing Committee Report. I would be very happy to direct the attention of the Senate to the reference.
—You are making this up as you go along.

—I repeat that a Standing Committee of the Senate recommended that there would be grave difficulties in the concept of an institute. I do not denigrate Mr Jacobi's goals. Mr Jacobi is aiming to get better control of water quality and quantity in Australia and I commend him for that. But the seven State Ministers and the Commonwealth Ministers in their council agreed that the right way, the first class way, was through a national water research council. They had the knowledge of the recommendations of Mr Jacobi. They proceeded with this and we have done so too.

—Does the Minister representing the Prime Minister recall that the Governor-General in his November 1980 Speech said that firm anti-inflationary fiscal and monetary policies were essential to any lasting solution to the problems of unemployment, the achieving of higher growth and the more rapid raising of living standards on a sustainable basis? Did he go on to say that there was no alternative to such policies and that any such alternative, including those policies described as stimulatory, would set back the economic recovery then under way? I ask the Minister whether it is still the Government's view that any stimulatory policy or degree of stimulation is inappropriate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no doubt that what Senator Ryan referred to is a faithful extract from the Governor-General's speech of 1980. It is also a paraphrase of Mr Hayden's Budget Speech of 1975. I commend that speech to Senator Ryan, and indeed I would be delighted to read to Senator Ryan the words with which Mr Hayden argued that it would be wrong simply to inflate the money supply to create jobs and that in fact by putting more money into the community more inflation and more unemployment are created. Indeed, since she queries this , tomorrow I will bring with me a copy of the actual phrases. I have no doubt at all that what the Governor-General said in 1980 was what Mr Hayden knew in 1975 but did not practise. Indeed, everybody knows that if there is an undue expansion by deficit financing, by simply inflating a currency and bringing pressure upon interest rates in a community, it creates an upsurge of inflation and creates unemployment. On record is Mr Hayden's arguing this as the essential premise of his 1975 Budget Speech. I recommend that Senator Ryan look at that.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to his statement a moment ago regarding the establishment of a national water research council. This move is highly commendable and undoubtedly will please Mr Jacobi, but I want to query the proposed membership of this council. Does the Minister recognise that for this body to be most effective it should be representative of all users of water in Australia and not simply of water administrators of Government departments? If so, will the Minister consider appointing a representative from large industries, which of course will become increasingly reliant on adequate supplies of good water in the future? Will it be within the competence of the council to deal with the diversion for inland use of the more than 50 per cent of Australia's rainfall that currently flows wastefully into the sea? If so, will he ensure that provision is made so that appropriate engineering expertise is appointed to the council, possibly from the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Water Resources Council will be one of the significant instrumentalities in supervising the long term conservation and use, both in quantity and quality, of our most limited resource-water. I announced that its goals would include advice on goals for water research, a continuing overview of water research to develop an overall balanced national water research effort, recommendations on national water research needs, priorities, funding levels and appropriate programs and projects, and advice on an effective program of technology transfer to water authorities and users. With regard to Senator Jessop's second last question-I think this relates to his whole question-the council would have a wide-ranging interest in looking at the whole of the uses of Australian water, and particularly the fact that we are sending into the sea about half of the precious water that we have.

ANSWER.PARA: Therefore, the Government believes that this important initiative will enable an orderly expansion of established water research organisations. This represents a far more practical and cost-effective approach to meet the challenge of water research. The Government will shortly consider the membership of this council. As I mentioned in my Press statement, and as I respond to Senator Jessop, it will include user, management and research experience, including engineering expertise. With regard to the honourable senator's comment on the discharge of river waters into the ocean, it would not be appropriate for me to foreshadow the extent to which this occurrence will influence the deliberation of the council, but of course it will be very significant indeed. Yes, it will include engineering experience and user experience. It will be, as it takes shape, like the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council-widely representative of its particular discipline.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. If the Prime Minister had not broken his many promises to index the tax schedule, would not personal income tax be automatically reduced by $1,500m in tonight's Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, unlike the previous Government, believed that it should strive to index tax.
—Promised to.
—Promised to.
—The previous Government, the present Opposition, did not, in fact, try to do so.
—It did not promise to, either.

—No, the Whitlam Government did not promise to, because it harvested inflation. It was the classic example of harvesting inflation for its own tax purposes. I do not know what the value of indexation would be, but I suggest that since Senator Walsh does not know the contents of tonight's Budget he should contain himself until he does know.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that the Soviet Ambassador to Australia was recently invited to the campus of the University of Western Australia by the Vice-Chancellor as an official guest of the University? Is it also a fact that His Holiness the Dalai Lama of Tibet, who is a spiritual head of the Tibetan people and who was driven from that country by the Communist invasion in 1950, was invited to visit the University by the Dean of the Faculty of Medicine but will not be accorded the dignity of an official welcome by the Vice-Chancellor? Can the Minister explain the apparent discrepancy in the treatment of these two foreign dignitaries? Was the Vice-Chancellor in any way reflecting the attitude of the Federal Government towards His Holiness, and does the Government consider this treatment as an insult to him and his position? Finally, does the Minister condemn such insulting and uneven-handed behaviour towards His Holiness the Dalai Lama and his followers in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that the Soviet Ambassador was in Western Australia earlier this year, but I cannot confirm whether he was accorded an official welcome by the University of Western Australia. I have no knowledge of the nature of his visit to the University or otherwise. The Dalai Lama sought entry into Australia as a private and non-official visitor. Again, I am not able to comment with regard to his visit to the University of Western Australia. I do not know whether the University of Western Australia gave him official or non-official status as a guest, or whether he had any particular treatment in any visit that he made to that university. I think that the non- official nature of his visit to Australia was sought by him when he asked for entry to Australia. I can only comment that I think his visit has attracted a wide and deep interest on the part of many Australians, and that he has been impressive in those interviews that I have seen. I think that the dignity and courtesy with which he has conducted those interviews would make him a welcome visitor. But, as I say, I have no knowledge of the attitude of the University of Western Australia in this matter. In his non-official visit, I hope that he has enjoyed seeing this country and that the people who have met him have enjoyed that visit, too.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Given the facts with which I have provided the Minister, does she condemn the University of Western Australia for its uneven-handed attitude towards the Dalai Lama?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given that the statements made by the honourable senator may be an accurate record of the circumstances, I am still not in a position to comment on the status that the University of Western Australia would accord to any visitor who went there in an official or personal capacity. I think that that is a matter in the hands of the vice-chancellor or whatever body in the university asked the Dalai Lama to attend. I make no further comment on that. I do not think there is any point in the pursuit by the honourable senator of any further comment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask the Minister whether he is aware of the statement by Professor Russell Mathews, a distinguished adviser to the Government at various times who said:

QUESTION.PARA: The present Government has used tax indexation as an overt political device by twice promising before elections to introduce it and by abolishing it as soon as possible thereafter.

Is he aware that the Prime Minister once said that tax indexation was the way to keep governments honest? Will Senator Carrick admit that the Government has used the taxation system to exploit wage and salary earners at the expense of other income earners? Can we have an assurance that any tax relief in this Budget will redress these imbalances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Implicit in this, of course, is that any Government that does not attempt to use tax indexation at all must be exploiting wage and salary earners. I remind the Senate that between 1973 and 1975 there was no attempt to introduce tax indexation, and therefore Senator Grimes has condemned his own party. At least the present Government attempted to introduce tax indexation. Of course, it is true that if one has inflation and does not make adjustments, one is harvesting inflation and getting in higher taxes. That is beyond doubt. It is true that if, indeed, a government is to be compelled to keep its costs down and to keep government small, perhaps the most effective way is through tax indexation and that, I have no doubt, is what Mr Fraser had in mind. Nevertheless, the Government was not able to do this fully; on the other hand, we did so much better than our predecessors who, on Senator Grimes's basis , were openly exploiting the taxpayer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I again draw the Minister's attention to the remarks of Professor Russell Mathews, which the Minister chose to ignore in his dishonest answer. Has the Minister any comment on the words of Professor Mathews? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: The present Government has used tax indexation as an overt political device by twice promising before elections to introduce it and by abolishing it as soon as possible thereafter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not ignore those remarks. I spoke to the fact that tax harvesting in times of inflation is the exploitation of the taxpayer. I make no doubt about that. What I said was that our Government, unlike the previous Government, the Whitlam Government, did try tax indexation and partial tax indexation. The previous Government made no such attempt. It made an open exploitation of the taxpayer, and the taxpayers settled that argument in 1975, 1977 and 1980, and will do so in the future. The fact of the matter is that at least we have tried to control the volume of taxation whereas the Whitlam Government simply harvested it.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. The Minister will recall that I asked him a question on 18 March 1982 regarding the call by the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia for a full inquiry into small business in Australia. Has the Minister seen the August edition of 'Small Business Review', which again calls for such an inquiry into small business, particularly on such questions as alleged discriminatory taxation policy, inequitable financial treatment, and the impact of high level tariffs on small business? In view of the major importance of small business to the Australian economic and social well-being, will the Government reconsider its earlier refusal to institute such an inquiry?

—In the reply which I gave to the honourable senator earlier this year I indicated why the Government thought that such an inquiry was not necessary. The recent edition of the newsletter to which he referred was sent to me, in common, I think, with other members of the Parliament, and I have noted the further call by the organisation for a public inquiry. I have not had a chance to discuss that matter with the Minister for Industry and Commerce. I will seek his advice on the matter and let the honourable senator have a reply.

—I ask the Minister for Finance whether she is aware of statements made last month by Professor Russell Mathews that Australia's taxation system has 'made Australia one of the world's most charitable tax havens for the rich capitalist, and probably the only one in an economically advanced country'. Will the Minister indicate how the Government proposed to alleviate the massive and inequitable tax burden which this Government has placed on wage and salary earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did notice the comments in the Press by Professor Russell Mathews. I do not think that I saw the full text of any address he made on the subject. Within the time frame of the Budget, which is to be presented in just a short time, I think it would be more appropriate to discuss some of these things at a future time. To embark upon an analysis of what the Federal Government proposes to do about certain things on the day of the Budget, prior to the Budget Speech, would seem to me an ill-timed attitude to take on these matters. If the Opposition were not showing such nervousness about the fact that it thinks there is to be some tax relief in the Budget that is to be announced, it might be in a better position to discuss at a later time some of the questions it is raising today.
—I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister whether, in view of the answer which she has not given, she would concede that Professor Mathews's analysis was correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Professor Mathews is entitled to express a view he may have about the application of personal income tax or company tax or whatever other form of tax his address had relation to. If we wished then to analyse the application of rates of tax, personal tax, average rates of tax, company tax and so on, perhaps that would be a productive exercise, but it is not one upon which I would embark at this time.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In the discussions on closer economic relations with New Zealand, has any progress been achieved in having the New Zealand import licensing system for fresh fruit and vegetables, which is due to continue until 1995, readjusted to a shorter or more reasonable period?

—The proposals which have been produced for closer economic relations with New Zealand provide for New Zealand's import licensing regime to be phased out by 1995 and, in the interim, for Australian industries to be provided with improved access into New Zealand. The question was critical of the 1995 date, but the negotiation of that date for the phasing out of import licensing was one of the most difficult parts of the discussions and represented a major change in the New Zealand Government's position. The Government will shortly be giving consideration to the next steps to be taken in the closer economic relations process, and industry's views on this matter will be taken into account at that time. I say that because industry, like Senator Archer, has been critical of the distance we have to travel before we get to 1995. The interim licensing arrangements proposed provide for exports by the Australian fruit and vegetable industry to be given special access into New Zealand. The industry and government officials are currently looking to see whether the proposed level of access for fruit and vegetables is commercially viable. When these details are available the issue will be taken up with New Zealand.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the Prime Minister's call for restraint by the Australian work force, what action has the Prime Minister taken to require the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, to set a like example by relinquishing his most favourable Commonwealth home loan mortgage of $17,964, which was granted to him on 17 December 1964 for a period of 45 years at the fixed interest rate of 4.75 per cent and which, at 1 October 1981, still had an amount of $15,005 owing? As a large number of Australian citizens have protested to the Parliament by way of petitions at these most generous terms granted to the Deputy Prime Minister, who ranks amongst the highest income earners in Australia, when can these petitioners expect similar generous terms to be extended to the many thousands of desperate home owners throughout Australia who are now in grave danger of losing their homes because of crippling high interest rates and record unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLaren will know that the particular conditions that were made available to Ministers and office holders who were required to spend a considerable time in Canberra were made available to and were availed of by members of both sides of the Parliament. The concessions as such were used by members on both sides of the Parliament. There was nothing unusual in the conditions as they were set up. Governments of the day, including the Whitlam Government, knowing those conditions, maintained them. The conditions as they persisted and exist today were conditions which both Labor governments and others set up and maintained. Under those conditions, no one person should be prejudiced against others from all parties who have observed them.
—I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that Mr Anthony-

—I raise a point of order. I know that it is the first day of the parliamentary sittings and at this stage the Opposition always has a few questions it wants to ask. Later on in the session it will not have many. Mr President, I ask how long you will allow the Opposition to continue to ask two questions for every one that is asked on this side of the chamber? I put it to you that these are not supplementary questions.
—I ask the chamber to come to order. I cannot hear the question which is being put to the Chair. I would like to hear the question so that I can respond accordingly.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Lewis

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I put to you the ruling of President Sir Magnus Cormack on 22 August 1973, when he said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . I shall allow supplementary questions in order to elucidate an answer.

Mr President, I put it to you that the questions that have been put by the Opposition today are second questions and have nothing to do with elucidating the answer of the Minister. I ask you to rule on whether they will be permitted to continue to ask two questions for every one from our side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to speak to the point of order. With respect to the point of order raised by Senator Lewis-I quite agree with him that a supplementary question can be allowed in order to elucidate an answer-I think your ruling ought to be in respect of the Ministers who continually refuse to answer the questions that have been put up to date. Had we been getting co-operation from the Ministers, and direct answers, we would not be in this position where we have to prise answers out of the Government.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, I respond first to Senator Bolkus. I have said on many occasions with regard to Ministers responding to questions put to them that Ministers have every right to answer the question as they see fit. I suggest to honourable senators that if they look at some of the questions asked today they will see that they offend by their length and their request for detail. If we are going to draw very heavily on and stick very strictly to guidelines, I will also have to respond to some of those questions which are too lengthy.

INTERJECT.PARA: With regard to the point raised by Senator Lewis, according to my record, at this moment there have been two supplementary questions, one asked by the Government side and one asked by the Opposition side. I am yet to hear the supplementary question by Senator McLaren and I will respond to his supplementary question after I have heard it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My supplementary question to Senator Carrick is: Is it not a fact that Mr Anthony, the Deputy Prime Minister, is the only existing member of parliament who still has this privileged home loan and, in deference to your answer, is it not also a fact that Mr Whitlam, as Prime Minister, issued a decree that no more of these privileged loans would be made available to members of the Parliament, particularly Ministers? My question was: What action has the present Prime Minister taken to see that Mr Anthony now relinquishes those special privileges which have been bestowed upon him?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware whether Mr Anthony is the only existing member of Parliament who is a current holder of a home loan under the scheme. I know that various names have been suggested here in the past. I am not aware of any such edict by Mr Whitlam. Mr Whitlam did not stop the scheme as such. I do not know of any action taken by Mr Anthony to terminate the situation. I will direct the supplementary question to the Prime Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Can the Minister confirm or deny the report attributed to the Prime Minister of Fiji that he suspects that the Australian Broadcasting Commission television program Four Corners may have unknowingly been the tool of the Russians or their sympathisers in their efforts to oust him from office? Can the Minister tell me whether there is to be any inquiry into this very serious allegation against the ABC and, if so, will the Parliament be told the result of that inquiry? Can the Minister also tell me whether there is any connection between this report and the reported activities of the Soviet Union in disinformation activities reported to be taking place currently in Spain, Greece , Africa, Denmark and Sweden as contained in the United States International Communication Agency Backgrounder dated 8 July 1982?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was aware during the election which took place and to which the honourable senator refers that there was some trouble in which accusations were made against the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I was as disturbed, as any Australian would be, that an organisation which has such high esteem in this country should come under attack, especially when it was difficult for those of us in Australia, from reading the reports, to quite work out what the complaints were about or on what basis they rested. I am not able to advise Senator Lewis of the answer to the specific question he puts, that is, as to whether there was any accusation that the ABC was some kind of client of Russian interest or, indeed, whether there had been a program of Soviet disinformation which had led to the present situation.

ANSWER.PARA: It is appropriate, in view of the seriousness of this matter and in view of the concern of all of us, for the good name of the ABC, that this matter be referred to the Minister whom I represent for an early and detailed answer to Senator Lewis's question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer her to the Treasurer's statement of 27 June on the McCabe- Lafranchi report in which the Treasurer outlined the extraordinary saga of confusion, timidity, pathological lethargy and sheer lack of political will on the part of the present Government in dealing with the bottom-of-the harbour tax avoidance and evasion schemes after they first came to official notice in the early 1970s. Will the Minister table, within the next 24 hours, with the names of possible individual defendants erased, if necessary, all the opinions which the Government has received from the Crown Solicitor's Office and from private legal counsel as to whether prosecutions could be sustained against any of the persons involved in such schemes whether as promoters, vendors or purchasers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer the question to the Treasurer for any appropriate action that he feels he wishes to take.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. I refer to the recent cost allocation review of the Independent Air Fares Committee and in particular to the Committee's advocacy of government subsidies on services such as those provided by ANA, that is, Airlines of Northern Australia, to Katherine and Tennant Creek. I understand that these subsidies are presently offered over western routes in Queensland and on services between Melbourne and Tasmania. Will the Minister advise the Senate of the Government's attitude to providing financial assistance to the Northern Territory regional air services where distance, remoteness and sparse population bring about high costs factors on air fares and air freight?

—It is true that, for instance, in Western Queensland, there is a government subsidy for the continuance of the operation of F27 aircraft in that area which has had quite a problem maintaining services on an economic basis. It is also true to acknowledge that the State of Tasmania does receive a form of subsidy for all kinds of transport deficiencies which that State suffers as an island State. This of course is government policy in order to maintain some kind of parity with the mainland. As for other requests for subsidies of the kind mentioned by Senator Kilgariff, each of them would need to be considered on an individual basis. I think all I could do in this particular case would be to refer that matter to the Minister and obtain a further reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask the Minister whether she is aware of a Sydney tax consultancy service which offers its very large ethnic clientele tax refunds before their income tax return is even lodged with the Australian Taxation Office in exchange for the clients signing over their income tax refund entitlements to the agency. As a result, the agency is pocketing large sums of money since the true Taxation Office refunds are usually a great deal more than the original sum paid to the unsuspecting clients by the agency. Further, I ask the Minister: What are the powers of the Tax Agents Registration Board in dealing with such an agency? I ask this because I have good reason to believe that the Board has known about this agency's operation for some time but has not done anything about it. Will the Minister agree that the practices mentioned in my question are completely unethical? If so, will the Government take steps to immediately outlaw these exploitive practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter outlined by Senator Sibraa does appear to be unethical and certainly inequitable. If arrangements are being made that deprive tax clients of their full refunds- I assume the deduction that is made from them is the fee for services rendered-I do not know whether the Australian Taxation Office has knowledge of such a scheme as has been referred to within the ethnic communities. If there is any knowledge in the hands of the Treasurer or if he is able to gain any and seeks to take any action to redress this scheme, I can have that advice given to the Senate when the Treasurer is able to respond to it. I will draw the matter to the Treasurer's attention to see whether we can get some reaction to the matters outlined by Senator Sibraa.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bonner Sen N.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications whether he is aware of an article appearing in today's Daily Telegraph headed ' Cable TV may pose a risk to privacy, says judge'. The learned Mr Justice Michael Kirby is reported to have further said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the new technology took TV beyond being a means of entertainment to becoming a system of collecting and supplying information.
Cable TV could be used to collect information on people's political views, buying habits and financial transactions.
I ask the Minister: What steps does the Government propose to take to protect subscribers' privacy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Most honourable senators will be aware of the work of Mr Justice Kirby in a number of spheres, including those which relate to people's rights, through law reform, which is his interest. Some honourable senators will have seen the article which Senator Bonner said appeared in this morning's Daily Telegraph. There was also an article in the Canberra Times, which is the one I saw. The Government is aware of the possibilities arising from new technologies and the fact that these new possibilities include what one might call downside risks as well. The Department of Communications, together with other departments such as the Attorney-General's Department, is monitoring developments through institutions such as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development committee on information, computers and information policy. At this stage it is proper to point out that the Government has not taken a policy decision on what sort of cable television, if any, would be introduced in Australia. That makes it even more appropriate that Mr Justice Kirby should have spoken out at this time, as it were putting before us, before we have taken a decision, some of the problems which we could face with the introduction of new technology.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister whether the Prime Minister in his 1977 policy speech said:

QUESTION.PARA: We have been able to reduce inflation, reform the tax system and start interest rates falling.

Does the Minister acknowledge that there has been no significant decrease in the rate of inflation over the last three years, that interest rates are at record levels and that the overall effect of the changes to the tax system since 1975 has simply been to place a greater relative burden on lower and middle income earners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister did say those words in 1977 and they are abundantly true. When the Government came to office in 1975 the inflation rate was running at 17 1/2 per cent according to the Australian Statistician. We managed to reduce it to 9 per cent. It is now something over 10 per cent. So we did, in fact, very substantially reduce the rate of inflation. We were able to so modify taxation that, instead of having six or seven stages of the tax scale, we brought it down to three, and the great majority-something more than three quarters-of all taxpayers were in the 32c in the dollar bracket and not in the higher bracket. So quite major reforms were undertaken.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the sad situations is that as the world recession has forced other countries to lower their rates of inflation, in Australia wage spirals and industrial actions have forced costs up. In the immediate past the inflation rate moved upwards. The pressure of overseas interest rates plus our difficulties have given us very high interest rates indeed; one admits that. One of the important things to keep in mind is that this Government has shown that it is willing to go out and attempt to do those things, however unpleasant, that are necessary in order to bear down on inflation, to bear down on costs as such and to seek to overcome industrial unrest, whereas that was not done in the past .

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April-this is recorded at page 1657 of Hansard-I answered a question addressed to me, as Minister for Health, by Senator Hill concerning bed retention fees in nursing homes. The answer I gave at that time requires some clarification. The Commonwealth Government will pay the appropriate nursing home benefit for up to one day a month when a patient is absent and when there is medical confirmation that this is desirable. The patient is still responsible for the difference between the amount of benefit and the fee charged by the proprietor of the nursing home up to the full approved fee.

—Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 27 May 1982, I lay on the table the report of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare relating to homeless youth which was presented to me on 13 August 1982. In accordance with the terms of the resolution, I have authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I shall make a brief statement relating to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare concerning homeless youth. In considering this report I believe the main issue at stake is whether we, as a community-that includes both the Commonwealth and State governments-are prepared to spend time and resources now to try to redress this problem. Failure to do so will simply allow a growing number of unfortunate young people to drift into a Skid Row type of existence. There is already ample evidence to show that the average age of our Skid Row population has fallen dramatically over recent years.

One of the things that our Committee cannot stress strongly enough is that programs for homeless youth should not be developed in conjunction with the traditional homeless persons program. It is not appropriate for homeless youth to be housed with the older hard-core homeless. It would be an admission of failure if we did not develop specific programs for homeless youth. If we can help these young people become productive members of our society, the time and cost in the short term will surely be outweighed by both the social and economic benefits gained in the long term. A recent United States Senate report stated that homeless youths' needs are hardly extravagant and certainly fall within the inalienable rights of all people. I believe this to be so for homeless youth in Australia.

The Committee's recommendations are, I believe, both sound and practical and cannot be categorised as extravagant. Therefore the implementation of our recommendations, even under the current economic conditions, will go a long way to help redress the plight of homeless youth. I do not propose at this stage to discuss any details of the report, but I seek leave to continue my remarks on the next day of sitting.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table further information received by Estimates Committee C on the Additional Estimates for 1981-82 and seek leave for it to be incorporated in the Hansard record of the Committee's proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

DEBATE.TITLE: AIR ACCIDENTS (COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982CIVIL AVIATION (CARRIERS' LIABILITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 May, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Civil Aviation ( Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill is to amend Part IV of the principal Act, the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959, to raise the limitation on damages for personal injury suffered in a commercial air accident from $45,000 to $100,000, operative from the dates to be proclaimed. I think a significant feature of the debate on this legislation in the dying hours of the House of Representatives in May this year-it seems that this feature will recur in the Senate-was the lack of Government interest in the legislation. One wonders why there is no concern on the back benches of the Government parties about a proposition that falls far short of what should be the liability requirements with respect to air accidents in the Commonwealth of Australia. It may well be that honourable senators opposite take the view that increasing the limitation on damages from $45,000 to $100,000 is adequate. However, based on the criterion of previous determinations that have been made by Liberal and conservative governments the Opposition has put up a case for a cover of at least $130,000. Of course, we have raised-I intend to do so again when moving a second reading amendment to the Bill-the whole question of third party insurance for passengers who travel by both private and public aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it must be generally recognised that since the House of Representatives dealt with this legislation there has been a very significant downturn in air traffic movement throughout the world as well as in our own country. In fact, the evidence shows that the airline industry generally is in a state of decline and near bankruptcy in many countries and that the crisis which has overtaken the airline industry overseas has had some impact upon our international airline , Qantas Airways Ltd, as well as an influence on the financial capability of the two airlines-one government and one private-which operate in Australia. Of course, in recent times we have seen a very decided downturn in transport service in this country in particular. I do not think it is good enough to increase the quality of the food or the amount of alcohol offered to passengers if in fact there is a deterioration in the transport service itself. This deterioration is particularly marked in aircraft operations in and out of Canberra.

There has been a dramatic change in the whole airline industry since this matter was debated in May. Consequently one would think that if Government members in particular were interested in the airline industry and the rights of passengers, the consumers, they would have been prepared to participate in the debate. However, they did not do so in the House of Representatives. Debate was left to the Opposition with the exception of a brief interlude by the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Donald Cameron), who supported a proposition relating to compensation following an aircraft accident near a Brisbane airfield. One can only say that there is a lack of concern by the Government about this problem.

I have referred to liability provisions in respect of airline passengers. The legislation also provides for the limit on liability for damage to registered baggage to be raised from the existing $300 to $900 and for the limit on hand baggage to be raised from $30 to $90. Clause 3 of the Bill widens the definition of airline licence and charter licence to ensure that carriage by operators following the introduction of the new air service licence classifications later in 1982 will be covered by the provisions of the principal Act. In the view of the Australian Labor Party the increased limits of compensation provided for in the Bill are inadequate, although, of course, increases are long overdue. Because they are long overdue the Opposition does not intend to oppose the Bill. However it wishes to express some concern. Therefore I propose to move:

At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that provision should be made for the introduction of third party personal injury insurance in respect of all aircraft operated in Australia and which are not covered by this Bill and the principal Act'.

I think it has to be said that compensation is rarely paid with respect to aircraft accidents in Australia. Everybody in Australia and in the Parliament accepts the very high standard of safety control that has been determined by the Department of Aviation. We are aware of the fact that we have a very high standard, if not the highest standard in the world. If we accept that as being part of conventional wisdom-I think we can-one wonders why we haggle over compensation. If that standard is maintained, particularly with respect to the major airline operators, it is clear that the compensation liability ought to be subject to rises commensurate with rises in the standard of living based on average weekly earnings.

I remind the Senate-this might have escaped the attention of honourable senators-that in the last few months we have not had so many small aircraft accidents resulting in injury and fatalities as occurred early this year. However there have been one or two in the last few months. Although small private aircraft and charter aircraft are becoming a popular means of transport in our country passengers do not necessarily understand that they could be inadequately covered in the case of accident or death. The Opposition has been put in the position of being the watch dog for the general public. There is enough evidence to show that this legislation is inadequate. Although we recognise that inadequacies and shortcomings exist we are not prepared to cut off our nose to spite our face. We are prepared to recognise that, notwithstanding all the limitations I have referred to, there is a case for supporting the legislation.

I have moved a second reading amendment calling for the introduction of a third party personal injury insurance for passengers on all aircraft operated in Australia. We believe that it would be untenable for the Government not to take this proposal on board. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) acknowledged in the House of Representatives that the shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Morris, made some significant suggestions in the debate. Nevertheless, the Government was not prepared to accept the Opposition's amendment or to give any definite assurances in relation to the criticisms which our party made in the House of Representatives and which we make in this place.

We say that compensation payment of $100,000 in respect of a death is totally inadequate. We know, for example, that in Sydney the cost of a very modest three bedroom house is more that 80 per cent of the proposed amount of compensation payable to the surviving members of the family if they were to lose the breadwinner. The average price of a home in New South Wales is such that this level of compensation is quite inadequate in terms of the current inflationary cost of accommodation which has largely been brought about by the economic policies which have been pursued by this Government. This Government never shows a preparedness to take on board any justifiable points which are raised in debate even though a Minister, as the Minister for Transport did on this occasion, may accept that some significant suggestions had been made.

This legislation affects the rights of consumers. As we recognise, a very large section of the Australian community uses aeroplanes as a means of transport. Whilst we accept that there is a high level of safety control in the movement of air traffic, particularly in the major airlines sector, we cannot understand why the Government is reluctant to relate the amount of compensation liability to average weekly earnings which was the basis upon which the legislation was originally introduced in 1959. The Senate should know the basis upon which liability in this area is assessed and I think the public also should know. I am sure that we are on good ground when we assert that the average person using charter flights in this country is not aware of whether he is adequately insured in respect of injury or death as a result of an aviation accident even having regard to the standard of safety which exists in this country. We are very fortunate compared with other countries in that we do not have the extreme weather conditions experienced in European countries and the United States of America. We have a much more temperate climate. We are in a position to expect that high standard and a low incidence of fatalities arising from aircraft accidents. I remind the Senate of the incident involving an airline aircraft that was returning to Australia recently. It encountered volcanic ash over Indonesia. That was quite an incident. A disaster involving the whole of the aircraft could have occurred. I suppose it was good luck and also good management that the pilot was able finally to get his plane to Australia thus preventing what could have been a disaster like that which is fairly commonplace in many other parts of the world where a plane goes down and all of the passengers lose their lives. One never knows when a passenger may be placed in a position in which the question of the level of compensation is a very important factor for the passenger who is injured or for the members of the family of persons who may lose their lives as a result of an aviation accident.

The essence of the principal Act is that the question of negligence by an air operator in the event of an accident is not contested by the operators, except where the claimant party is shown to have contributed to the cause of the accident. What strikes me as somewhat interesting here is the basis for this legislation. It has the support of the airline operators generally. Of course, they have a vested interest in this matter. I suppose it is part of the cost structure. But we have an overriding responsibility to the general public. If the Parliament does not accept its responsibility to look after the interests of the general public, I am sure nobody else will fulfil that obligation. I think it is our duty within the area of public interest to make sure that the public interest is protected in these matters.

In return, a limit is applied to the amount of damages that can be awarded to a claimant or claimants by the court. In effect, this constitutes a trade off, an admission of liability, in return for a limit on the operator's liability. It thus constitutes a form of no-fault insurance, with resultant savings in litigation costs for both parties. It seems to us that in such a system it is essential for the Parliament to ensure that the limit of compensation be adequate and subjected to regular review in light of changes in money values and personal earning capacities as measured by movements in average weekly earnings. The Government of course has rejected that view which was very strongly put by Mr Morris. The Minister expressed a view relating to variations in international agreements. I think the Warsaw convention tries to achieve some rationality in respect of accident liability. It is desirable to have rationality and uniformity but we should bear in mind the differences in living standards in the various countries. We say that compensation of $100,000 in Australia is not adequate. However, in Thailand, for example, that amount of compensation would represent a fortune. It is difficult to look at this matter in terms of uniformity. Consequently, we must fight the issue on the basis of the local environment to ensure that there is an adequate level of compensation.

When the original legislation was established 23 years ago back in 1959 there was a compensation limit of $15,000. Of course $15,000 in those days represented a lot more in money values than $100,000 represents in today's conditions. It took 11 years before the Minister for Civil Aviation, then Senator Cotton, agreed to double the level of compensation to $30,000 in 1970. In the second reading debate in the Senate he used the increase in average weekly earnings as the basis for increasing the compensation to $30,000. It took another six years to increase the limit by 50 per cent to $45,000. Of course, we all know what the rate of inflation has been in the last six years. It is considerably more than the increase proposed in this legislation. If the rate of inflation or the rate of average weekly earnings is in any way to be the yardstick in this matter, the Opposition is strongly of the view that nothing short of a payment of $130,000 should be laid down in this legislation.

Neither the Minister for Transport in the other place nor the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) who introduced these Bills into this place in the dying stages of the autumn session gave any reason for plucking out of the air, as it were, a figure not related to anything other than just some general determination by the Department or by the responsible Minister. The only explanation given was that it had the agreement of the major air service operators and the Opposition expresses its dissatisfaction with the legislation to that degree. The Opposition recognises, of course, that it is an improvement to increase the amount from $45,000 to $100,000. We will not press the point by opposing the legislation because that would certainly disadvantage a number of claimants. A number of small-operator accidents have occurred in the last year, and we would not want to place in jeopardy any of those claims or claims that might be made after the passage of this legislation.

I think it is true to say that this Government has had a somewhat negligent, ' don't care', even callous attitude. This was graphically illustrated in the events surrounding the tragic Advance Airlines crash of 21 February 1980. As the Press has reported, there have been tragically long delays and difficulties for the families involved. The level of compensation capable of being paid with respect to that case was nowhere adequate to cover the loss of earnings of those who were killed or injured in the accident. Due to the refusal of the Government to adjust the levels of compensation the families affected have suffered very serious disadvantages.

It is not generally realised that passengers travelling by air in other than airline or chartered aircraft covered by this legislation do not have automatic protection in the event of an accident. I know that many honourable senators take advantage of charter arrangements. Whilst it may be argued that that they are covered, people leaving the tarmac at the same time in other aircraft- ordinary members of the public-are not necessarily covered to the same extent as are honourable senators. For example, statistics show that in the years 1976 to 1980 people flying for private and business reasons were involved in 52 per cent of the 1,209 general aviation accidents that occurred. The statistics indicate that there is a lack of cover and that there are management problems in respect of small aircraft because private and business flying hours comprised only 33 per cent of the total hours flown by general aviation.

The absence of automatic third party personal injury insurance coverage can cause financial ruin for pilots and passengers who are unfortunate enough to be involved in an aircraft crash. Many times I have read of people who join such flights at the last minute for reasons that have not been planned, and often those people find that they are not covered by adequate compensation. In fact, in some cases they are not covered at all. It is for these reasons that the Australian Labor Party believes that a system of compulsory third party personal insurance with limited liability attached to the aircraft should be introduced without delay. That is the purpose, of course, of the Opposition's amendment.

I now turn to the Air Accidents (Commonwealth Government Liability) Amendment Bill 1982. This Bill, in line with the provisions of the Civil Aviation ( Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill 1982 which I have just discussed, raises the limit of compensation for personal injury from $45,000 to $100,000. The principal Act applies to Commonwealth employees, to people travelling on Commonwealth business, and to certain situations where the Commonwealth may be operating an aircraft and non-Commonwealth personnel are injured, such as in cases where the Commonwealth has chartered a plane for Commonwealth purposes but the plane also is carrying people who are not engaged on Government business.

These pieces of legislation are very much related and I would have expected the Australian Democrats to have agreed to participate in the debate. I would have expected that the Government would have supplied a speaker to make a general contribution to the debate. The legislation is not being rushed through the Senate, nor was that the environment in which the Bills were debated in the House of Representatives. The same carefree attitude and lack of concern is being exhibited in the Senate. The Australian Labor Party Whip in the Senate has given me a list of speakers in this debate. I note that I am the only speaker on these Bills, apart from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). One would have thought that a little more interest would have been shown by some of the 64 members of the Senate, the majority of whom sit opposite. That confirms the view expressed by the shadow Minister in the House of Representatives that the Government does not seem to be very interested in the whole question of liability, insurance and compensation so far as accidents are concerned. I now propose to move the amendment which I foreshadowed earlier. I move:

At end of motion add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that provision should be made for the introduction of third party personal injury insurance in respect of all aircraft operated in Australia and which are not covered by this Bill and the Principal Act.'
I think there is enough evidence to show that there are passengers, pilots and crew members who are not covered under the general terms of either piece of legislation being debated by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for its support of the legislation. I understand the points made by the Opposition in several respects. I suppose the first point that needs to be made following Senator Gietzelt's argument that the limit should be raised at least to $130,000 is that there is some degree or arbitrariness about his move for a figure such as that. The Government, of course, has arrived at the amount of $100,000, which it regards as a reasonable figure in the circumstances. Senator Gietzelt obviously has researched the matter quite thoroughly, and he does understand the effects of the Warsaw Convention of 1959. If one uses the average weekly earnings inflator, the figure of $15,000 that applied then would be $110,000 today. On the other hand, if we were to apply the consumer price index-Senator Gietzelt referred to this in his remarks-from the date of the commencement of the Warsaw Convention, the sum would be $60,000. On that basis it is somewhat a matter of judgment to decide upon any figure. I think that substantiates the point I seek to make that $100,000 is a reasonable sum in the circumstances. Neither of those tests appears to support Senator Gietzelt's claim that the figure should in fact be $130,000. Nevertheless, I believe that the essential point made by Senator Gietzelt is that adjustments to the limit should be made on a regular basis. I think it is quite clear that the Government is concerned about that point. The legislation provides that that sum can be adjusted by virtue of regulation in future rather than by going through the process of specific legislation, which of course is a lengthy and time-consuming process. By that means the Government hopes that in future any adjustment can be made rapidly after constant review by the departments concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Gietzelt dealt with the third party personal insurance question at some length. I think it is true to say that the Government also is very concerned about the possibility of extending the legislation to embrace private and aerial work operators and with the broader question of compulsory insurance for domestic carriers' liability for passengers. All of those matters are presently under consideration by joint Commonwealth-State government bodies.

The question of a broad third party compulsory insurance scheme to cover such occurrences as damage to people or property on the ground is, as was well and truly emphasised by Senator Gietzelt, one of very great concern. However, one has to acknowledge that it is a very complex issue. As the honourable member would well know, the treatment of this kind of liability varies considerably as between States and as between States and Territories. Some States enforce a no- limit, no-fault regime, while others leave to common law action the determination of liability. Extensive consideration by both the Commonwealth and State governments would be required to determine what options were available for a standardised approach, Australia-wide, to cover both interstate and intrastate operations. That is not to say that the Government has closed its mind or its eyes to the problem about which Senator Gietzelt is so concerned. Rather the point needs to be made that coming to terms with the policies of the various jurisdictions in the area of compensation for third party damages is essentially a practical problem. I believe that deals effectively with the Opposition's motion, which seeks to draw attention to the question of third party personal injury insurance.
