GUIDELINES FOR THE COMMONWEALTH SCHOOLS COMMISSION-1983
(Including Budget Decisions)

The value of programs administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission is continuing to increase in real terms. In 1983 the increase will be 3.9 per cent. Grants totalling $1,240.8m will be provided, compared with $1,194.3m in 1982. All 1983 program amounts in this statement are on an outturn basis and for the purposes of comparison those for 1982 are expressed in the same price terms. As in the past, recurrent grants for non-government schools and for part-time ethnic schools will be made on a per capita basis with the total allocations being determined by actual enrolments.

The Commission is asked to prepare recommendations on the detailed allocation of the funds consistent with these guidelines and as set out in the accompanying tables. To enable consideration of these recommendations and passage of the necessary legislation during the Budget Sittings, the Commission is asked to report by 31 August 1982.
GENERAL RESOURCES PROGRAM

Government Schools General Recurrent Grants-The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation to increase in real terms general recurrent grants for government schools by 2 per cent or $6.3m. These additional resources, which will be available to each State for general educational purposes in government schools, further underline the Government's commitment to all Australian schools . Although there have been overall decreases in government school enrolments, these additional general recurrent grants will assist States to overcome the financial difficulties which the Commission reported were facing government school systems.

Capital Grants-As recommended by the Commission, the Government will maintain in real terms the present level of funding for government school buildings. In order to ensure that the Commonwealth's effort is specifically directed to identified areas of need in government schools, the Government has also accepted the Commission's proposal that a new places element be introduced into the Capital Grants Program. The Government asks the Commission to recommend on the size of this new element and appropriate weightings in its recommendations on capital allocations among States. It also asks the Commission to consider and report on the effects of the new element on existing elements within the program . The Government is unable to accept the recommendation that States be given forward commitment arrangements for government schools capital programs. The Commission is asked to follow up the Government's approach to the States and report on the following arrangements in relation to the Commonwealth's capital program for government schools:

(i) the adoption of measures to obtain greater identification of Commonwealth capital funds for government schools, including States advising in advance of proposals for expenditure of Commonwealth funds for the approval of the Commonwealth Minister;
(ii) measures which might be taken to encourage the States to maintain their effort from their own financial resources for government school building programs; and

(iii) a joint review, with State and non-government school authorities, of the rationalisation of school building provision, taking into account the implications of changing enrolment patterns within and between government and non-government schools and between schools and TAFE.

Non-Government Schools General Recurrent Grants-The Government will continue to provide all non-government schools in Australia with a basic grant equal to 20 per cent of the standard cost of educating a student in a government school and additional grants on the basis of need. In accordance with its 1980 election commitments, the additional grants for Group 3 non-government schools, those with greatest need, will be raised in 1983 from 18 to 20 per cent of standard costs. That is, in 1983, the Government will provide per capita grants for non- government schools on the following basis:
Group 1 Schools: 20 per cent of standard costs
Group 2 Schools: 30 per cent of standard costs
Group 3 Schools: 40 per cent of standard costs
As recommended by the Commission, the Short-Term Emergency Assistance Program for non-government schools is reduced to $0.6 million in 1983 because of significantly reduced demand.

Capital Grants-The Government will provide the third portion of the $25 million in money terms it promised over three years in the 1980 election to help meet the demand for new student places in non-government schools; $9 million is allocated for this purpose in 1983. However, the Government has not adopted the Commission's recommendation that it authorise the forward commitment of up to 90 per cent of the 1983 level of funds for new places for non-government capital funds for 1984 and 1985. Forward commitment arrangements will continue to apply to the basic level of capital funding for non-government schools.

Special Purpose Programs for Government and Non-Government Schools English as a Second Language Program-The Government has agreed to the Commission's proposal that the provision for transferring any surplus funds from the New Arrivals element to the General Support element of the English as a Second Language Program be discontinued. Following its review of the Evaluation of Post-Arrival Programs and Services for Migrants conducted by the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs (AIMA), the Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation for additional funds for the New Arrivals element of the English as a Second Language Program; an additional $1.8 million has therefore been provided to meet the demand for services as a result of the projected increase in newly arrived students.

Consistent with the Government's decision on the Evaluation of Post-Arrival Programs and Services for Migrants, the Commission is asked to initiate a research program to provide information on the English language competence of students from non-English-speaking backgrounds, to identify factors affecting that competence and to develop methods of assessing the English language proficiency of migrant children. Funds for this research are to be provided from within existing programs.

The Commission is asked to ensure that the funds for the Multicultural Education Program are allocated between community language and other multicultural education activities on an approximately equal basis. The present funding of multicultural projects of national significance should be transferred to the Special Projects Program and should support both a multicultural education and a community languages element.
The Commission should broaden its review of the operations of the Multicultural Education Program to include an evaluation of the impact of the Program on school curricula and programs including:
an assessment of the development undertaken in multicultural education through Multicultural Education Program funding;
an evaluation of the impact of these developments;
an assessment of future community language teaching needs;
a phased program for multicultural education and community language teaching to be met by recurrent funding to schools.

The Government has not accepted the Commission's recommendation that additional funds be provided for non-dislocation grants to schools systems affected by the new formula for the distribution of funds under the English as a Second Language Program. The per capita grants of up to $30 for ethnic schools will be continued in 1983 and will be considered further following the current survey of needs by the Commission.

Special Education Program-The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that eligibility criteria for the Special Education Program be altered to enable participation by handicapped children of below school age who require early educational intervention services; appropriate provision will be made in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) legislation. The Commission is asked to recommend on ways of achieving this purpose within the Special Education Program for government and non-government schools.

Disadvantaged Schools Program-The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that funds for the Disadvantaged Schools Program be maintained at the present level in real terms. The Government has also agreed to the Commission's recommendation for a further minor transfer in 1983 of funds under the Disadvantaged Schools Program between sectors, consistent with the Commission's revised funding formula.
The Government has not agreed to the Commission's recommendation that it introduce a new School Improvement Program in 1983.

Joint Programs Shared between Government and Non-Government Schools The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendation that the Severely Handicapped Children's Program be increased by 25 per cent or $0.7 million. The Government will provide the same real level of funds for the Professional Development Program for 1983 (including funds for Education Centres) as recommended by the Commission. In addition, to meet the need for more efficient and longer term budgeting in this program, the Government has accepted the Commission's request that it be permitted to enter into forward commitment arrangements with individual Education Centres for 1984 and 1985, up to 70 per cent per annum of the 1983 level. The Commission is asked to report on the operation of the Professional Development Program with a view to ensuring that the full range of schools in the government and non-government sectors have access to the program and, if necessary, negotiate with the States to achieve this end. The Government will not be providing the proposed additional funds for the Country Areas Program in 1983 but it will be maintained in real terms at the 1982 level.

The Government will provide some additional funds in 1982, and again in 1983, to enable extended participation by schools in the Australian Capital Territory in the Special Education, Professional Development and Disadvantaged Schools Programs. The Government will not be extending further the range of these programs in 1983 as proposed by the Commission.

Additional Allowances for Cost Increases in 1982 The Government has reviewed the existing cost adjustment provision for the Commission's 1982 programs. It has decided that some additional funds should be made available beyond present prospective arrangements to cover unanticipated cost increases arising from recent teacher salary determinations. For government school general recurrent grants it has decided to provide an additional $10.4 million. This will meet approximately two-thirds of the estimated salary increases over and above those already provided for in the existing prospective allowance. Having regard to the fact that Commonwealth general recurrent grants constitute only 7 per cent of government school recurrent costs, the Government believes that this additional allocation to the States for 1982 should assist them to maintain resource standards in government schools.

For non-government schools the additional funds for general recurrent grants will be provided to preserve the Government's 1980 election commitment to pay general recurrent grants to non-government schools at the rates of 20, 30 and 38 per cent of average government school standard costs in 1982. This will significantly assist these schools to cope with the financial problems they are currently experiencing as a result of unexpectedly high salary increases this year. The cost of this additional provision for non-government schools will be $ 25.7 million. The Government will also provide additional funds to supplement fully increases in salary costs in all of the special purpose and joint programs of the Commission for both government and non-government schools. This will require an additional $8.8 million in 1982.
For 1983 the prospective allowance has been determined on the same basis as announced in last year's Guidelines.

DEBATE.TITLE: UPDATED BUILDING BUDGET FOR NEW PARLIAMENT HOUSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a very brief statement on behalf of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs ( Senator Messner).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I wish to announce that the updated building budget for the design and construction of the new Parliament House is $370.4m at March 1982 prices. It is the Government's intention to report periodically to Parliament on the updated budget for the new building, and honourable senators will recall that in September 1981, when this House approved the latest declared stage, the building budget was $303.9m at June 1981 prices.

SPEECH.PARA: In accordance with the Government's determination to contain costs on the project, the Parliament House Construction Authority has succeeded in containing the increase in budget figures between June 1981 and March 1982 to the inflationary effects of movements in the cost of labour and materials. I therefore wish to stress that the budget originally approved by Parliament, plus approved variations amounting to only 2.9 per cent, is being maintained in real terms.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Death of Mr Bernie Scanlon-Death of Mr Reg Frost-Export of Live Sheep

PROCTEXT.PARA: Death of Mr Bernie Scanlon-Death of Mr Reg Frost-Export of Live Sheep
That the Senate do now adjourn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable senators will be aware of the deaths during the recess of Bernie Scanlon and Reg Frost. Bernie died unexpectedly and peacefully at his home in Queanbeyan on 6 August. He joined the Senate staff on 17 August 1970 as an attendant and in October 1974 he was transferred to the Senate Transport Office where he served with distinction until his retirement in August 1980. I, as well as many honourable senators, had the good fortune to know Bernie for a number of years and to greatly appreciate his friendship as well as his willingness to assist in every possible way. Bernie was highly regarded and well liked by all who were associated with him or worked with him in Parliament House and he will be fondly remembered by all who knew him. I again express my deepest and sincere sympathy to his family.

INTERJECT.PARA: Reg Frost joined the Department of the Senate on 17 June 1975 as an attendant and honourable senators will remember Reg for the quietly efficient manner in which he carried out his duties in the Senate new wing. He is survived by his wife Joan who is well known to honourable senators and his children Alan, Dennis , Lyn and their families. On behalf of all honourable senators I again extend our deepest sympathy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with you, Mr President, and indeed with all members of the Senate in conveying our sympathy to the relatives and friends of both Bernie Scanlon and Reg Frost. One of the remarkable happenings inside this Parliament is one which I had cause to remark upon before, and that is that it is not only the parliamentarians and their immediate staff who form strong bonds and strong friendships but it is also those who in the wider sphere of attendants and servants of this organisation become closely linked both with us as senators and members and with our families. Those kinds of bonds go well beyond the ordinary service of work and the ordinary dedication. They are, in fact, quite remarkable , almost unique.

SPEECH.PARA: Bernie Scanlon was in an extraordinary position in this place. It seems that those who become transport officers in the Senate are people who have a total dedication to serve, a cheerfulness and a kind of spirit of friendship that creates not only a service in itself but also a warmth that endears them to the senators and their families. No one could more justify those remarks than Bernie Scanlon. I think we all called him 'friend'. We would have been proud if he returned that compliment, as I think he did. I think we all shared Bernie's grief when he lost his wife in the latter part of his service here. We also shared his joys in his family and in his confiding in us on his son's service to the church in the Marist Order. We learnt later, day by day, of his involvement in local organisations, particularly St Vincent de Paul, and in his bowling club . He was a man who was greatly loved by us. We are all the sadder and the lesser for his passing. I join with you, Mr President, to say to those who were very near and dear to him just how much we miss him and how proud we were to have known him.

All of us here knew Reg Frost as a very cheerful attendant along the corridors, who carried newspapers to us, who undertook various duties and attended to us. He was very well liked and a very well known identity in this building and elsewhere. Of course, we are also privileged to know his wife Joan who works in the Parliamentary Refreshment Rooms. We share your sadness, Mr President, and join with you in expressing our great sympathy to Joan and to his children-Alan, Dennis, Lyn-and their families.

I can only add again that this parliamentary system works as it does and the two cambers work as they do not so much because of people like you, Mr President , and I but because of the people behind the scenes who do their work so well and so cheerfully as our friends. I sadly acknowledge the loss of these two fine people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Labor Party I concur with the remarks made by you, Mr President, and by Senator Sir John Carrick. I cannot, on a personal basis, say a great deal about Reg Frost. I remember his cheery demeanour and that will be missed. We express our condolences to his family.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say one or two personal things about Bernie Scanlon. It is not an expression I normally use, but I certainly regarded Bernie Scanlon as a mate of mine and I think he was a mate of everybody in the Senate. I will always remember Bernie for his Irish sense of humour-I guess he was pretty Irish in his background-and tolerance. It seemed to me that he was a man totally without malice. I have seen him get very angry with people on occasions and a few minutes later laugh and joke about the whole incident which caused the anger. He was a rare breed of man in the sense that I always had the feeling that he had been around a bit and really knew in a variety of ways what life was all about. That gives a person a great maturity and tolerance of the foibles of other human beings. That was very present in his attitude to and tolerance of everybody else . At a personal level I will miss him very much. Not that I saw so much of him recently, but on the occasions I did see him he always invited my kids to stay with the family. It was an invitation they never accepted, for other reasons. But the invitation was always there and it was a very sincere one. It was a measure of the sort of chap he was that even after he left the Senate he was still making that sort of offer in a quite genuine way. I join with you, Mr President, and the Leader of the Government (Senator Sir John Carrick) in expressing my personal sadness at the passing of a very fine man. I say the same in respect of Reg Frost and express my regrets to their respective families and friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: -Briefly, I should like to join in expressing condolences to the relatives and friends of Bernie Scanlon and Reg Frost. I can only endorse all the sentiments that have been expressed by the previous speakers. Bernie Scanlon was a man whose efficiency in his work was matched by his pleasant character and his capacity, as Senator Button suggested, to tolerate almost anything and still remain a bright member of our community. He was one of the many who make life inside these walls in some measure tolerable. To his relatives and friends I extend sincere sympathy.

SPEECH.PARA: Reg Frost, likewise, was a happy character. As he moved rapidly along the corridors bringing good tidings or bad he always had a smile on his face. He was a pleasant member of our society and we owe him a great debt. I join in the expressions of condolence and add my sympathy to those whom these two gentlemen leave behind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats join in paying a tribute to Reg Frost and Bernie Scanlon. The friendliness, cheeriness and graciousness of both these men will be missed. I considered it very fortunate that I happened to be in Canberra on the day Bernie 's funeral was conducted at Queanbeyan. I attended the funeral with my wife and was very pleased to be able to do so. I extended, I hope without impertinence, to all his friends and relatives the condolences of yourself, Mr President, and every member of the Senate of whatever party. They seemed to be particularly pleased to receive those condolences. As would be expected, the funeral was attended by an extraordinarily large number of people. There was great sadness at the funeral, particularly among the Catholic sisters who were there because apparently Bernie made it almost his life's devotion after he retired from here to do odd jobs and assist the sisters in their work among the poor and their charitable work, as one would expect from such a man.

SPEECH.PARA: I have always admired people who work in the service of the Senate and indeed the House of Representatives. Having been a member of the House of Representatives for 16 years or so, I thought that Gordon Pike and his cronies were impossible to beat. But when I moved to the Senate I found the same excellence of service among Bernie Scanlon and his mates. I sometimes wonder why these people stay in these jobs. I am sure that people with the competence, efficiency and dedication of Bernie Scanlon could double their salaries in private enterprise. But they stay here and they serve, and we are eternally grateful. Bernie Scanlon leaves behind him a great number of relatives and loved ones who grieve. On behalf of the Democrats, and my wife and I personally, I extend sympathies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with all of those who have spoken in expressing sadness at the death of Bernie Scanlon and Reg Frost. Four years ago today I came to Canberra as a new senator. Bernie Scanlon was one of the first to welcome me. He did so with a cheerful smile and in a helpful way. In my first 18 months in the Senate my wife and children frequently came here for two weeks of each three week session. So as a family we had a great deal to do with Bernie Scanlon. I could not believe the excellence of personal attention that he and his assistants gave to our family, as they did to all senators. I think his cheerfulness, sense of service, generous giving of time and special initiatives to help the members of this chamber were unexcellable. He lived up to the very highest tradition of Senate staff. Senator Sir John Carrick said that Bernie Scanlon is greatly loved by us. Senator Button said he is a mate of ours. I think that those words aptly describe my own remembrances of Bernie Scanlon. I express my own sincere sympathy to his family and special friends.

SPEECH.PARA: I also remember very dearly Reg Frost, who seemed to sit every day and every evening on the corner of my corridor. I think he did so for the four years that I have been here. He was a permanent cheerful institution on the corner of the corridor outside my room in the Parliament. He always smiled and showed good humour. Towards the end of a three-week session when things were rather strained it was a point of cheer to senators in that corridor to know that Reg was able to act in the way in which Senate stewards assist us. It was only a matter of a month ago that I said my usual hellos to him on arriving at Parliament House. So it was a real shock when I heard of his recent death. I extend my sincere sympathy to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was saddened to hear of the passing of Reg Frost. I too was an occupant of the far corridor for some time. I got to know Reg very well because he was always in the corner as one went up to one's room. Reg used to get a great deal of mirth after I moved from that corridor. Perhaps because of my rigid behaviour pattern, I used to forget that I was in a new office and I used to head off to my old corridor. Every time I did so Reg would be there with his cheerful face saying: 'You have done it again'. But he did this in such a way that it was pleasurable. That part of Parliament House will not be the same with Reg's passing. I certainly pass on to his family my condolences.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only I but also my family were saddened when we heard of the passing of Bernie Scanlon. Bernie has been described in numerous ways here tonight. But my family felt we had lost a close friend, someone for whom we felt deeply. I think we were shocked and saddened because he passed on so soon after he retired. He did not have a chance to enjoy the retirement that he really deserved. Bernie, of course, was one of the army of workers who keep this Parliament House going. They are unsung workers. They do not receive any publicity, but without their help this place would grind to a halt.

I think that perhaps the transport officers are among the most hardworking of the army of workers we have behind us. They have to work extremely long hours when we are in session and they have to put up with a great deal. They have to keep track of where 64 senators are, where they are going and where they have been. They seem to do this with an ease which belies the difficulty which must go with their work. I remember a transport officer once saying that the best way to get a politician-I do not particularly like that word-to change his mind is to give him an airline ticket. I think this indicates some of the difficulties that Bernie and his fellow transport officers would have. Not only did he look after us but also he looked after our spouses and, as Senator Teague has mentioned, sometimes he looked after our family members as well.

I would like to mention at this stage that with Bernie's passing we should perhaps ponder whether we expect our transport officers to do too much-whether we are asking them to work too many hours. Most of us remember Wally Lee. Wally did not live for very long after he retired to enjoy what was really a well- earned retirement. Now this has happened to Bernie. Perhaps we should ponder the position at some stage and think about those people who are working for us, the hours that they are working and what it might be doing to their health.

Many of us here are indebted to Bernie for a number of things that he has done. Senator Button mentioned the generosity that Bernie offered with regard to people staying at his home and I would mention that it was a generosity that was extended quite a great deal. We have a great debt to Bernie. It is a debt that we will not forget with the passing of time. To Bernie's family, I extend my condolences and those of my family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: -It was with considerable shock in this last week or so when I was in the north of Australia that I learned of the death of Bernie Scanlon and then, having arrived back here in Canberra, learnt that Reg Frost had also passed way. Today in the Senate the leaders have spoken at length to motions of condolence about very famous people who have served as parliamentarians in the Federal sphere. The condolences measured their activities over the very many years of service to Australia. Tonight I think in no less a way we are remembering and thinking of these two men. Their efforts are not sung as was the case with these other famous parliamentarians. But in no less a way they have served the Parliament, particularly the Senate. Indeed, like other honourable senators one can only be impressed with these people who worked so quietly to assist us without really expecting any words of thanks or recognition. As I have said, their efforts are really unsung to quite a degree.

SPEECH.PARA: Only this evening I was looking at a document relating to the retirement of Bernie Scanlon on 6 August 1980. On that day we wished him all the best for a very happy retirement because we all felt that in the work he had done so cheerfully and over very long hours surely there could be some compensation for his years of effort so that he could relax and spend some time with his friends and his family. Indeed, I had an arrangement with Bernie to see him in the Northern Territory. We were going to do certain things, but that did not eventuate. After so many years of effort Bernie has gone. While we remember those very famous people, I am sure that all of us will remember Bernie too. At times I look at the staff of the Parliament, the very dedicated people who work in this area to keep the parliament working and to support parliamentarians, and I think about the long hours that they work. When I used to come into this building each morning at about 8 o'clock, Bernie would have been here for quite a long time before my arrival. When we left the building at 11 o'clock, 12 o' clock or 1 o'clock, Bernie would still be here. When we left to go to our home States, Bernie would still be here. When we returned, he would be here again. People like Bernie work incredible hours. Really, as other senators have said, are we asking too much of our staff? Indeed, these dedicated people really give their lives to what I would say is the well-being of the nation through the work they do here.

Reg Frost was a most pleasant fellow. Whenever you seemed to need somebody to assist you, you were under pressure, things were happening in a hurry and you needed an extra pair of hands, Reg was there-quiet, unassuming, very friendly and of tremendous assistance. In fact, you got the feeling that whenever you turned around Reg would be there. It was most remarkable that tonight all of us feel that those two men, Bernie and Reg, were our personal close friends. It is quite astounding that all of us have that feeling. I think it is indicative of the strength of character of these two men. We will miss them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to join the other speakers this evening in paying a tribute to the late Bernie Scanlon. On behalf of the ex- Parliamentary Labor Party members and the present ones, I want to express our very great sadness at his sudden death. Bernie was a great personal friend to a great many of us. He commenced work here, as you, Mr President, have said as a parliamentary attendant in about 1970. He retired on 6 August 1980 and passed away just two years to the day after his retirement. As I have said, Bernie commenced his duties here as an attendant, then became Assistant Senate Transport Officer to the late Wally Lee. On Wally's retirement he became Senate Transport Officer and it was in that position that he endeared himself to us all . Like his predecessor Wally Lee, he was always courteous and helpful despite the strains that are so often placed upon our transport officers by the unpredictable happenings in this place. Bernie was always willing to assist people in need. He had a very soft heart and a real understanding of the problems of those in need. My understanding is that he was engaged in this type of work right up until the eve of his death.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first came here in 1971 Bernie expressed concern to me about the conditions of work for parliamentary attendants and the fact that they were then being issued with hand-me-down uniforms. That was of great concern to Bernie and there were other conditions of work with which he was concerned too. I was only a senator elect at that time but I took the opportunity of speaking to a person whom I came to know very quickly in this Parliament, Vince Martin, then the honourable member for Banks in the other place. I drew to his attention the problems Bernie had acquainted me with. Vince Martin took the opportunity that very day in the grievance debate in the other place to raise these matters on behalf of the attendants and these problems, I am happy to say, were quickly solved. It was mainly due to the vigilance, understanding and concern of the late Bernie Scanlon that the attendants in this place, from that day onwards, got a much better deal in their conditions of work. They no longer had to wear second hand uniforms or buy their own shirts. They were very grateful to Bernie for that. There was a time when they thought that the politicians were responsible, but it was not politicians at all. It was the very great work of Bernie Scanlon in his understanding of the problems.

To his son, Michael, I would like to extend our deepest sympathy on behalf of us all. I had the pleasure of knowing Michael and I join the other honourable senators who have expressed the statement here this evening that he was a very fine young boy. Michael, of course, has had to go through the trauma of losing first his mother, then his grandmother and so soon afterwards his father. So there is a young man who has got off to a pretty rough start in life. We hope that he has got the outlook in life that his late father had, that he can overcome these problems and that he can go on and enjoy life as a young man of his years should be able to.

I got to know Reg Frost very well because he used to do many jobs for me at my request. He was in the Senate attendants office just around the corner from my office, and I got to know Reg very well. I received a great shock when I came back here during the recess to learn that just a few days earlier Reg had passed away. I pass on to his family our very deepest sympathy. I pay tribute to the work that both of those gentlemen did in their service to this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with you, Mr President, and other senators in expressing sympathy to the families of both Reg Frost and Bernie Scanlon and to pay tribute to them. As an occupant of the far corridor, as Senator Colston mentioned, I too came to know Reg Frost very well. He was one of the first people I greeted every morning when I came here. He was always helpful , always smiling, always ready to please, always prepared to have a chat about any problems, or the weather, or anything else that you wanted to talk about. He seemed to me to be a very good friend, and we will certainly miss him in that corridor.

SPEECH.PARA: I also join with other senators who have said that it is quite fascinating how both of these people became personal friends to honourable senators. I feel the same way about Bernie Scanlon. I believe, like Senator Button, that he was a mate of mine. He was also a close friend of my wife. Like others, he was a friend to our family. He was a kind and gentle man and a very loving husband and father. He used to talk a lot about his son, and he talked to my wife about his wife. It was clear that he was grieving over the loss of his wife. I have spoken to my wife about it and she believes that he never got over the death of his wife. It was certainly a shock to me, as it was to others to come back into this place and to discover that we had lost both of these fine friends.

TALK.START.PARA: -I simply want to endorse briefly all that has been said. As a one-time resident of the corridor mentioned by Senator Lewis , I am well aware of the friendly disposition of Reg Frost. In relation to Bernie Scanlon, I think honourable senators will be well aware of the reputation the Scanlon family has in the Northern Miners Federation of New South Wales. His brother Henry was a very prominent trade union leader. He was a very courageous man who could also be gracious in defeat. Henry had the same sense of humour and merry twinkle in his eyes that Bernie had. I think all honourable senators know that the name of Scanlon rates very highly on the northern coalfields. When Bernie came here he lived up to the reputation that the Scanlon family had in the Northern Miners Federation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with other senators from that famous corridor who have been so keen to speak about Reg Frost. He looked after honourable senators whose rooms are in that corridor very well. I must admit that I was always rather late with my box of paper to be tied up. Reg always accepted that late request very happily and tied up my terrible box of paper for me to take back to Hobart. He always did it very graciously. He was very keen on his garden. I saw photographs of his magnificent tomato plants. He was a very keen gardener. He loved growing fruit and brought it in to display it on many occasions. He told me how I should be looking after my own garden at home, but I was never quite as clever as he was with his plants.

SPEECH.PARA: Bernie Scanlon was a wonderful friend to all of us, as honourable senators have said tonight. He took particular care of the ladies, and always made sure that we got home safely in the wee small hours of the morning. If we had a rather dark area to go into, he always made sure that the driver went with us. He made sure that we were looked after well. Bernie was indeed a very dear friend to all of us. I agree with the remarks made by Senator Lewis. I believe that Bernie grieved for his wife and did not ever recover from her passing. Obviously they were a very close couple and he took her death very hard. I join with other senators in giving my condolences to both families. I hope that their sadness will be easier to bear after reading the condolences that have been expressed here tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —What needed to be said about Bernie Scanlon and Reg Frost has been said. I rise merely to add a few words about Bernie Scanlon who during the period I have been here-I am sorry to have to use the past tense-was a close friend of mine. I should like to give an example of his tremendous generosity, a generosity that was extended where it was not expected, in my case to my two children who came to Canberra at a time when I was not here and were unable to find accommodation. Their need was met by Bernie Scanlon, who in some way improvised accommodation for them until they found accommodation. He then took a personal interest in those people for the rest of the time they were in Canberra. They are deeply indebted to him and grieve at his loss. Special encouragement should be given to his son Michael because, as Senator McLaren has said, he has had to face the loss of three people. In a short period a household of four suddenly became a household of one. The lad is very much in need of courage and encouragement, and I am certain that what has been said tonight will be of great support to him.

SPEECH.PARA: Reg Frost, of course, was one of a number of people in this place who served us well. Although I did not have as close contact with Reg Frost as many other senators had, nevertheless, I understand the service he gave. I offer my condolences and those of my family to the families of both those gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to seek the indulgence of the Senate for a short time to talk about the export of live sheep . I consider this matter to be of significant importance not only to the rural producers of Australia but also, at a more fundamental level, to the direction in which Australia is heading as an exporting nation. The arguments and the debates in respect of live sheep exports have been going on since the mid-1970s. At one level it relates to the relative balance between live animal sales and carcass sales. At another level it becomes a question of Australia's role and its ability to dictate tastes, quantities and purchasing preferences for the world markets. At that level it is a question of whether the trade union movement can determine and decide unilaterally what Australian products the market wants, in what quantities, and how they shall be delivered. The Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, with the backing of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has adopted a dangerous and, in my view, a long term possibly destructive position which, in the final analysis, may well fall very heavily upon the rural producers of this country. Its view is simply that, in terms of live sheep exports, there ought to be correspondingly an equal export of processed carcasses. In my view, that stand has been based upon a false premise, a false assumption, and has been perpetuated by the following submission that the union made to the Australian Council of Trade Unions:

SPEECH.PARA: That countries predominately importing live sheep will accept a balance of carcase mutton to complement live sheep.

In the light of statements made by Middle East officials that belief is, to say the least, certainly questionable, but more importantly the underlying reasons for the union's policy on live sheep exports are also, to say the least, highly suspect. The AMIEU has stated that in the last decade some 10,000 jobs have been lost as a result of the export of live sheep. In fact, that is hardly the case at all. While, superficially, it is an attractive argument, which diverts attention from rising labour and associated costs in the meat industry which have made Australia's competitive position weaker relative to such other major suppliers as Argentina, East Africa and Europe, in my view it is no more than an exercise in locating for the benefit of the AMIEU a convenient scapegoat.

An examination of the markets in the Middle East which, by and large, takes all of our live sheep, makes this point very clear. Taking 1975 as the point at which live sheep exports took off-the first year more than one million animals were shipped to the Middle East-there has been a 291 per cent increase in live sheep sales to 1981. That, in itself, represents major growth in the industry for primary producers who, in recent years, have had to face enormous difficulties posed by droughts, rising costs and other factors of which everybody in the Senate would be aware. This has been true not only of Western Australia but also of New South Wales and Queensland. Their situation has also been influenced by fluctuating commodity prices. In that period of difficulty a major new export industry has developed-one which, for the most spurious of reasons, the trade unions would seek to destroy.

As I have said, the unions argue that live sheep sales in the Middle East have been achieved at the expense of processed meat sales but, in fact, those two distinct markets have developed very effectively, competently and capably in tandem. If we consider first Iran, we find that carcass sales to that country have increased in volume by 148 per cent in the period 1975 to 1981, but that over the same period live sales have increased by only 48 per cent. I begin with Iran for two reasons. The first is that it is not an Arab country. The second is that it was the country cited in a recent television report which claimed that New Zealand had banned live sales to Iran but had experienced a significant expansion in carcass sales to that country. Of course, the point is very clear. Australia did not ban live sheep sales. Nevertheless its carcass sales to Iran have expanded out of proportion to its sales to the live sheep market. In fact, carcass markets throughout the Middle East, with the exception of Bahrain, have expanded strongly throughout the period 1975 to 1981. The increases ranged from 59 per cent in Kuwait, the smallest increase, to 570 per cent in Oman. Overall, the volume of carcass sheep meat sales to Iran, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Dubai and Bahrain combined has increased from 20,262 tonnes in 1975 to 60,481 tonnes last year-a three-fold increase. Live sheep sales over the same period have increased very significantly from 1.33 million tonnes in 1975 to 4.7 million tonnes in 1981. That increase is about three and a half fold or, in other words, not so much out of proportion with carcass sales as the AMIEU would have us believe.

The simple fact is that the sheep sales, either live or in carcass form, have developed extremely well and side by side in the Middle East and not, as the Opposition would claim, one at the exclusion of the other. On a country by country basis it is true that increases in live sheep sales have exceeded those of sheep meat in Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain and Qatar but the reverse has been true in Iran, Oman and Dubai. Only in Bahrain have sheep meat carcass sales fallen between 1975 and 1981 but by comparison Oman has never become a significant live sheep consumer. It is a matter of market preference and, try though they may, the AMIEU, the Opposition, or Australia as a whole cannot tell a market what, why and how it should buy. That point has been made time and again by those purchasers in the Middle East.

A group of Australians drawn from the Government, industry bodies and the trade union movement generally has recently studied the question of sheep meat sales to the Middle East countries. The union delegates, whilst agreeing in basic principle, perhaps differed in emphasis from the other members of the group in terms of interpreting the findings. But even they had to admit:
All countries visited continue to tolerate the belief that the only way to ensure that sheep meat from Australia is Halal, is to slaughter it locally.
The union conceded also:
The local populations in all countries visited have a strong preference for fresh meat, particularly sheep meat.

That is really the point in this debate. Halal, the traditional Moslem way of killing sheep, must be observed. The Government has said that it will promote the fact that Australia's abattoirs will follow the Moslem killing procedures in an effort to ensure that we are able to provide overseas buyers with carcasses in the manner, form and style which they want and satisfy the unions as best we are capable. But as long as the demand for live animals in the Middle East countries persists and it is people's desire to do their own slaughtering in their own countries all that the Government of this country can do is ensure that we can promote carcass sales in the best way. It would be quite irresponsible in the extreme for us to jeopardize our live sheep sales. Australia cannot force upon those countries a style other than that which they would want for themselves. We should be very clear at this point: If Australia were to force the issue the result would be a disaster for rural producers of this country. I quote from a television report which I mentioned earlier. The Kuwaiti Minister in charge of meat imports was asked what Kuwait would do for live sheep if Australia banned exports. The report stated:
'Of course,' he replied. 'It is natural that we would look for other alternatives.'
Quoting the Saudi Arabian Minister of Commerce the Arab information bureau in Australia added:
If you (that is, Australia) don't sell us live sheep, we will look just across the Red Sea to Somalia, Sudan and Kenya. We will buy from there.
The bureau made the point as strongly as it could be made at that time when it said:
If we do not get live sheep (from Australia), we will buy it somewhere else. You cannot force people to buy things they don't want.

The potentially destructive attitude of the trade union movement means that it has the prospect of ensuring that our live sheep export market will be denied to us. At best this is naive loyalty to Australia's abattoir workers but at worst, and closer to the truth, it is a deliberate ploy to focus the meat industry's problems on external factors rather than to look to the behaviour of the unions themselves to explain Australia's trading decline. The live sheep trade in fact is a part of that ploy. The unions look to the external factors but ignore the effects of rising wages and shorter hours, which are crippling Australia's industry. They have maintained this position in the face of all of the evidence that all forms of sheep meat sales to the Middle East have grown markedly and in the face of an often repeated preference for live sheep.

If this position is ever translated into the sorts of conditions advocated by the ACTU is will mean disaster for the primary producers for whom this is a developing industry. It could well lead to reduced carcass sales, as well, in the Middle East, thereby affecting the very people in the work force for whom the union is professing concern. I leave honourable senators with the view that I would be horrified, distressed and concerned if I thought that the Government were at any point in time prepared to walk away, back away or compromise when pressure was applied by the trade union movement or by other people to ensure that we are not able any longer to export live sheep from this country to the Middle East. I trust that the Government will continue to pursue its aggressive policy to ensure that we are able to export that type of sheep, particularly wethers, to those countries to the benefit of our rural producers.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.2 p.m.

(3) Will the Attorney-General consider whether any action should be taken either to prevent any such invasion of privacy, or to ensure that guests are warned in advance that such a record is being kept.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it an International Civil Aviation Organisation principle that aircraft operators and other airport users should not be charged for facilities and services they do not use.
(2) Is the agricultural aviation sector charged for: (a) meteorological briefing; (b) flight service facilities; (c) en route flying aids; or (d) search and rescue facilities; if so; why.
(3) Did the General Aviation Study Report state that 89 per cent of the cost attributable to the agricultural aviation sector was being recovered.

(4) With the rise of 20 per cent in air navigation charges in the August 1981 Budget, is there now total cost recovery from the agricultural sector; if so, how is the level of attribution of costs to the agricultural sector justified.
(5) What are the details of the current air navigation charges which have been established.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Aircraft operations within Australia are liable, unless exempted by the Minister for Aviation or his delegate or by the Air Navigation (Charges) Act 1952' to pay air navigation charges as provided for under the Act. The charges take account of the cost of providing, operating and maintaining aerodromes, air route and airway facilities, meteorological services and search and rescue services. The charge is a composite one and cannot be itemised for the use of specific items or facilities.

Current aerial agriculture operators are entitled to receive a 15 per cent remission on air navigation charges for aircraft solely constructed and used for aerial agricultural operations or aircraft fitted for and exclusively used for aerial agricultural operations. This remission is additional to the 50 per cent remission which applies in respect of aircraft operating from non government owned or financed aerodromes.
(3) Yes.

(4) The General Aviation Study's estimate of the level of cost recovery from the agricultural aviation sub-sector was based on a method of apportioning costs developed specifically for use in the context of the Study.

The General Aviation Study's estimate of the level of cost recovery from the agricultural aviation sub-sector related to the year 1977/78. In order to establish whether the level of cost recovery for the agricultural aviation sub- sector has changed since 1977/78, it would be necessary to examine annual changes in both the level of attributable costs and revenues for this sub-sector in each subsequent year.

The current arrangements for levying charges on the general aviation sector, which were endorsed by the Government following the General Aviation Study, do not distinguish between sub-sectors. As a consequence, Departmental accounting records do not provide for aviation costs and revenue data to be identified by sub-sector. The General Aviation Study's calculations have therefore not been updated.

The 20 per cent increase in air navigation charges announced in the 1981/82 Budget was the first such increase for two years and was in line with movements in the consumer price index during that time. In addition, since the increase did not become effective until 1 October 1981, it only applies to part of the revenue collected in the 1981/82 financial year.
It does not follow that the increase in air navigation charges announced in 1981 has necessarily resulted in full cost recovery from the agricultural aviation sub-sector.
(5) The current details of air navigation charges payable by owners on their aircraft's operations are contained in the schedules to the Air Navigation ( Charges) Act 1952 as amended.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Health been drawn to the extent of the problem of tropical fish poisoning.

(2) Was research on ciguatera at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories (CSL) in Melbourne recently stopped because of a new policy to concentrate on work which makes money; if so, how many other non-profit CSL research projects have been abandoned.
(3) What is the Government doing about the ciguatera problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. My Department is fully acquainted with the subject and closely watches events.

(2) No. Ciguatera toxin as a possible research and development project has been under consideration at the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories for some time. The fact that an acceptable research project proposal has yet to be put forward is indicative of the uncertainty surrounding the ways in which the topic could be investigated.

(3) My Department has prepared a document on poisoning by marine animals, including ciguatera. The National Health and Medical Research Council is currently revising this document into a form suitable for release as a public information document. A copy will then be placed in the Parliamentary Library. I would also advise that a Commonwealth statutory body, the Fishing Industry Research Committee, has recommended and the Minister for Primary Industry has approved, provision of financial assistance from the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account for the investigation of ciguatera. This financial year a grant was awarded to Doctors Robert Endean and Richard Lewis of the University of Queensland for a research study titled 'A Study of ciguatera poisoning in Queensland'. Additionally grants have been approved for financial year 1982-83 to the University of Queensland for a study titled 'A survey of the incidence of ciguatera toxin in ''high risk'' fish from Cairns region' and to the Queensland Department of Primary Industries for a study on toxic dinoflagellates responsible for the formation of ciguatoxin.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is pressure being exerted by the Northern Territory Government to return to the Northern Territory control over that region north of the Kakadu National Park, known as Kakadu Stage 2.

(2) Would such action create a dangerous and crucial precedent for Aboriginal land rights claims, and, would it not also pave the way for further uranium mining in the region as the Territory's Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, has repeatedly called for the opening of new mines.

(3) Will the Federal Government maintain its support for the inclusion of the Kakadu National Park on the United Nations World Heritage list and not hand over control to the Northern Territory for its future despoilation for short term improbable economic gains and loss of Aboriginal land claims.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At the suggestion of the Northern Territory Government discussions are being held regarding the alternative means by which the Commonwealth Government' s policies for Stage 2 of Kakadu can be given effect to.
In announcing the Government's decisions about the establishment of Kakadu National Park on 25 August 1977 it was made clear the Stage 2 area would later be declared part of the Park.

The fee simple interest in the Stage 2 area land was acquired by the Commonwealth on 29 June 1978 and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 amended to enable Commonwealth control of the area as a Conservation Zone prior to incorporation in the Park.
(2) As far as land claims are concerned the entire Stage 2 area was the subject of a land claim under the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

The Aboriginal Land Commissioner made his recommendation in relation to the claim to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on 2 July 1981. On 8 March 1982 the Minister announced his acceptance of the recommendation.
I understand that there is no action being taken by the Northern Territory Government which would affect the claim.

In so far as uranium mining is concerned the Government announced in August 1977 that in line with the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry (RUEI) recommendations the Jabiluka project would be excluded from the Park to accommodate mining activities. It was also announced at that time that exploration would be permitted in the Stage 2 area under strictly controlled conditions.

There are no further uranium mining projects for Stage 2 currently in prospect although it is intended that the area should be subject to exploration following its establishment as a Conservation Zone under the NPWC Act. Any exploration or development of land which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs announced on 8 March 1982 will become Aboriginal land, would be subject also to the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.

(3) The Commonwealth Government nominated Kakadu National Park for inclusion on the World Heritage List on 25 August 1980. At the meeting of the World Heritage Committee held in Sydney on 26 October 1981 it was agreed that Kakadu National Park should be added to the list of properties on the World Heritage List.
The Commonwealth Government remains by its decision and welcomes the international recognition of Kakadu's status as an area with outstanding natural and cultural values.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Persia carry live sheep out of Fremantle on 2 September 1981 and did 1269 sheep perish due to ventilation failure within six days of sailing and another 7495 sheep die from other plant breakdown.
(2) Is the Persia approximately 30 years old and unseaworthy; if so, why did the Australian Government not refuse to allow the ship to leave Fremantle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, except that the only plant breakdown was in the mechanical ventilation equipment.

(2) Persia was built in 1953 and originally operated as the passenger/general cargo carrier Asia. It was converted as a livestock carrier, thoroughly overhauled in 1976-77 and entered the Australian livestock export trade in 1977. The definition of seaworthiness is contained in section 207 of the Navigation Act, sub-section (2) of which provides as follows:
Where- (a) it is proposed to take a Safety Convention ship to sea on a voyage from a port in Australia; and
(b) there is in force in respect of the ship the certificate or certificates that may be required to be produced under sub-section 206W (2) in respect of the voyage,

the ship shall, for the purposes of this Act, be deemed to be seaworthy in relation to that voyage with respect to the condition of the ship and its equipment unless the condition of the ship or of its equipment does not correspond substantially with the particulars of that certificate or of any of those certificates.

Persia is a Safety Convention ship for the purposes of that provision and carried the required certificates issued by the flag state. At the time of the voyage in question there was no reason for departmental surveyors to suppose that the condition of the ship or of its equipment did not correspond substantially with the particulars of its certificates.

In addition to the seaworthiness requirements the arrangements for the carriage of livestock, including ventilation, are inspected by departmental surveyors for compliance with Requirements for the Carriage of Livestock by Sea (June 1978). These inspections have taken place on the 6 or 7 occasions each year since 1978 when the ship has loaded livestock in Australia and there has been no previous problem with the ventilation machinery.

The above requirements also require the issue of a certificate of fitness by an authorised veterinary officer certifying that the livestock are capable of withstanding the conditions which they are likely to experience on the proposed voyage. The breakdown of the ventilation equipment gave rise to conditions which could not reasonably have been expected.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are steel-belted radial tyres more likely to shed their treads at relatively low speeds than other tyres reported by the Queensland Road Safety Council, if so, will the Government consider taking some form of action against advertisers who imply that these tyres are safer than other tyres.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1979 and 1980 enquiries concerning the safety of steel radial tyres were conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, the New South Wales Traffic Accident Research Unit, and my Department.

I am advised that the main cause of tread separation in tyres is rubber compound fatigue cracking. Fatigue occurs in all tyres, but a correctly manufactured and operated steel-belted radial tyre is not more likely to suffer a premature failure than other types of tyre.
In keeping with the other enquiries, my Department concluded, inter alia, that
steel-belted tyres appear to require more care in their operation and maintenance than do other types of tyres
motorists generally tend to neglect tyre maintenance to the detriment of their tyres
some early versions of steel-belted radial tyres marketed in Australia experienced higher than normal failure rates, but not all manufacturers experienced such problems
remedial action by the manufacturers affected apparently reduced adjustment and separation rates to normal levels.
If complaints were received that advertisers of tyres were incorrectly representing their products it would be a matter for the Attorney-General to consider under the Trade Practices Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will a system of benefit cards be considered for pensioners to enable them to purchase essential items free of sales tax in the same manner that government departments and businessmen are able to.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not clear what is meant by the reference to essential items to be purchased free of sales tax. Government measures to introduce a sales tax on, amongst other things, clothing and footwear which have been defeated in the Senate did not include proposals to tax foodstuffs, drugs or medicines. If essential items are clothing, foodstuffs, drugs and medicines there is simply no sales tax payable.

Commonwealth government departments are specifically exempt from sales tax on goods purchased for their use. Clearly it is unnecessary for them to pay sales tax on goods purchased out of consolidated revenue. Furthermore the Constitution guarantees freedom from sales tax to State government departments.

It is not correct to say that businessmen can obtain essential items free of sales tax. What the sales tax law does is to provide exemption for manufacturers to obtain their raw materials, aids to manufacture and similar goods free of sales tax so as to prevent double taxation or indirect taxing of exempt goods.
Under the indexation provisions of the Social Security Act, pensioners are automatically compensated for all price increases that are reflected in the consumer price index.
It is therefore not considered appropriate to introduce the system proposed by the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many people in the post code areas in the Federal Divisions of Barker and Wakefield have been recipients of the 'Isolated Patients' Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme' in each year since the inception of the scheme.
(2) How widely is the scheme publicised to acquaint people with benefits available to them.
(3) Are notices displayed in doctors' reception rooms, hospitals and pharmacies ; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (since (to Federal Division

* A significant proportion of persons in the Division of Wakefield are precluded from the Isolated Patients' Travel and Accommodation Assistance Scheme (IPTAAS) as they reside less than 200 kms from the metropolitan area.

(2) The IPTAAS program has been widely publicised throughout Australia. The Department wrote individually to all doctors in rural areas at the time the program was introduced in October 1978, and explanatory pamphlets and posters were widely distributed. Advertisements announcing the introduction of the program appeared in all rural and provincial newspapers in 1978, as well as the AMA Gazette and the Medical Journal. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have representations been made to the Minister for Social Security to establish an office of the Department of Social Security in Innisfail.
(2) Have representations been made to have a resident social worker attached to that office; if so what decision has the Government made in relation to these requests.
(3) Has a decision been taken not to establish an office or appoint a social worker; if so what are the reasons for that decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes.
(3) There are currently no plans to open an office of the Department of Social Security at Innisfail.

Taking into account current workloads in the Innisfail area and existing services provided from the Cairns office of my Department, the opening of an office at Innisfail cannot be justified. There are other areas with greater needs and comparatively fewer services.

The needs of the people of Innisfail are currently met by a fortnightly visiting service from the Cairns office of my Department. This visiting service is located in the Commonwealth Employment Service office. During these visits departmental staff receive applications for pensions and benefits, conduct interviews in relation to applications and answer general enquiries.

In addition, departmental field officers, welfare staff, an Aboriginal liaison officer and often a social worker, visit Innisfail and surrounding districts on a monthly basis. These staff also accept applications for pensions and benefits.
In relation to the stationing of a social worker in Innisfail, this could not be done without the establishment of a regional office.
I can asssure the honourable senator that my Department will continue to closely monitor existing services to determine both their adequacy and the need for additional services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 24 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any method of monitoring the use of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB ) in Australia.
(2) Is there any method of safeguarding the storage of used PCBs.

(3) Is the Minister considering banning the importation and use of PCBs in Australia in the light of recent discoveries of high levels of contamination in countries where the use of PCBs has been practised in the past.
(4) Have any tests been undertaken in Australia to detect and measure the presence of PCB contamination in (a) watercourses; (b) birds and animals; (c) humans; (d) food; and (e) packaging.
(5) Are humans sensitive to small intakes of PCB and what are the effects of PCB contamination on the human body.
(6) What methods of disposal of PCBs are available in Australia and what is the approximate cost of each method.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A control under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations has been in force since 1973 under which the importation of PCBs is prohibited except with the approval of the Minister responsible for administration of the Customs Act. Approval would usually be given only where PCBs are to be used in enclosed electrical transformers and large power factor correction capacitors, heat transfer fluids, and hydraulic fluids in mining equipment. Importation of PCBs for dissipative uses where recovery of waste material could not be guaranteed has not been allowed. Since the introduction of the customs regulation, statistics show that the importation of PCBs for electrical uses has fallen from a peak of 300 tonnes in 1975 to zero in each of the last two years. A survey commissioned by the Australian Environment Council in 1975 found that heat transfer fluids and hydraulic fluids containing PCBs were no longer being marketed in Australia. Where it is known that PCBs are in use in electrical transformers and capacitors, this use can be monitored.

(2) PCBs can be stored safely for an indefinite period provided certain standards are observed. Almost all used PCBs in Australia are stored in areas of State jurisdiction and State authorities have the responsibility for setting appropriate standards and monitoring their observance.

(3) Environmental contamination by PCBs in Australia and overseas seems largely to have been the consequence of dissipative uses of these chemicals and of improper disposal practices for waste PCBs. The Customs control referred to in ( 1) above, effectively precludes dissipative uses of PCBs in Australia. State and Commonwealth authorities are well aware of the need for strict control of storage and disposal of waste PCBs.

(4) I understand that recent research by Professor Waid at La Trobe University in Melbourne has identified the existence of PCBs at low levels (less than 0.9 parts per million) in samples of sediment and biota from Port Phillip Bay. There are no data available on the effect these low levels of PCBs might have on birds or fish species. Earlier investigations have been conducted by other research workers at different locations.
In regard to the presence of PCBs in humans, food and packaging, I am advised that:

(i) a survey was conducted by the Division of Occupational Health and Radiation Control of the New South Wales Health Commission to determine the health effects of PCBs on exposed workers employed in the electrical industry. Thirty-four PCBs workers were examined; in general they complained of burning sensation on the face and neck during exposure to PCB 'fume'. Five suffered from eczematous rash on the hands and legs. PCB blood levels ranged from 300-600 parts per billion ( ppb) compared to zero level among 30 non-exposed workers. Since PCBs are hepatoxic, liver function tests were done on these workers. The results were normal.

(ii) Since 1976, the published results of the National Health and Medical Research Council's Market Basket Surveys indicate that no PCBs were detected in processed food samples for the years 1976-79. These results would also imply that packaging is free from PCBs.

(5) I am advised that PCBs are irritant to the eyes and cause an acne-form dermatitis (chloracne). In the absence of epidemiological data, long term effects of exposure to PCBs, apart from an incidence of liver toxicity and skin complaints, are largely unknown. This is confirmed in a recent study carried out on PCB workers in Milan where liver damage was correlated to PCB levels in the blood. The authors of that study have indicated their intention to begin epidemiological studies to determine whether there is any suggestion of a positive association between PCB exposure and cancer.

(6) Incineration in special high-temperature incinerators is the only environmentally acceptable means of disposing of polychlorinated biphenyls. No such specific-purpose incinerator exists in Australia at the present time. Although I understand that the New South Wales Metropolitan Waste Disposal Authority has plans to construct such a facility. An incinerator presently operating in Perth is capable of burning small quantities of PCBs at high temperatures. PCBs have also been destroyed in cement kilns in Canada and Sweden .
PCBs can be shipped from Australia for destruction in other countries. In 1978, an Australian company did use this means of disposing of stocks of PCB wastes.
Research into other methods of degrading PCBs is being carried out in the United States. Recently a chemical process which can be used to degrade wastes containing PCBs was announced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: How much money has been paid to date to successful appellants on social security matters before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal by: (a) the Department of Social Security; and (b) the Department of Finance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The amount of money paid to successful appellants on social security matters before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which would not have been paid but for success before the Tribunal, is not capable of ready calculation. However, the Department of Social Security has paid or is in the process of paying all amounts which are required to be paid to such persons in accordance with decisions of the tribunal.

(b) None. On two occasions where the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has found that no payment to an appellant could lawfully be made pursuant to the Social Services Act 1947, the Tribunal has nevertheless recommended that consideration be given to the making of an act of grace payment. Such payments may be made only pursuant to and within the provisions of Section 34A of the Audit Act 1901, which is administered by the Minister for Finance. In each of these two cases, therefore, the Tribunal's recommendation has been forwarded to the Department of Finance for consideration by the Minister for Finance or an authorised officer. In one case the Minister for Finance was not satisfied that an act of grace payment was justified under the provisions of Section 34A. The second case is still under consideration.

Act of grace payments approved in relation to social security matters are normally made by the Department of Social Security (currently from Appropriation Item 590.3.09) and not by the Department of Finance.

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated financial impact of the Public Service Acts Amendment Bill, 1982 for:

(b) the next and succeeding two financial years,
and what is:
(i) the estimated financial burden, if any, which will be imposed on industry or other sections of the community; and
(ii) the estimated savings of governments, if any.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Bill is not expected to have any financial impact in the financial year 1981-82.
(b) In current terms the following savings might be achieved: 1982-83-$1.82m, 1983-84-$1.84m, 1984-85-$1.85m.

These savings are based on estimates of Public Service promotion rates, and derive from the proposed s.50E in Clause 27 of the Bill which provides for salary on promotion to be payable from a prescribed day. It is proposed that the prescribed day will be five weeks after notification of the promotion in the Gazette. Under present legislation salary on promotion is payable from the date of notification in the Gazette.

(i) The proposed s.64 in Clause 43 of the Bill provides for the recovery by a creditor of a debt owed by an officer of the Australian Public Service through attachment of salary. A small administration fee yet to be settled will be payable by the creditor to the Commonwealth for the service of collecting the debt on his behalf.

(ii) The savings due to the proposed new rule for payment of salary on promotion are estimated in the answer to (b). The savings due to the administration fee mentioned in the answer to (i) will result in the accrual of a small amount of revenue by the Commonwealth.
