QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have all Australian fissile material exports been audited by the Australian Safeguards Office as outlined by the Minister for National Development and Energy in the Senate (see Senate Hansard, pages 186-7 of 18 February 1982); if so, have those audits, which are carried out overseas, been checked.
(2) How many officers carry out these audits overseas.
(3) What methods do these officers employ in their audits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Australian Safeguards Office maintains inventories of all nuclear exports. Inventories of all safeguardable nuclear items are checked by regular consultation and exchange of information with responsible authorities under Australia'a bilateral Safeguards Agreements.
(2) The ASO has five officers contributing to nuclear material accountancy and control. ASO audits do not necessarily involve overseas inspections by ASO employees.

(3) Methods of auditing are based on those used by the IAEA. Details of these are available in pamphlet IAEA/SG/INF/3 IAEA Safeguards An Introduction. Arrangements have been made for the pamphlet to be deposited in the Parliamentary Library.

ASO methods of audit also recognise an additional accounting obligation arising from Australia's bilateral Safeguards Agreements to specifically identify nuclear material subject to these Agreements at certain points. Australia's Safeguards Agreements ensure that Australian origin nuclear material will be subject to such accounting throughout its lifetime.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Transport or the Department of Aviation granted approval to Mr Keith Williams to construct an airstrip at his Hamilton Island resort project on the Great Barrier Reef; if so, what will be the dimensions of the proposed runway.
(2) What types of aircraft will be permitted to use the airstrip.
(3) When is the airstrip due for completion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are the National Acoustic Laboratories (NAL) the only source of hearing aids for pensioners in Australia.
(2) Why are pensioners forced to wait for periods from six to twelve months for the supply of a hearing aid from the NAL.
(3) What action is being considered to overcome these delays.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Acoustic Laboratories (NAL) are the only source in Australia providing free hearing aids, service and batteries to eligible pensioners. Pensioners, if they so wish can obtain hearing aids from private sector hearing services. They would however have to pay the full price of the aids and the services provided.

(2) The waiting times for the expanding population of eligible pensioners are the results of catering for the increased demand with the available staff. In addition, priority for initial appointments is given to children and young people under 21 years of age with hearing difficulties to ensure that their education and possibilities of entering the workforce will suffer to the minimum extent possible. Eligible pensioners are assessed after an average waiting time for all hearing centres of 4.4 months for initial appointments. Depending on the type of aid required to be manufactured and/or supplied, fitting of the hearing aid will be completed after an average of a further two weeks.

(3) Delays in waiting times have been minimised by improving arrangements for the training of staff, reviewing work methods, reviewing appointment schedules and by including new features in hearing aids. Further increases in demand by eligible pensioners will be met by a continuing revision of work methods and, as necessary, by reconsideration of Departmental work priorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many abattoirs have closed or reduced their workforce since January 1978.
(2) Can he supply a list of those abattoirs which have (a) closed, and (b) reduced their workforce.
(3) What was the loss of jobs suffered in each of 2 (a) and 2 (b).
(4) What is the prospect for further closures or reduced operations over the next 12 months.
(5) What action has the Government taken to assist the meat processing industry meet its problems.
(6) What action is proposed to ensure an orderly rationalisation of the meat processing industry.
(7) What is the estimated loss of income to country centres where abattoirs have either closed or reduced operations.
(8) What is the estimate of the number of jobs lost in non-abattoirs employment as the result of the retrenchment of an abattoirs worker.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Twenty export registered abattoirs have closed since January 1978. In addition, the export works at Derby, which normally operates on a seasonal basis , has not operated for the past two seasons. My Department has no statistics on the number of export registered premises which have reduced their workforce. Statistics relating to abattoirs operating for the domestic market and for slaughterhouses are available from State authorities with responsibilities in this area.
(2) (a) The following is a list of registered export abattoirs which have now closed:
New South Wales
Wagga Abattoir-Wagga
Anderson Meat Packing-Wallangarra
Condobolin Industries Ltd-Condobolin
T. A. Field Pty Ltd-Orange
Goulburn City Council-Goulburn
Gwydir Valley (Abattoir) County Council-Moree
Illawarra Meat Co.-Yallah
New England (Abattoir) County Council-Guyra
Riverstone Meat Co.-Tenterfield
Dubbo Abattoir-Dubbo
Victoria
Farmers and Graziers-Brooklyn
Anderson Meat Packing-Shepparton
T. Borthwick & Sons (Aust.) Pty Ltd-Portland
J. C. Hutton Pty Ltd-Kyneton
Ballarat Abattoir-Ballarat
Protean-Geelong
Queensland
T. Borthwick & Sons (A'asia) Pty Ltd-Murarrie
Roma Meat Works Pty Ltd-Roma
Western Australia
Midland Junction-Perth
Anchorage Butchers-Coogee
Derby-Derby (has not operated past two seasons).
(2) (b) see reply to (1).
(3) (a) As a result of the closure of the export works listed, in excess of 8, 000 abattoir workers were unemployed.

(4) Estimates of cattle numbers at March 1983 indicate that the cattle herd will be around 24.7m head, a slight reduction on March 1982 levels. This reduced availability of stock coupled with already very low rates of utilisation in many export works due to weak demand in our major export markets would suggest that further rationalisation is inevitable in the next 12 months.
(5) The Government has considered requests from the industry but decided not to offer assistance.

Government assistance to the meat processing industry will not alleviate the shortage of stock for slaughter. To assist both producers and processors, the Government has, however, directed its efforts to negotiating minimum levels of access for Australian beef exports in overseas markets in the belief that this will add greater stability to the industry in the future. For example, the Government in the Multilateral Trade Negotiations, was able to negotiate guaranteed global levels of access to the United States and Canada and to obtain an assurance of growth in the Japanese market. In addition, the European Economic Community gave an assurance on levels of imports of manufacturing beef and agreed to increase its quota for imports of beef free of import levy. The Community also established a levy free quota of 21,000 tonnes of high quality beef of which 5,000 tonnes is specifically reserved for Australia.

In addition to these measures, meat producers and exporters have received significant benefits through Export Market Development Grants ($2.7m in 1979-80) and through promotional efforts internationally by both the AMLC and the Department of Trade and Resources and domestically by the AMLC.

(6) The fundamental problem of the abattoir industry at the present time is that there is overcapacity in many works in relation to the number of stock available for slaughter and this is likely to be the case for the next few years . Fluctuations in the national cattle herd are largely responsible for the present situation. Abattoir expansion was widespread during the boom years for the cattle industry in the early 1970s but numbers have decreased since the mid 1970s due to poor export demand and drought over much of Australia, leaving abattoirs with excess capacity.

It is the Government's belief that the rationalisation process should proceed without Government direction or assistance and that commercial considerations should determine the size and location of works.
(7) I have no information on the estimated loss of income to country centres where abattoirs have either closed or reduced operations.
(8) I have no information on the estimated number of jobs lost in non-abattoir employment as a result of retrenchment of an abattoir worker.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any official estimate of how much it would cost (in 1982 dollars) to overcome problems of land degradation in Australia.
(2) Is land degradation, as it affects agricultural production, worsening.
(3) In any allocation of funds on a national basis, which (a) States; and (b) regions would have the ten highest priority places.
(4) Is any part of Australian primary industry now: (a) losing production; or ( b) likely to lose production because of land degradation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 'The Commonwealth and State Government Collaborative Soil Conservation Study 1975-77,' released in April 1978, estimated the cost of treating and controlling land degradation at $675m in 1975 prices.

(2) The 1975-77 Collaborative Study found that about half of the agricultural and pastoral land in Australia required some form of treatment. No comparative and comprehensive study has since been made.
(3) Soil conservation is a responsibility of the States and the allocation of priorities is a matter for the States.

(4) While farm management and soil conservation practices may minimise land degradation, it needs to be recognised that agricutural development can involve an acceleration of natural land degradation. Land degradation would, of itself, lead to reduced production in most circumstances.

Rural development in Australia has resulted in a steady significant growth in total production and, with due attention to soil protection, this production can be maintained. However, the Collaborative Study indicates that, across the rural production areas of Australia, degradation ranges from minimal, where soil protection measures are highly effective, to the point where production is impossible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the funds for the integrated Family Services Emergency Relief Funds for the City of Fremantle be completely withdrawn; if so, what are the reasons for this decision.
(2) Was there any consultation between the Department of Social Security and the City Council before such a decision was made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)) The City of Fremantle was approved to receive funding of $55,000 in respect of the extended Family Support Services Scheme for the three year period 1 January 1982 to 31 December 1984. The City Council will continue to receive funding for their Integrated Family Services Emergency Relief Funds to 30 June 1982. The Western Australian Commonwealth/State Management Committee (comprising representatives from my department and the Western Australian Department for Community Welfare), which nominates organisations for funding, proposed that those services sponsored by Municipal Corporations should receive basic salary rates plus an allowance for indexation increases, but after 1 July 1982 program and administrative costs should be met by the Municipality. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Entitlements and eligibility criteria vary from State to State, no doubt reflecting differences in State government policies and in geographical circumstances. The Commonwealth Government has no responsibility in these matters.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for National Development and Energy say in reply to a question without notice on 23 March 1982 that the Australian Radiation Authority carries out a national progam of monitoring Strontium 90 levels.
(2) When was this program begun.
(3) How often is this monitoring carried out.
(4) Where is this monitoring carried out.
(5) What have been the results of this program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The routine program for monitoring Strontium 90 in the Australian environment is carried out by the Australian Radiation Laboratory and began in 1957.
(3) Currently two types of samples are collected for analysis:

(i) Milk being processed commercially for human consumption is sampled monthly with the samples forwarded to the Australian Radiation Laboratory where they are combined for analysis as quarterly samples representative of each city in which they were collected.
(ii) Fallout deposit is collected on a continuous basis for analysis as a quarterly sample for each collecting station.
(i) Milk is sampled in the six State capitals, viz: Perth, Adelaide, Melbourne, Sydney, Hobart and Brisbane.

(ii) Fallout deposit is collected in the six State capitals, in a town in the dairying area serving each of the State capitals, and in two other populous towns, viz: Perth and Wokalup (WA); Adelaide and Meadows (SA); Melbourne and Warragul (Vic); Sydney and Berry (NSW); Hobart and Hadspen (Tas); Brisbane and Samford (Qld); and Townsville (Qld) and Darwin (NT).

(5) My colleague the Minister for Health advises that the results of monitoring programs since 1957 have indicated that Strontium 90 in fallout has created no significant hazard to the health of the Australian population. Results up to 1974 have been published in scientific journals and in Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council (AIRAC) Reports Nos 1 and 2. Results for later years are being collated for publication; however levels of Strontium 90 in the environment have declined steadily in recent years and have now reached levels which are barely detectable by the most sensitive analytical methods available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Were any special instructions issued to any lightstations during the period 1 November 1981 to 28 February 1982 last regarding assistance to the public during the holiday period, and especially in relation to the major yacht races; if so, (a) what added costs were involved; (b) was aid or assistance rendered by any lightstation to the public over this period; and (c) what was the nature of the instructions issued to the lightstations regarding this matter.

Lightkeepers are instructed as a matter of course that to the extent that their navigation aid duties permit they should observe passing vessels and report any signs of distress, difficulty or unusual activity to the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre.
(a) Not applicable.

(b) In accordance with normal practice there were two reports from lightstations to the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre during this period of yachts which appeared to be in trouble. In neither case were lightkeepers required to provide aid. In one case the yacht continued its passage normally after a short while. In the other the State Police already had the matter in hand.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the function of the Australian Universities International Development Program, sponsored by the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee.
(2) Is the AUIDP funded by a grant from the Australian Development Assistance Bureau; if so, what amounts have been allocated to it in each of the past five years.
(3) When was the AUIDP established and what are its main objectives.
(4) How is policy of the AUIDP formulated, who are the members of the governing body and how are they selected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The function of the Australian Universities International Development Program (AUIDP) is to help strengthen universities in the developing countries of the ASEAN region, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore and Thailand. This is achieved through the direct assistance of Australian universities co- ordinated by the AUIDP. AUIDP only engages in activities specifically requested by the appropriate authorities in the developing countries. Activities include:
short and long term secondments of Australian academics to particular faculties or institutions.
intensive training courses for groups of academics.
fellowships for training either in Australia or in the home country.
provision of research support.
preparation and publication of text books and teaching manuals in either English or the home country language.
support for programs of English language teaching in overseas universities.
(2) AUIDP receives a grant from the Australian Development Assistance Bureau ( ADAB) towards the cost of its overseas activities. The amounts allocated to AUIDP in each of the past five years are:

(3) The AUIDP was formally established in November 1969 through an exchange of letters between the Chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee (AVCC) and the Minister of Foreign Affairs. It was originally known as the Australian Asian Universities Co-operation Scheme.

The AUIDP aims to assist universities in the developing countries of the ASEAN region to improve their own capacities in teaching and research, mainly through staff development, and to help promote the contribution of these universities to the development of their respective countries.

(4) All AUIDP policy is formulated by a Standing Committee of the AVCC in close consultation with ADAB. ADAB is responsible for maintaining broad aid policy objectives in the light of the stated needs of the recipient countries.
The AUIDP Standing Committee fulfills the role of a governing board. Members of the Committee are Vice-Chancellors and other senior academics. Members of the Committee at present are:
Professor K. J. C. Black-Chairman
Professor E. C. Webb-Deputy Chairman
Professor D. E. Tribe
Dr R. Knight
Professor M. J. T. Norman
Professor W. A. Rachinger
Mr J. E. Ritchie
Professor N. M. Tulloh
Professor A. S. Carrington
Professor R. C. Gates
Professor D. A. Low
Dr P. A. Denham
Dr G. J. Hugo
Professor D. Lim
Associate Professor D. R. Lindsay
ADAB representatives always attend meetings of the Standing Committee.

The Standing Committee is appointed by the AVCC and, except for the four Vice- Chancellor representatives, each individual serves for five years, two being replaced each year. Members are nominated in order to maintain a broad balance of disciplines, developing country experience and Australian university representation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Merrill Lynch and Agricultural Investments Australia Ltd

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: On what date did the former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs resign from directorships of the stockbroking firm Merrill Lynch and the rural property company Agricultural Investments Australia Ltd.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In accordance with the Government's acceptance of the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest, Ministers are precluded from engaging in professional practice, from being involved in the daily routine work of any business or from holding directorships other than directorships, in certain circumstances, in family private companies. Ministers also provide me with a written statement of any relevant pecuniary interests they may have. Also consistent with the Inquiry's recommendations, it has not been the practice to make these statements public.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. What broadcast areas are currently served by the Radio Australia transmission station at Shepparton in Victoria.

2. Have there been any complaints of inadequate reception as a result of transmissions from Shepparton: if so, (a) what were the nature of these complaints; and (b) from what areas did they originate.
3. Is short-wave transmission to areas such as Papua New Guinea most technically effective from a distance such as the distance of Shepparton from Papua New Guinea.
4. What technical assessment has been made, and what advice has the Government received, of the relative technical merits of transmission from Shepparton and Townsville.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communication has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Indonesia, Malaysia, Indo-China, Papua New Guinea, Central Pacific, South Pacific, New Zealand, Philippines, Japan, India, Africa, United Kingdom, North America, Antarctica.
2. Yes.
(a) Inadequate signal levels; interference (including jamming); inadequate duration of service; inferiority to competitive short-wave broadcasters' services.
(b) All target areas via Department of Foreign Affairs, the Australian Broadcasting Commission, official monitors in the areas and direct from individuals.

3. No. However, technical effectiveness is only one of several important considerations. Choice of particular transmission sites is influenced by many factors, including investment in existing sites, availability of suitable technical staff and accessibility for production and program purposes.

4. No technical assessments by the Department have been presented to the National Broadcasting Service Planning Committee at this time. No advice is currently under consideration by the Government on the relative technical merits of transmission from Shepparton and Townsville.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When and where have there been meetings of Ministers on human rights.
(2) What are the names and titles of the Ministers who attended each meeting.
(3) What international conventions have been considered at each meeting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) To date there have been nine meetings of Ministers on human rights. At Tanunda on 8 February 1979; Sydney on 4 May 1979; Port Moresby on 24 July 1979; Brisbane on 13 October 1979; Hobart on 14 February 1980; Alice Springs on 6 November 1980; Canberra on 10 April 1981; Cairns on 2 August 1981; and Queenstown, New Zealand, on 15 February 1982.

(2) and (3) The Ministers present at the meeting in Tanunda were myself, as Commonwealth Attorney-General; the Honourable F. J. Walker M.L.A., Attorney- General of New South Wales; the Honourable Haddon Storey Q.C., M.L.C., Attorney- General of Victoria; the Honourable W. D. Lickiss M.L.A., Minister for Justice and Attorney-General of Queensland; the Honourable P. T. Duncan M.L.C., Attorney -General of South Australia; the Honourable I. G. Medcalf Q.C., M.L.C., Attorney -General and Minister for Federal Affairs of Western Australia; the Honourable B . K. Miller M.L.C., Attorney-General and Minister for Police and Emergency Services of Tasmania; and the Honourable P. A. E. Everingham M.L.A., Chief Minister and Attorney-General of the Northern Territory. As this was the first meeting of Ministers on Human Rights there was no substantive consideration of international conventions.

The Ministers present at the Sydney meeting were the same as those present at Tanunda except that the Hounourable C. J. Sumner M.L.C., Attorney-General and Minister of Prices and Consumer Affairs represented South Australia. Ministers gave consideration to the ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The Ministers present at Port Moresby were the same as those present at the Sydney meeting except that Tasmania did not have a ministerial representative and the Honourable A. J. Hunt M.P., Minister for Education, represented Mr Storey. At this meeting Ministers gave consideration to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The Ministers present at Brisbane were the same as those present at the Sydney meeting except that New South Wales did not have a ministerial representative and the Honourable K. T. Griffin M.L.C., Attorney-General represented South Australia. Ministers gave further consideration to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The Ministers present at the Hobart meeting were the same as those present at the Brisbane meeting except that neither Western Australia nor the Northern Territory had a ministerial representative. Ministers gave consideration to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

The Ministers present at the Darwin meeting were myself; Mr Walker; Mr Storey, the Honourable G. James M.H.A., Minister for Public Health, Consumer Affairs and Administrative Services, Tasmania, representing the Attorney-General; the Honourable J. Robertson M.L.A., Acting Attorney-General of the Northern Territory. Ministers considered aspects of the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination and the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

The Ministers present at the Canberra meeting were myself; the Honourable Ian Wilson M.P., Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, also representing the Commonwealth; Mr Walker, Mr Storey; Mr Griffin and the Honourable S. S. Doumany M.L.A., Minister for Justice and Attorney-General of Queensland. The Honourable P. Torato M.P., Minister for Justice of Papua New Guinea also attended. Ministers gave consideration to Australia's first report under Article 40 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and to the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

All Attorneys-General were present at Cairns. Ministers considered the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women and Australia's first report under Article 40 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

The Ministers present at the Queenstown meeting were the same as those present at Cairns. The New Zealand Minister of Justice, the Honourable J. K. McLay, also attended. Ministers gave consideration to the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

I also mention that, although there was no separate meeting of Ministers on Human Rights as such in Adelaide on the 3-4 July 1980, the Ministers who had met there as the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, namely myself, Mr Walker, Mr Storey, Mr Lickiss, Mr Griffin, Mr Medcalf, Mr Miller and Mr Everingham gave consideration to the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Compensation for Loss or Damage to Luggage

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the maximum compensation to a passenger for liability by an airline for loss or damage to luggage or personal effects $300; if so, when was this sum fixed.
(2) What is being done to bring the figure into line with current values.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Part IV of the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 sets domestic and non-convention air traffic carrier liability limits of $300 for loss or damage to registered baggage and $30 for loss or damage to other than registered baggage. These sums were fixed in 1970 by the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1970.

(2) On 24 March 1982 the then Minister for Transport introduced the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Amendment Bill 1982 aimed, in part, at increasing the domestic and non-convention liability limits prescribed under Part IV of the Act. With regard to baggage, this involves increasing the existing limits to $ 900 for loss or damage to registered baggage and $90 for other than registered baggage. This increase broadly reflects the increases in factors such as the consumer price index and average weekly earnings since the limits were last reviewed in 1970.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the case of Mrs Sylvia M. Faulkner v. the Commonwealth have its origins in business transactions between Mrs S. Faulkner and the Australian Army which took place in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
(2) Is it correct that at the time, investigations carried out led to the resignation of a very senior Army officer in 1973.
(3) Is it correct that Mrs S. Faulkner took legal action against the Commonwealth in 1974, claiming damages of $1.4m.

(4) Is it correct that since that date there have been numerous procedural delays, including delays in approving legal aid by the Australian Legal Aid Office of up to six months, and the filing of a defence by the Crown Solicitor 32 months after particulars were supplied.

(5) Will the Attorney-General inform the Senate what steps are being taken to bring the case to a speedy conclusion, both as a matter of natural justice to Mrs Faulkner and also to contain the monetary expenditure of public funds and would he further inform the Senate of the date on which he expects this matter to be concluded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The proceedings pending between David Joseph Noel Bluett (as trustee of the estate of Sylvia Margaret Faulkner, a bankrupt) as plaintiff and the Commonwealth and Charles Francis Flint as defendants are based on allegations that the Commonwealth, by its agent Brigadier Flint, represented to Mrs Faulkner , as the beneficial owner of the issued share capital in a company, Trisal Engineering Pty Limited, and as its governing director, that the Commonwealth would lodge orders in large quantities for the purchase, for use by the Australian Armed Forces, of articles known as Trisal clips produced by the company and that, relying on those representations, Mrs Faulkner suffered damage . These allegations are all in issue in the proceedings.
(2) Yes.

(3) A writ was issued out of the High Court of Australia on behalf of Mrs Faulkner on 8 May 1974 but was not served on the Commonwealth until 7 May 1975. The writ did not specify the amount of damages claimed. Particulars have been furnished showing the total amount claimed as $1,246,852.

(4) The proceedings have not yet come on for hearing but the Commonwealth has not been guilty of any undue delay in relation to the matter. In particular, it is not correct that the Commonwealth's defence was not filed until 32 months after particulars were supplied. On 8 July 1977 the plaintiff's solicitors furnished further and better particulars requested by the Deputy Crown Solicitor in a letter dated 28 October 1976. In furnishing the further and better particulars the plaintiff's solicitors also indicated that at the hearing of the action leave would be sought to amend the statement of claim. In a letter dated 29 July 1977 the Deputy Crown Solicitor indicated to the plaintiff's solicitors that the amended statement of claim should be filed before the Commonwealth was required to deliver a defence. The amended statement of claim was not delivered to the Deputy Crown Solicitor until 9 August 1978. The Commonwealth's defence was delivered to the plaintiff's solicitors on 22 August 1978 by which time Mrs Faulkner had become a bankrupt and the cause of action had vested in the Official Receiver.

The allegation of delay in approving legal aid to Mrs Faulkner by the Australian Legal Aid Office was considered by my predecessor in May 1976 and he concluded that there had been no undue delay in that Office in considering the application.

Complaints of undue delay on the part of the Commonwealth in dealing with this matter have been made to the Ombudsman on more than one occasion. In relation to the question of legal aid, the Ombudsman appears to have been satisfied with the explanations furnished to him by the Australian Legal Aid Office. In relation to the proceedings generally the Ombudsman, in a letter to Mr R. Faulkner dated 28 September 1981, stated that he had seen no evidence of any attempt to frustrate the litigation of the matter and that he did not regard the actions of the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor in defending the action as coming within that category. He further stated that, given that the legal advisers of the Crown have not accepted that the Commonwealth is legally liable, they have acted properly in defending the Commonwealth against the claim and in declining to made a settlement.

(5) I am unable to indicate when the proceedings are likely to be concluded. At this stage the future course of the proceedings is largely in the hands of the Official Receiver, who has been substituted as plaintiff. The Commonwealth has indicated that it will support any application for an expedited hearing that the plaintiff wishes to make.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In which country do the five persons eligible to receive payment under the Governor-General Act 1974 live.
(2) Where are the five officers situated.

(3) What was the individual cost incurred in the provision of the five offices, secretaries and car transport for 1980-81, and is this cost in addition to the stated figure of $203,784 (See Senate Hansard, page 918).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 to 3) My answer to the honourable senator's earlier question No. 1945 ( Hansard 17 March 1982, page 918) sets out in general terms arrangements made for former Governors-General or their widows.

Except where pension eligibility is conferred by the Governor-General Act 1974, payments in the nature of pensions are made on an ex gratia basis. Two persons are currently eligible for payments under the Governor-General Act 1974. One is resident in Australia and one in Britain. The other three recipients of payments , referred to in my answer to Question No. 1945, receive ex gratia payments as they (in the case of widows, their husbands) ceased to hold office as Governor- General prior to the Governor-General Act coming into force. One of these recipients resides in Australia and the other two in Britain. Payments to the five recipients in 1980-81 amounted to $203,784.

Office facilities, including a secretary and car transport, are provided for two former Governors-General, one in Perth and one in Sydney. These facilities, on a more limited basis than would apply in Australia, are available to Sir John Kerr who for the time being is resident in Britain. In 1980-81, the costs of these facilities were $32,097, $22,708 and $51,670 respectivity. These costs were additional to the pension payments of $203,784.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are well-equipped Sydney private schools such as St Joseph's College, Hunters Hill; St Patricks College, Strathfield and St Aloysius' College, Milsons Point, classified in the deprived category for Federal funding by the Schools Commission, and are such schools subsidised by the taxpayer to the extent of 40 per cent of the average cost of educating a child in a State secondary school.

(2) Will future funding allocations to private schools be made on a strict needs basis only, and cease this discrimination on the part of the Federal Government in favour of the more privileged of the private schools.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the General Recurrent Grants Program administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission, St Joseph's College, Hunters Hill, St Patrick's College, Strathfield and St Aloysius College, Milsons Point have been approved for Group 3 funding in 1982. The per capita grants for this subsidy group represent 38 per cent of the Commission's standard cost of educating a student in a government school, which is calculated on an Australian-wide basis. The subsidy rate for Group 3 schools will increase to 40 per cent in 1983.

(2) The Commonwealth has a policy of funding all schools on the basis of need. General recurrent subsidies to non-government schools are based on a three-tier system of per capita grants which provides a variable level of assistance according to need. The basic minimum per capita grant, available to all non- government schools, represents 20 per cent of the average per pupil cost of education in government school systems. Schools in funding Groups 2 and 3 receive per capita grants in 1982 which represent 30 per cent and 38 per cent respectively of standard government school per pupil costs.

The placement of a school in one of the three funding groups is determined primarily by the school's level of recurrent expenditure per pupil from private sources. This measure of need was first defined by the Karmel Committee in 1973 and has been used since then. However, the Government accepted a Commonwealth Schools Commission recommendation to the effect that, in the case of those schools moving to a higher subsidy group, from 1982 onwards school income as well as expenditure will be considered before determining the need of each school for additional subsidies beyond the basic grant of 20 per cent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are counter staff of the Minister's Department permitted to smoke whilst interviewing clients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The circular 'Smoking in Commonwealth Government Offices,' issued by the Director-General of Health on 20 November 1980 was widely distributed within my Department. Although the circular did not contain specific directives, the general approach was to discourage smoking in certain areas of Commonwealth departments, recreational areas, restaurants, lifts, etc.

Each of my Department's regional offices has the responsibility for determining guidelines to counter staff on the question of smoking. The practice is generally either not permitted, or actively discouraged. In three regional offices, staff are not permitted to smoke while interviewing clients, and the office areas utilised are in fact non-smoking areas for staff. Three other regional offices do not allow counter staff to smoke unless the client being interviewed is smoking, or gives permission. In the remaining two regional offices, no instructions have been issued.
Where no specific action has been taken to declare non-smoking areas for staff, I have asked that the issue be re-examined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are counter staff of the Minister's Department permitted to smoke whilst interviewing clients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In accordance with the Australian Taxation Office policy on smoking in Commonwealth Government offices, Taxation Office staff are discouraged from smoking in interview rooms and at inquiry counters.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics is in the process of determining an overall policy dealing with this issue in accordance with guidelines from the Public Service Board and the Department of Health. In the meantime it is being left to the management of each of its offices to determine a local policy. In all but one office there is as yet no formal policy. However, as a general rule, staff do not smoke because of voluntary restraint or because smoking is discouraged. In the New South Wales office, staff have been instructed that smoking is not permitted in areas where there is public contact.

The Treasury does not have counter staff who interview clients, so the question does not arise. At the Royal Australian Mint, voluntary restraint is exercised by counter staff who have contact with the public and smoking is not practised while serving at the counter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department, if so, in what capacity is it used, if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to 'new' paper wherever possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In circumstances where stocks of papers are rendered surplus to requirements by virtue of changes of name, changes of address and other similar changes, it is the practice for the Department to recycle such stock in the following ways:
the paper may be reduced from A4 size to A5 size and be reprinted as appropriate.
A4 and A5 sizes of headed paper may be converted into writing pads for the reverse side to be used for internal Departmental purposes.
envelopes are recycled through the use of printed 'peel off' labels which are used to cover the outdated details.
(2) As indicated above, paper from the Department is recycled.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to 'new' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled; if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Superseded unused forms are recycled wherever possible for use as note scribblers, pads and for the preparation of draft letters, reports etcetera when only printed on one side.

It is not known if paper supplied to the Department is the result of recycling. Paper is supplied at a price determined through the normal purchasing procedures and there is no condition of contract that it should be recycled paper.

(2) Waste and used paper is collected by private paper recycling contractors from the Department of Health offices in Canberra and most State offices. Further consideration is being given to extending the recycling collection to all States, to the Capital Territory Health Commission offices and to the Canberra and Woden Valley Hospitals.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to 'new' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled; if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All new paper supplied to my Department contains a production component of 30 per cent recycled paper.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to 'new' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled; if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised as follows:
(1) Recycled paper is currently being used by the Department and its authorities for internal purposes wherever practicable.
(2) Generally paper which cannot be used within the Department is sent to the Department of Administrative Services contractor for recycling.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department, if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to 'new' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled: if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Department of National Development and Energy has contracts for purchase, removal and recycling of better quality waste paper, such as superseded maps and publications. The bulk of ordinary office waste is removed under contracts let by the Department of Administrative Service, which provide that waste should be recycled wherever possible.

Internally the Department attempts to maximise the use of paper before it is removed, including using the reverse side of superseded forms as note paper and over printing redundant forms, envelopes et cetera if possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to 'new' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled: if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes: recycled paper is used to the extent that such paper has been included in material provided to the Department by the Commonwealth Government Printer and commercial suppliers. It is understood that products such as envelopes, board, cartons, hand towels etc. contain a percentage of recycled paper. It is not known whether any recycled paper is included in 'new' paper used by the Department. Some scrap paper is used again for notepads, backing sheets and similar purposes.

(2) The majority of waste paper collected within my Department comes within cleaning contracts under the control of the Minister for Administrative Services . It is understood that a large amount of this waste paper is recycled.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to 'new' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled; if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My department purchases bulk paper under contract arranged by the Department of Administrative Services. No details are available on whether the paper is recycled paper.
(2) The department makes use of facilities to recycle paper.
Generally waste paper from offices in all States and Territories, except Tasmania and the Northern Territory, is recycled. Companies operating under government contract undertake the task.
Some waste paper, for example, from staff rubbish bins and from offices in country areas where a recycling service is not available, has to be burnt.
In Tasmania and the Northern Territory a recycling service is not available and all waste paper is burnt.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are a large number of Australian small business people facing bankruptcy in the early stages of the establishment of their businesses because of the burden of provisional tax.

(2) Will the Treasurer consider making provisional tax payable quarterly so that it would be fully paid within a year and would allow for reconciliation with actual tax assessed/paid and the issue of that year's provisional assessment; if not, can Australia's small business people look forward to some form of provisional tax relief in the August budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no evidence to suggest that a large number of small business people face bankruptcy in the early stages of the establishment of their businesses because of the burden of provisional tax. Wage and salary earners pay tax, via instalment deductions, as their income is received. Provisional payments, like pay-as-you-earn deductions, are intended to collect the main part of the tax on a year's income during that same year, although in the case of provisional tax it is not collected until nine months of the year have elapsed.

(2) One of the recommendations of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System (the Campbell Committee) was that the arrangements for collecting provisional tax be reviewed with the aim of introducing a system of instalment payments at an early date. The Government will consider this recommendation along with the other recommendations of the Committee.

(3) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 18 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who are the directors of Forest Home Films Pty Ltd.

(2) How much capital was invested by them as distinct from the Australian Film Commission loan of $35,000 as listed in appendix A of the Annual Report of the Australian Film Commission for the film The Killing of Angel Street.
(3) What arrangements have been made by Forest Home Films Pty Ltd to repay the Australian Film Commission loan.
(4) Who are the other creditors.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Film Commission has advised as follows:

(1) Forest Home Films Pty Ltd, was established in 1977 to produce the film The Irishman, and subsequently produced The Night. The Prowler, The Killing of Angel Street and Kitty and the Bagman. The directors were Anthony Buckley, Donald Crombie and Judith Crombie. Mr Buckley has recently resigned his directorship.

(2) No capital was invested by the directors of Forest Home Films Pty Ltd, in the production of The Killing of Angel Street. This accords with normal practice in the film industry, whereby investors contract and fully fund a production company to produce a film on their behalf.
(3) The Loan of $35,000 to Forest Home Films Pty Ltd, listed in appendix A of the 1981 Annual Report of the Australian Film Commission has been repaid, with interest.
(4) The auditor's report on The Killing of Angel Street dated 30 April 1982, lists no creditors of the film, except in respect of the fee owing to the auditors for their report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked all Ministers, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress has been made in the completion of Stage 2 of the Ross River Dam.
(2) Have the seepage problems been overcome; if so, how were they rectified; if not, what work still needs to be carried out to overcome the problem.

(3) Has the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation or any other Commonwealth authority recently been involved with any aspect of the dam's stability or construction; if so, what was the Corporation's or the authority's role. (See Senate Questions on Notice Nos 3146, 3148 and 3151 of 9 September 1980, question without notice relating to the Ross River Dam of 17 September 1980 and the subsequent written reply dated 2 October 1980).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Apart from the fitting of temporary crest gates across the spillway to raise stored water level by four feet, no work on Stage 2 of the Ross River Dam has been undertaken since the raising of the earthfill embankment on the left bank of the river was completed in 1976. A start on the relocation of the highway and railway to Charters Towers has not yet been made.

(2) Seepage problems at Ross River Dam have been under intensive investigation during the past two years, and the Queensland Water Resources Commission is now finalising a report to the Townsville City Council which will present the results of these investigations and details of the works required to overcome the seepage problems.

A decision on whether or not to proceed with the recommended remedial measures is one for the Townsville City Council, having regard to the costs involved and the availability and costs of water supplies which may be obtainable from other sources. It is expected that the Council will reach this decision in the coming months.

(3) There has been no involvement by the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation or any other Commonwealth organisation since the Corporation reviewed, in February 1980, the proposals of the Queensland Water Resources Commission for detailed investigations into the seepage problem.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the food price index produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics no longer produced on a monthly basis; if so, why is it no longer being produced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that, following their publication for March 1982, food group indexes for the six State capital cities, Canberra and Darwin will no longer be compiled and published on a monthly basis.

In the course of a general review of the consumer price index, the Australian Statistician considered the desirable frequency of collection of prices of all goods and services included in the index, bearing in mind the extent of short term price fluctuations of particular items and their weighting in the total index. He also reviewed the resources required to collect all food prices every month and to compile a monthly food price index, against the use made of that monthly index. The Statistician concluded that it would be a more effective disposition of the resources involved, from the point of view of the overall reliability of the index, to use these resources to increase the frequency with which some non-food prices are collected and to decrease the frequency with which some food prices have been collected in the past.
