TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 February 1982 (Hansard, Page 74) Senator Mulvihill asked the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, refers to the massive dimensions of what I might call embezzlement that can occur in the manipulation of or rorts in computer operations. I ask the Minister: Firstly, is he satisfied that our federal legislation is adequate to grapple with such white collar crime manifestations and, secondly, is he satisfied that our law enforcement agencies have sufficient sophistication in this industry to detect the offenders?

My colleague the Attorney-General provided a response to the first part of that question and advised that he was referring the second part concerning law enforcement agencies to the Minister for Administrative Services for a more detailed answer. The Minister for Administrative Services has now provided the following answer:

The Australian Federal Police provides training for its investigators and those of the State Police Forces in the form of an annual course of four weeks' duration conducted at the Australian Police College, Manly, New South Wales, aimed at providing a practical approach to the use and manipulation of computers.

The question of specialist training overseas is being examined following the recent return of a senior officer from a course at the Federal Bureau of Investigation Academy at Quantico, Virginia, United States of America.

A pilot training course for investigators of computer-related crime was held at Rokeby in Tasmania between 19 and 23 April 1982. The course was developed in conjunction with the National Companies and Securities Commission and was conducted under the auspices of the Australian Police College. Representatives from all Corporate Affairs Commissions and Police Forces in Australia attended for the purpose of evaluating the course content and determining the direction further training will take. If this pilot course proves to be acceptable, it is proposed to include it as a basic training unit in the normal training programs of all Police Forces.

The Australian Police Minister's Council also has considered, at my request, the adequacy of existing statistics in the area of white collar crime and has asked me to take up with relevant colleagues the question of improving statistical data in this area with a view to more accurately identifying the dimensions of the law enforcement problem. I will be pursuing the matter with the Treasurer, as Minister responsible for the Australian Bureau of Statistics, at an early date.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 March 1982, (Hansard, page 572) Senator Jones asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it normal practice for Telecom Australia subscribers on Great Barrier Reef Island resorts to have to pay in advance for the installation of radio/ telephone facilities to those islands from the mainland? It is a fact that the Minister for Communications chaired a meeting between Telecom and a Mr Keith Williams, the developer of a new resort at Hamilton Island, off Proserpine, at which a decision was made that Telecom would install a 60-channel radio telephone initially, followed by a 350-channel radio/telephone with no advance payment being made by Mr Williams?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Under By-law 51 the Commission is empowered to determine the charges which will apply for the provision of telephone services to a subscriber in a place remote from developed areas where significant capital expenditure is required. In the case of Mr Williams' development at Hamilton Island a radio system with an ultimate capacity of 60 channels is at present being installed. This will cater for Mr Williams' initial requirement for six circuits and provide spare capacity for his future needs and for other applicants expected on the island in the future. The commercial condition determined for the services for Mr Williams was a capital contribution of $56,000 of which he has already paid a deposit of $20,000 with the remainder due before connection.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: United Kingdom: Hospital Charges for Visitors

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 March 1982 (Hansard, page 577) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning free hospital treatment for United Kingdom visitors.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

It is true that foreign visitors to the United Kingdom will no longer be provided with free hospital treatment under the UK National Health Scheme from October 1982, unless their home government has entered into a reciprocal health agreement with the UK Government. It is also true that Australia has no such reciprocal agreement. However, this is for reasons other than those mentioned by the honourable senator.

Under existing health financing arrangements State Governments have sole responsibility for the administration of their respective public hospital systems, including policy on charges. The role of the States was reinforced with the changes to the health care arrangements introduced on 1 September 1981 . The Federal Government is, therefore, not in the same position to guarantee ' free' recognised hospital care to UK visitors as the governments of the countries referred to by the honourable senator. I understand that in those countries the national government is generally responsible for the provision of public hospital care and thus able to implement undertakings given under a reciprocal agreement. Australian States may provide such care if they so wish.

So far as the Federal Government's responsibilities are concerned, all persons from the date they take out at least basic medical cover with registered medical benefits organisations are eligible for Commonwealth Medical Benefits. This includes visitors to Australia. Other Federal health benefits (domiciliary nursing care benefit, nursing home benefits and pharmaceutical benefits) are also available to all persons in Australia, irrespective of country of origin or residential address.
Notwithstanding the new arrangements in the UK from October 1982, I am advised that accident and emergency outpatient treatment will remain free to visitors from other countries.

Finally, the impact of this UK action should be judged in the knowledge that most Australians visiting the UK usually travel to other countries and therefore need insurance coverage against possible health care costs in those countries. This need for insurance would remain, regardless of any entitlement in the UK.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 March 1982 (Hansard, page 642) Senator Lajovic asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources noted an item in the Daily Commercial News of 8 March stating that the Australian sheet steel industry is being swamped by a tidal wave of low cost imports? Can the Minister confirm whether that statement is correct? If it is correct, can the Minister advise the Senate of what action the Government has taken or intends to take to prevent dumping of steel on the Australian market?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The article of 8 March 1982 has been drawn to my attention.

In January 1982, the Department of Industry and Commerce notified interested parties that it had received a request for temporary assistance against imports of certain types of hot rolled, cold rolled and coated sheet steel

Subsequently the Department received a request for temporary assistance on certain other forms of hot rolled flat steel products and on steel pipes and tubes, and this request was notified to interested parties at the end of March.

Following analysis of the information necessary to the consideration of these two requests, I announced on 21 May 1982 that a reference would be sent to the Temporary Assistance Authority on the question of urgent assistance to the industry producing these goods. I also announced that the Industries Assistance Commission would be asked to report on the question of longer term assistance to the production of a wider range of steel products. The references were sent on 25 May 1982, and the Temporary Assistance Authority is to report within 45 days and the Industries Assistance Commission within 12 months.

The Australian steel industry has been concerned at both the overall increase in imports and at the alleged dumping of imported steel on the Australian market. Following investigations into complaints lodged by the industry, an undertaking was given by steel exporters of the Republic of Korea to export at a price which excluded any dumping margin. Investigation of alleged dumping from several European sources is nearing completion.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1028) Senator Robertson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning expenditure on rehabilitation in the Finniss River area.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Responsibility for the rehabilitation of Rum Jungle rests with the Minister for National Development and Energy who has advised that the Civil Works Program 1980-81, Budget Paper No. 5, item 17 (Department of Housing and Construction, Capital Works and Services), contained a proposed new works program of $12m for rehabilitation of Rum Jungle, subject to report by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. In addition an amount of $140 ,000 was provided in the 1980-81 Budget, for detailed site investigations. Following an approach to the Prime Minister by the Chief Minister, Northern Territory, the Commonwealth Government in 1981 accepted in principle that the Northern Territory should take responsibility for conducting the work, subject to Northern Territory advice on standards, costs and time frame for a program. This financial year the Commonwealth is providing the Northern Territory with $ 200,000 to carry out investigative work to establish the standards to which rehabilitation is to be undertaken, the measures which are to be adopted, firm estimated costs and the time frame for undertaking the program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1094) Senator Giles asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, refers to Australian representation at the United Nations and at other international forums. In determining the composition of the Australian delegation to the United Nations Committee on World Disarmament Conference in June of this year, will the Minister seek advice from the National Women's Advisory Council or the office of Women's Affairs regarding inclusion of women in the delegation in view of the long association of various Australian women's organisations with questions of peace and disarmament? Can the Minister guarantee that the value of Australia's participation in this and other international forums will not be diminished by financial and staffing constraints which would inevitably affect the level of support, the preparation of briefs and, in general, the quality of the Australian delegation's performance?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The delegation, which I led, included the Australian Permanent Representative to the United Nations, Mr Anderson, the Australian Representative to the Committee on Disarmanent in Geneva, Mr Sadleir, and other Officials drawn from Australian missions in Geneva and New York as well as from the Departments of Defence and Foreign Affairs in Canberra.

The Government was confident that the Australian delegation to the Special Session was able to represent fully the policies of the Australian Government and the interests of all Australians including women. The officer in our permanent mission to the United Nations in New York who deals with disarmament matters on a full time basis is a woman, Miss Susan Boyd, who was a member of the Australian delegation to the Special Session.

As part of the Government's preparations for the Special Session, the Department of Foreign Affairs held consultations with representatives of a number of non-government organisations, including women's organisations, interested in disarmament issues. Our delegation in New York had regular meetings with representatives of Australian NGOs who travelled to New York for the Session.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1090) Senator Martyr asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs will be aware of the Prime Minister's recent statement that Soviet military occupation of Afghanistan was violating the most elementary laws of international behaviour. Does the Minister agree that the Soviet Union has done exactly the same for nearly all the years of its existence? Is the Minister aware that sporting teams and other delegations from Australia and elsewhere continue to visit the Soviet Union and maintain all manner of other links with the Soviet Union? Is it the intention of the Government to sever all these connections with the Soviet Union? If not, will the Government allow the same sort of contracts-I understand that it is called even-handedness-to be made with South Africa? Is the Minister aware that our trade with South Africa is actually increasing, that South African minerals are vital to the free world's economy and that South Africa is vital to Indian Ocean security? Does the Minister therefore agree that we should work at a better relationship with South Africa?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Soviet Union's continuing occupation of Afghanistan and its disregard of the views of many countries have not given the international community any cause to discontinue its strong condemnation of what has occurred in Afghanistan. In these circumstances, and in view of recent events in Poland, the Government is not prepared to conduct normal bilateral relations with the Soviet Union and has made its position clear to the Soviet authorities.

It is true that, because of its invasion of Afghanistan, the Government has imposed a number of limitations on Australia's bilateral relations with the Soviet Union. These measures include the suspension of cultural, scientific, academic, trade union and sporting exchanges, a ban on the use of Australian ports by Soviet cruise vessels, the cessation of cooperation in fisheries and civil aviation matters, the cancellation of scheduled official talks and the suspension of official visits.

It is also true that notwithstanding this curtailment of bilateral relations, some Australian individuals, groups and teams have visited the Soviet Union in the period since Afghanistan. In some cases they have done so to represent Australia in multilateral activities. It is to be noted that the Government's measures against the Soviet Union are directed to bilateral exchanges: generally it is not the Government's intention that current policy towards the Soviet Union be allowed to detract from Australia's reputation and standing as a participant in important multilateral cooperation. In other cases some Australians may have visited the Soviet Union privately and in spite of the Government's policy. Their actions, where they contravened bilateral policy, are to be regretted, but the choice was theirs and the Government was not prepared to stand in their way, for example, by denying passports.

The Government also imposes a number of limitations on Australia's relations with South Africa. It is not prepared to conduct a normal bilateral relationship with South Africa as long as that country continues to apply the policies of apartheid, which Australia rejects on moral, intellectual, political and strategic grounds. The limitations include the active discouragement of sporting contacts with South Africa, the strict upholding of an arms embargo against South Africa and the observance of UN resolutions which prohibit military and nuclear collaboration with South Africa. The Government does allow economic relations with South Africa to continue, but withholds avoidable official assistance to the conduct of those relations. The Government is aware that the value of Australian trade with South Africa has increased recently. The Government is also aware that South Africa has been endowed with great mineral wealth and that Western countries purchase large amounts of those minerals. The Government does not consider, however, that the extension to the non-white population of South Africa of political and social rights to which they are entitled would in any way prejudice the continuation of sales of South African minerals to Western countries. The Government also believes that South Africa has a role to play in the security of the southern African/Indian Ocean region. Its best contribution to this security would be to abandon the policy of apartheid which promotes political instability and uncertainty in the region , and provides opportunities for involvement in the region by the Soviet Union and its surrogates.

The Government will continue to oppose oppression and abuses of human rights wherever they occur, and is not prepared to seek an improvement in its relations with South Africa until that country moves to abandon the policy of apartheid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1160) Senator Jones asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, a question without notice regarding problems being experienced with the public address system in the new terminal at Coolangatta Airport. Senator Jones asked if the Minister would ensure that the fault was rectified urgently and I undertook to raise the matter with the Minister and seek early rectification of the problem.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Aviation has advised me that he is aware of the problem and of temporary measures which the airlines have taken. He also advises that the Department of Transport and Construction has undertaken a major study to ascertain the nature of the problem and to recommend corrective measures. This report is now complete and it is expected that remedial works will commence in the near future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 March 1982 (Hansard, page 1164) Senator Keeffe asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I preface it by reminding the Minister that on 18 November 1981 I raised with him the poor telephone communications between Palm Island and the mainland and Burketown and southern areas. The Minister promised to investigate the matter. Can the Minister now inform the Parliament what improvements to the telephone system have been made to these two centres?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Regarding Palm Island, Telecom has advised that although twenty-four hour access for the general community is restricted to the two public telephones, most public services (for example police, hospital, doctors) have full time access through after hours connections to Townsville.

Telecom has explained that intitial studies indicate that the cost of providing an automatic service to Palm Island would be between $300,000 and $ 500,000 depending on the extent of new cable reticulation required and the conditions under which it would be provided. Due to the many competing demands for funds it is unlikely that a higher priority can be placed on the provision of automatic service to Palm Island so that the current target is still the 1984-85 year. However, Telecom has arranged for a survey to be carried out whereby the communications needs of the island can be re-assessed. The results of this survey will be taken into account when future programmes are finalised.
The Burketown area is currently served by a manual exchange connected to the rest of the network by a single trunk circuit to Normanton.

Over the years Telecom has investigated a number of proposals to improve trunk access to Burketown and all are very costly. Upgrading the present physical route for example to provide for 3 or 12 channel working would cost about $200, 000 but would perpetuate the present maintenance problem.

Telecom also considered a proposal to provide a five stage six channel radio system between Normanton and Burketown at a cost of about $1m. This would not have been completed before 1983-84 and would only have interconnected with the circuits on the single pair of open wires between Normanton and Cloncurry.

Telecom has made firm plans to install a major microwave radio route between Cloncurry and Normanton in 1983-84-85 at a cost of $3.25m. Telecom considers that the best solution to bring improved communications to Burketown subscribers is to provide a radio system for Burketown to connect with this microwave route at a point between Normanton and Cloncurry. This will require the prior completion of the microwave system and therefore could not be completed prior to 1985-86.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1275) Senator Lajovic asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister for Education noted an item appearing in the Saturday 17 April edition of the Sydney Morning Herald under the title of 'Strings wanted on State aid' in which it is alleged that a New South Wales Australian Labor Party platform committee has recommended that all private schools receiving State aid should be made to account publicly for the way they spend the funds received from State and private sources? Can the Minister inform the Senate what provisions exist, if any, for the public schools funded by Federal funds to account for the way in which they spend their funds and whether the public is in any way informed of the way this is being done?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Direct Commonwealth grants for primary and secondary schools are conditional on education authorities' agreement to pre-determine conditions. These conditions vary according to the type of grant and between the government and non-government sectors. They are set out annually in legislation governing the grants, that is the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Acts. In summary there are restrictions on the application of funds provided for capital works in the government sector to exclude the provisions of housing for teachers or other staff in capital cities. The use of other funds is restricted to meeting recurrent expenditure at or in connection with the operation of government schools, including recurrent expenditure for specific purposes, such as the teaching of English as a Second Language, the special education of handicapped students and disadvantaged schools.

In the non-government sector, capital grants may not have the sole or principal object of providing housing for teachers or other staff nor may they provide facilities for use in relation to religious worship. General recurrent grants are paid having regard to the needs of non-systemic schools or schools within an approved system of non-government schools. Other grants to non- government schools are paid for recurrent purposes, including recurrent expenditure for specific purposes, such as the teaching of English as a Second Language, the special education of handicapped students and disadvantaged schools or for minor capital expenditure which has been approved by the Commonwealth Minister for Education.

Where grants are provided for joint programs, that is, programs in which both the government and non-government sectors participate, recipients are required to expend funds in ways which accord with the objectives of the programs.

Once grants have been accepted and applied, education authorities are required to provide the Commonwealth with evidence that the predetermined conditions have been met. For government schools and for joint programs, each State is required to provide a certificate by an authorised person that the specified conditions applying to the grants have been fulfilled, together with a list of building and equipment projects and a summary of the application of recurrent grants. The accountability requirements applying to Commonwealth grants to non- government schools are more stringent and detailed than those applying to government schools. The approved authority for each non-government school must provide a certificate by a qualified accountant to the effect that the accountant is satisfied that the agreed conditions for each grant have been fulfilled. The Minister may also require the approved authority for each non- government school to furnish additional information in respect of the school should he wish to do so.

As soon as practical after the 30 June following the year in respect of which grants were paid, the Minister for Education is required to table in each house of Parliament a report on the application of funds by both government and non- government schools. This requirement has been met in respect of each Act administered by the Commonwealth Schools Commission since its inception. Thus the application of Commonwealth funds for school level education in both the government and non-government sectors is a matter of public record.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1345) Senator MacGibbon asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Have the severe backlogs reported last year in the connection of telephones in Queensland country areas and provincial cities been overcome? Is the Minister aware that the number of unsatisfied installations in Gladstone alone was estimated to be 500? Are adequate resources being devoted to this matter so that these fast growing, highly taxed areas, such as Gladstone are not disadvantaged?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Telecom Australia has advised that the backlog in connection of telephones in Queensland country areas and provincial cities has not yet been overcome. During April the total country unsatisfied demand for service reached 15,100 of which 4,466 were deferred for 3 months or longer and 6,188 were in the process of being connected. The comparable figures for the same month in 1981 were 14, 649, 3,853 and 5,564 respectively. This increase in backlog has occurred despite the fact that 45,421 new services have been connected in the financial year to April compared with 44,649 over the same period of 1980-81.

With regard to the city of Gladstone itself, Telecom has advised that during April the unsatisfied demand for service reached 515 of which 253 were deferred for longer than 3 months and 162 were in the process of being connected. This is an improvement in the position at June 1981 when the comparable figures were 609, 252 and 175.

During 1980-81, 1,365 new services were connected in the Gladstone district, 61 per cent of these being connected within 15 days of payment of fees. The latter figure has improved to 66 per cent in April 1982. It is estimated that 1 ,650 new services will be connected in the Gladstone district in the current financial year, an increase of 21 per cent over the figure for 1980-81.

This improvement has been achieved by the injection of additional resources into the Gladstone area. Lines staff particularly have been transferred from Brisbane and interstate to assist with the abnormally high workload. Advertisements have been placed in all the major Australian newspapers seeking technical staff for Gladstone, and these have resulted in an encouraging response.

Telecom has given assurance that it is conscious of the need for special action to provide adequate communications facilities for high growth places such as Gladstone. The initiatives taken and effort expended in this direction will be continued until the backlog is reduced to a more acceptable level.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

I am aware of the importance of the large and progressive South Australian company G. H. Michell and Sons Pty Ltd, in the Australian wool industry, although I am not certain as to the precise ranking of the firm in the purchase of Australian wool. On the basis of information provided to me, I believe that wool purchases by the firm and its associated companies in 1980-81 exceeded 100 ,000 bales.
G. H. Michell and Sons has displayed most commendable enterprise and energy, both in its wool related interests and in the way in which it has diversified its activities.

The scale of the Michell operations, and the success of its enterprise, typifies Australian capability to manage commercial affairs with exceptional efficiency in competition with the best of international trading bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1447) Senator Lajovic asked Senator Messner a question, without notice, in his then capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. The question was in regard to New South Wales poultry farmers.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The hen levy forms an integral part of the present marketing arrangements for the egg industry. I would stress that these arrangements were implemented in 1965 at the request of the industry and the States to assist in stabilising egg production.

Under Commonwealth/State agreements the egg marketing boards in each State collect hen levy on behalf of the Commonwealth. The Australian Egg Board is not involved. The money collected is paid into a Trust Fund administered by the Department of Primary Industry and the bulk of it is returned to the States for use in providing assistance to the industry in that particular State.

Current arrangements involve two major elements, namely, State hen quotas, which are agreed upon by the Australian Agricultural Council, and the Commonwealth hen levy. The application of the hen levy, which, as stated above, was enacted at the specific request of the States, ensured that all producers contributed equally to the losses incurred in the disposal of surplus eggs, especially on the export market. This has helped to stabilise returns to producers, while the quotas, which are applied under State legislation, have assisted in restricting surpluses.

Dr A. Galea was arrested and jailed for several offences in relation to the arrest of Mrs Cassar by New South Wales police for unpaid fines and court costs . Dr Galea was fined $950 on 25 May 1982 in the Campbelltown, New South Wales, Court of Petty Sessions. It is understood that he has lodged an appeal in the District Court.

Mrs Cassar was convicted in a New South Wales Court in 1978 for failure to submit returns of hen numbers as required in accordance with the Regulations under the Poultry Industry Levy Collection Act 1965 and fines and court costs totalling $220 were imposed on her. The returns referred to are required to be made each fortnight to the State Egg Board in connection with payment of the hen levy.

After an appeal against her conviction was disallowed the Deputy Commonwealth Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney wrote to Mrs Cassar on several occasions seeking payment of the fines and costs involved but received no reply. A Warrant of Committal was sought from and issued by a New South Wales Court in February 1982. It was then a matter for the New South Wales police to carry out the Warrant.
Mrs Cassar was arrested only after being given every opportunity to pay the relatively small fines and costs of $220 imposed in 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1449) Senator Macklin asked Senator Messner, as Minister for Veterans' Affairs, a question without notice concerning the distribution of questionnaires to Vietnam veterans.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Messner subsequently referred the question to the Minister for Health who has provided the following information:

The only questionnaires issued by the Australian Veterans Health Studies group to elicit information have been those issued in a pilot study undertaken in the Sydney metropolitan area. There have been no other pilot studies or issues of the questionnaires referred to in any State but New South Wales. The six hundred names, randomly selected, could contain members of the State and Commonwealth Public Service. However, there were no criteria governing selection or non-selection of public servants. TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1441) Senator Jones asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Following the extension of the terms of reference of the Stewart Royal Commission into Drugs and Drug Trafficking to allow it to examine all the operations of the Nugan Hand group in any drug dealing, laundering of money and links with organisations, including the United States of America's Central Intelligence Agency, will the Minister take steps to make available the files of the Australian Federal Police which have not been made available to the Commonwealth and New South Wales task force? TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1652) Senator Lajovic asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Construction, the following question without notice:

Following the Report of the Committee of Inquiry into Housing Costs the Commonwealth moved to establish with the States the Australian Uniform Building Regulations Co-ordinating Council. TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1657), Senator Townley asked me, as Acting Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Acting Treasurer. It follows an article in today's Australian about Sir Roderick Carnegie's speech at the annual conference of the National Farmers' Federation. Does the Minister agree with Sir Roderick Carnegie's assessment that Australia is going into debt as a nation to maintain an unearned current living standard and that its international credit rating is at risk, as he intimated?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The address by Sir Roderick Carnegie to which the honourable senator referred contained, inter alia, the following arguments:
that Australia has had a deficit on the current account of its balance of payments for the last 25 years and has thus been going into debt over that period to maintain an unearned living standard;
that there would be comparatively little need to be concerned about our growing overseas debt if our borrowings were adding to productive assets. Unfortunately, this is not the case.
The following responses may be made to these arguments:

(a) It is natural for a country like Australia, with the limited domestic savings, but substantial real resources awaiting development, to have borrowed overseas to help finance that development. If such overseas borrowings had not occurred the rate of growth in Australia would have been lower and/or standards of living of Australians would have been lower. In these circumstances the continuing current account deficit has simply reflected the fact that we are drawing on overseas resources (financial and real) to supplement our own savings in developing the Australian economy.

(b) It is important that, over time, these overseas borrowings are able to be serviced out of increased productivity, including exports of goods and services made possible by the economic development of Australia. This can occur in a direct fashion as, in the past, in the case of iron ore and, more recently in cases like coal and aluminium. But even where the investment is not immediately export oriented, increased capital inflow means more capital available in Australia for all kinds of investment, including export oriented or import competing industries. The connection does not have to be a direct one. Provided the Government's macro-economic policies-fiscal, monetary and external-are soundly based, the economy will generate sufficient production and foreign exchange to service the overseas debt.
The following ratios of property income payable overseas to exports of goods and services suggests that, in fact, capital inflow has not run ahead of our ability to meet servicing obligations.
RATIO OF PROPERTY INCOME PAYABLE OVERSEAS (EXCLUDING UNDISTRIBUTED INCOME) TO EXPORTS OF GOODS AND SERVICES

(c) Of course there will be variations in these ratios from year to year. For instance, the ratios will tend to be relatively high in years when capital inflow and related servicing costs are relatively high because the subsequent increase in exports of goods and services to time lags. Then again the ratios will tend to be relatively high in years when world trade is sluggish because these tend to be years of relatively low exports.

(d) For both these reasons the ratio was high in 1980-1 (the last year for which complete data are available); it was around 10 per cent. It should be noted however that the ratio exceeded 10 per cent in nine of the last 25 years. The 1981-2 figure, when available, is again likely to be relatively high for the same reasons as in 1980-1.
I refer now to Sir Roderick Carnegie's apparent view that Australia's credit rating is at risk.

The international financial journal Institutional Investor produces a list of countries ranked in order of its assessment of credit ratings. The March 1982 list ranks Australia as number six in a list of 103 countries. Indeed, Australia has gone up two places from eighth to sixth since these ratings were published in March 1981.

Perhaps a more decisive argument is that foreign investment (excluding undistributed income) in enterprises in Australia reached $A4.8 billion in 1980 -1, and significantly more than that in 1981-2. These are record figures and would seem to suggest that there is, in fact, great confidence in Australia among overseas investors at this time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1812) I answered a question from Senator MacGibbon concerning six cattle then held at the Cocos Island Animal Quarantine Station because they had been found to have been exposed to epizootic haemorrhagic disease virus.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1767) Senator Colston asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does Telecom Australia pursue a deliberate practice of restricting the provision of public telephones in new locations? Is it a practice of Telecom to suggest that organisations should lease a red coin-operated telephone when representations are made for the provision of a public telephone in an area where a demand for such public telephones obviously exists? Has Telecom's pursuit of profits made it neglect its obligation to provide acceptable services to the community?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Telecom's policy is to provide public telephones in locations where they best serve the community and receive sufficient use to offset, to a reasonable degree, the high cost of their provision and maintenance. Telecom points out that substantial losses are incurred with the public telephone service.

It is not Telecom's practice to suggest that leased coin telephones be provided in lieu of public telephones in areas where there is a specific community need which can only be met by a public telephone installation. However, in some instances, the security of a leased coin telephone may be more beneficial to users than an unsupervised public coin telephone.

Telecom will continue to provide additional public telephones on the basis of expected revenue and community needs. Telecom has, over the past six years, carried out a public coin telephone network modernisation programme providing new kinds of public telephones. These units, with their advanced technology and improved resistance to vandalism, provide a high grade of local and STD service for public telephone users.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1828) Senator MacGibbon asked me, in a question without notice, whether family allowance is paid to mothers of children who do not reside or who have not resided in Australia, and if so, how much is paid annually.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
Family allowance may be paid for a child outside Australia where the child is temporarily abroad, or living abroad pending migration to Australia within four years.

No figures are available regarding the annual expenditure for children who are eligible for family allowance as a result of the application of these provisions. However, my department does keep records where family allowance is paid directly to an overseas address. These payments amounted to $63,000 for the financial year 1980-81.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1912) Senator Ryan asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the distribution of the Film Australia production Images of Man.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Australian Film Commission has advised that:

The 28-minute film Images of Man was distributed to 17 film libraries throughout Australia and 29 film libraries in Australian missions abroad. A German version was made and copies are available through Australian Embassies in Bonn and Vienna. The film is also available commercially in Europe through Film Australia's representatives in Britain, Guild Sound and Vision.

Prints have been sold in Australia to museums and art galleries, the Darwin Regional Office, Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Department of Aboriginal Studies of the Australian National University and education authorities in Australia and Papua New Guinea.
The film was entered in appropriate film festivals in New Zealand, Italy, Ireland, India, United States and France, and in the Sydney and Melbourne Film Festivals.
Video cassettes are available through Film Australia's London and Los Angeles Offices, and through the Canberra Office of Film Australia.

The film was offered to Australian theatrical distributors who felt it had excellent artistic merit but needed to be placed with an appropriate feature film. To date, no such feature has become available.

The Australian Broadcasting Commission and commercial television networks auditioned the film on several occasions as a single program, but were unable to place it. However, it is again with a network, together with a package of films on similar subjects dealing with the work of conservationists, rangers, mineral developers and national parks management people.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2021) Senator Walters asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the tar content of cigarettes.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The cigarette filters referred to in the honourable senator's question are by- pass filters. The first and only brand on sale so far in Australia with this type of filter is 'Barclay', which has been trial-marketed from selected outlets in Brisbane from January 1982.

At a meeting with officers of the Departments of Health and Science and Technology (Australian Government Analytical Laboratories-AGAL) on 21 April 1982, representatives of a tobacco comany informally expressed their concern that by-pass filter cigarettes yield lower tar levels under machine testing conditions than those developed in human smoking conditions, because human lips occlude the air filter outlets, thereby reducing the dilution of the smoke that is drawn through the cigarette.

It may be true that the present collaborative AGAL/industry cigarette testing method and machines-which conform to the International Standards Organisation standard-will not provide valid, comparable test results for by-pass filter cigarettes. My Department and AGAL therefore have technical aspects of the matter under review and relevant information is being obtained from the United Kingdom. The implications for tar and nicotine yield labelling of cigarette packets-to be introduced no later than August 1982 under the requirements of the Voluntary Code in Respect of CPM ('Tar') and Nicotine Labelling on Cigarette Packaging-are also under investigation.

A change to the testing method prescribed by the Code-to which all cigarette manufacturers and importers of cigarettes in Australia are signatories-would be considered on the basis of a 'universal' request from industry. I should emphasise here however, that industry has responsibility to ensure no breaches of the Voluntary Code, the operation of which will be monitored by the Government.
My Department and AGAL will continue to collaborate to ensure that labelling requirements are fulfilled on the basis of scientifically valid and comparable test results.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1982 (Hansard, 18 May 1982, page 2021) Senator Foreman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services to an article in today's Australian concerning the construction of a new national police college in Perth. Is it a fact that by choosing to build the college in Perth construction costs will be 10 times higher than they would have been for the Canberra alternative? Why has Perth been chosen as the site for such a national college, especially in view of its distance from Australia's major population centres? In view of the rather more central position of Adelaide and the depressed state of the building and construction industry in South Australia, will the Government give consideration to building the college in Adelaide?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The variation in costs referred to in the Australian of 18 May 1982 relates to two of the options for the location of the Australian Police College which have been under consideration by the Australian Police Ministers' Council. The comparison is not the difference in construction costs between the two locations but rather the difference in relocation costs on the basis of the Canberra option only involving alterations to an existing building, against the Perth option involving a new building designed specifically as a police college .

The location of common national police facilities is influenced by the Commonwealth Government's federalism policy. To date the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence has been located in Canberra and it has been agreed to locate the National Exchange of Police Information in Sydney and the National Police Research Unit in Adelaide.

As the final resolution of the siting of the College rests with the Premiers' Conference the Chairman of the Australian Police Ministers Council has advised the Premiers that the Council supports the relocation of the College in Perth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2222) Senator Coates asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, a question without notice concerning international services at Hobart Airport and supporting the expansion of the domestic terminal for this purpose rather than the construction of a separate international terminal.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

A range of options relating to the expansion of the existing domestic passenger terminal at Hobart Airport to cater for the Hobart-Christchurch services were considered by the Government and rejected in preference to the construction of a separate international terminal facility.

Advantages of a separate building include: the ready capability of expansion as Tasmania's tourist potential is progressively realised; no disruption to domestic operations; no constraints to the future orderly expansion of the domestic terminal; and it is the only option that would fully cater for security, customs, health and immigration requirements.

The decision is not affected by the recent TAA reduction of the Hobart- Christchurch services from two to one per week. This decision was based on operational and long term requirements and not on the number of services.
Consideration is being given to alternative uses for the building when it is not being utilised for international services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Central Intelligence Agency: Activities in Australia

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2382) Senator Coleman asked me, in my capacity as either Attorney-General or as Minister representing the Prime Minister, a question without notice concerning alleged activities of the Central Intelligence Agency in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The recent allegations made by Christopher Boyce-a convicted spy and bank robber-in an interview with 60 Minutes on Sunday, 23 May 1982 add little or nothing to the allegations which appeared in the media at the time of his trial in 1977. In that context I refer the honourable senator's attention to my statement of 24 May 1977 on this matter (House of Representatives Hansard pages 1695-1696). In that statement I also said that President Carter has denied that the United States Government or its representatives had been involved in improper or inappropriate activities here. The CIA recently emphatically denied that it had engaged in operations against the Australian Government and Vice- President Bush has also been reported as repeating these denials on behalf of the United States Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2494) Senator Thomas asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Recently I drew to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services the matter of stolen trucks in Australia. My information, which came from a constituent who has spent many years working in the road transport industry, is that some 160 heavy road trucks were stolen and not recovered in Australia during the last three years. Some trucks that have been recovered indicated that the trucks are changed in such a professional way as to make them virtually unrecognisable to the original owner and that they are invariably resold in a different State from that in which they were stolen. My suggestion was that this could be the subject of discussions between State and Federal Ministers responsible for police. Can the Minister tell me the outcome of those discussions?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

During March the subject of stolen trucks was brought to the attention of the Honourable R. J. Hinze, MLA, Queensland Minister for Police and then Chairman of the Australian Police Ministers' Council. Because of the number of items already on the agenda for the Council meeting on 21 May, however, Mr Hinze decided to refer the matter directly to the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI). One of the functions of the ABCI is to identify persons and practices which warrant investigation and to refer them to the relevant police commissioners for appropriate action. I understand that the appropriate action is being taken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were Commonwealth public servants working in the Northern Territory able, after a suitable qualifying period, to purchase the government house in which they were residing, prior to 1 July 1978.
(2) Has this practice ceased since 1 July 1978; if so, what is the reason behind the cessation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Following Northern Territory self-government on 1 July 1978 the Northern Territory Housing Commission assumed responsibility for general community housing and housing for employees of the Northern Territory Public Service. The Commonwealth retained a relatively small stock of staff houses which are in the main job-related and as such are required for successors in office. In these circumstances, and having regard to its changed role and presence in the Territory, the Government decided to suspend the home sales scheme pending a review of the Commonwealth's housing policy for its staff in the Territory.
Following completion recently of a review of policy by an interdepartmental committee, the Government has decided that the home sales scheme will not be reintroduced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the staff ceiling cut of 450 as recommended by the Review of Commonwealth Functions for the Department of Administrative Services be achieved by June 1982, as intended; if not, when will it be achieved, if at all.
(2) What procedure for severence or redeployment will apply for Departmental employees.
(3) What changes or reduction in standards of services have resulted or are expected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Of the reduction of 450 full time staff recommended by the Review of Commonwealth Functions 260 will be achieved by 30 June 1982. The further reduction of 190 will be achieved progressively between July 1982 and December 1982.

(2) The administrative processes established under the Commonwealth Employees ( Redeployment and Retirement) Act and associated arbitral determinations provide the groundwork which the Department will use for departmental employees who become surplus to the requirements as a result of the implementation of the Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions.

(3) No changes in the nature of services provided have resulted, or are expected. Where work is contracted to the private sector, the contract conditions aim at ensuring that standards of service are maintained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What functions of the Department under the Minister's supervision are now performed on a regular basis by private contractors and have been taken over from Commonwealth employees since:
(a) the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions;
(b) January 1981;
(c) January 1980; and
(d) January 1979.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Administrative Services for many years has made use of private contractors to supplement the work of its own staff, either in peak workload situations or where special expertise is required. Within some functions, where the use of contractors has been found to be more effective, the extent of contracting has been increased, for example cleaning, watching, quick printing and non-departmental food and other services formerly operated by the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd.

As a result, some work within several functions is now performed on a regular basis by private contractors. However, until the Review of Commonwealth Functions decision to contract out all of the remaining cleaning and watching operations of the Department and examine the scope for further major transfers, there has been no attempt to transfer whole functions.
Functions now performed on a regular or ad hoc basis by private contractors since the dates mentioned by the honourable senator are:

(a) A proportion of grounds maintenance and flag raising. The remaining cleaning and watching operations are expected to be transferred on or shortly after 1 July 1982. There will be a significant increase in the extent of survey work undertaken by private contractors immediately funds can be provided.
(b) A proportion of quick printing, cleaning, watching, foyer and lift attendants.
(c) Nil.
(d) A proportion of janitorial services, plant servicing and non-departmental food and other services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 9 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Industrial Training Commission for Victoria recently release figures that show a downturn in the indenture of first year apprentices for 1981 .

(2) Do those figures show that Victoria apprentices indentured in 1981 totalled only 10,366 compared with 11,506 in 1980; if so, what action is being taken by the Government in the area of technical training.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The figures have been released and will be published later in 1982.

(2) Yes. Although the 1980-81 figure was down on 1979-80 it was the fifth successive year that it had exceeded 10,000. This constant high level of new apprentices commencing training resulted in a record total of 39,890 apprentices in training in Victoria at 30 June 1981.

In addition, the national intake reached new record levels in each of the past two years. The intake for the financial year 1979-80 was 46,395-over 3,800 more than in 1978-79. The intake for 1980-81 was 48,665-an increase of more than 2, 200. Most of this growth occurred in the critical metal, electrical and building trades groups.
Similarly, the number of apprentices in training nationally at 30 June 1981 was a record 142,523.

The Government has provided significant support to employers for the training of apprentices under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full time Training ( CRAFT) scheme with a view to achieving an increase in the quantity and quality of trade training.
Estimated expenditure for all CRAFT incentives for 1981-82 is $72m and will be paid in respect of some 101,000 apprentices.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the estimated financial impact of the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1981 for:
(a) the balance of the financial year 1981-82; and
(b) the next and succeeding two financial years, and what is;
(i) the estimated costs to government, if any;
(ii) the estimated revenue of governments, if any;
(iii) the estimated savings of governments, if any;
(iv) the estimated financial burden, if any, which will be imposed on industry or other sections of the community; and
(v) the estimated savings, if any, which will be of benefit to industry or other sections of the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) (i-v) Nil. Legislation to establish a PVR scheme introduced but not yet debated by the Senate.

(b) (i) and (ii) The establishment of a PVR scheme will not have a particularly significant financial impact. It is intended that ultimately income from fees will meet the cost of administering the scheme. In the meantime the Commonwealth will accept responsibility for funding which is estimated initially to be $100, 000 per year.
(iii) Nil.
(iv) Registration fees payable by plant breeders have not yet been set. It is expected that they will be in line with comparable fees overseas, which are mostly less than $1,000 per right.
Farmers and gardeners may find the price of seed of protected varieties higher, but could be expected to pay the higher prices only if expected higher returns made it worth their while.

(v) Improved productivity is expected but accurate estimation is not possible. In New Zealand, where PVR was introduced in 1974, the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research estimates that the national benefit of the new varieties released during the last five years is (NZ) $10m annually.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 24 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why does the Government permit holders of import quotas to sell these on the open market.
(2) Does the current system tend to create monopolies of quota holders.
(3) Does the current system encourage high prices for quotas and thus higher priced goods to the consumer.

(4) Will the Government consider introducing a system whereby quotas will lapse if they are not used either by permanent quota holders or tenderers, and the quotas sold by tender on the open market by the Government to people or companies who will use the quotas direct.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is Government policy to introduce as much flexibility as is practicable into any system of Government regulation. This is the case with the transfer provisions of import quotas. Allowing quotas to be transferable provides an avenue for new-importers to enter the market and enables individual quota holders to expand or contract their quota holdings on the basis of their commercial judgements made in the light of market trends.

(2) While some importers hold considerably more quota than others this often reflects past import patterns or company takeovers. There is no evidence to suggest that the methods used in quota allocation lead to monopolies of quota holders. It also needs to be remembered that imports entering under quota must compete with the products of the local industry.

(3) Prices paid for quota reflect the purchaser's assessment of market conditions and prospects, including competitiveness against local production, rather than an ability to increase prices per se. Moreover, where quotas are sold at tender, the premiums paid and the tariff duty applied have the effect of transferring to the Government, and hence the community at large, some of the benefits which might otherwise accrue to quota holders.

(4) The Government's policy is to encourage quotas to be fully utilised and this was one of the main reasons why quota transfer provisions were introduced. Where a quota is purchased at tender, as in the case of certain textile, clothing and footwear items, securities lodged by quota holders are forfeited if quotas are not utilised. In the case of passenger motor vehicles, penalties apply if quotas are under-utilised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any official estimate of how much it would cost (in 1982 dollars) to overcome problems of land degradation in Australia.
(2) Is land degradation, as it affects agricultural production, worsening.
(3) In any allocation of funds on a national basis, which (a) States; and (b) regions would have the ten highest priority places.
(4) Is any part of Australia primary industry now: (a) losing production; or (b ) likely to lose production because of land degradation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 'The Commonwealth and State Government Collaborative Soil Conservation Study 1975-77', released in April 1978, estimated the cost of treating and controlling land degradation at $675m in 1975 prices.

(2) The 1975-77 Collaborative Study found that about half of the agricultural and pastoral land in Australia required some form of treatment. No comparative and comprehensive study has since been made.
(3) Soil conservation is a responsibility of the States and the allocation of priorities is a matter for the States.

(4) While farm management and soil conservation practices may minimise land degradation, it needs to be recognised that agricultural development can involve an acceleration of natural land degradation. Land degradation would, of itself, lead to reduced production in most circumstances.

Rural development in Australia has resulted in a steady significant growth in total production and, with due attention to soil protection, this production can be maintained. However, the Collaborative Study indicates that, across the rural production areas of Australia, degradation ranges from minimal, where soil protection measures are highly effective, to the point where production is impossible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 22 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Transport and Construction aware of the call made by the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, Mr Katter, for the Federal Government to introduce legislation to implement random breath testing throughout Australia.
(2) Does the responsibility for road laws, including matters such as random breath testing, lie exclusively with the States.
(3) Can the Minister for Transport and Construction give an unqualified assurance that the Government will not interfere in matters which are the sole responsibility of the States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that it has never been Mr Katter's intention to imply that the Federal Government should legislate to introduce random breath testing throughout Australia. Mr Katter has long been a supporter of random breath testing and, more recently, has urged those States that have not yet implemented the measure to consider its introduction at least on a trial basis.

(2) Prime responsibility for road safety regulation rests with the States and Territories. The Commonwealth is, however, concerned with road safety because of the national economic and social issues involved and because of its role in relation to the roads infrastructure. The Commonwealth's highest priority is to co-ordinate road safety efforts on a national basis, in co-operation with the States and Territories, through the Australian Transport Advisory Council.

(3) Road safety issues are not the preserve of any one level of government. All governments have the right, perhaps the duty, to express a view or to urge a course of action relating to road safety, irrespective of which level of government may have the responsibility for making laws concerning the matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 28 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What staff retrenchments have there been in Telecom Australia Exchanges in the Perth metropolitan area since 21 October 1981.
(2) What was the establishment of telephone operators in the Perth metropolitan area as at 1 October 1981, and what is the current number of staff employed.
(3) What extension in level of overtime payments to such staff has been made since 1 October 1981.
(4) What is the standard time in which calls should be answered by operators, and has this standard been maintained.
(5) What alterations to the service have been made with respect to international calls, and what complaints have there been relating to the international call service.
(6) What directions have been given by Government with respect to Telecom staff ceilings in the State of Western Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from information furnished by the Australian Telecom- munications Commission and the Department:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There have been no staff retrenchments in Perth exchanges.
(2) (a) Establishment as at 1 October 1981 was 429 (72 supervisors, 357 telephonists).
(b) The current number of telephonist staff is 418 (86 supervisors, 332 telephonists).
(3) From the beginning of this financial year to 30 September 1981, 1617 hours overtime were worked by telephonist staff. From 1 October 1981 to 7 May 1982, 308 hours have been worked.

(4) Service to customers is currently measured against a standard requiring operators to answer 80 per cent of calls to International, National and Directory Assistance within 20 seconds and 90 per cent of calls to Service Assistance within 20 seconds.

Difficulties have been experienced on occasions in meeting these standards largely due to the diversion of staff to training for the recently introduced new technology exchanges and peak loads related to occasions such as Mother's Day and the visits of United States Navy Personnel to Perth.

(5) The International Manual Service is provided by new technology facilities at the Wellington Exchange in Perth, enabling operators to set up calls in less time. However, customers have had to become accustomed to some time constraints when call details (such as pricing) are requested at the end of a call. In the 12 month period ending 30 April some 606,000 calls were handled by the International Exchange. Only four written complaints were received in this period.

(6) None. As in the case of Departments, the Government has set only an overall staff ceiling for Telecom. The Commission itself decides the staff adjustments necessary within each State administration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What tests are applied to ensure that medical dressings are free from contamination before they are marketed in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Most consignments of surgical dressings imported into Australia, since interim controls were introduced late last year, have been required to be tested for microbiological contamination. The exception is goods which are supplied unsterilized to some hospitals, since these hospitals sterilize the dressings prior to their medical use-a long-accepted practice in the trade.

The testing of imported dressings which are required to be sterile must comply with 'Guidelines on tests for sterility' laid down in an Appendix to the Australian Code of Good Manufacturing Practice for Therapeutic Goods. If a satisfactory outcome is not achieved, goods must be resterilized then retested.

Imported dressings which are not required to be sterile must be tested in three different media to detect Clostridia species, gram negative organisms and staphylococci respectively. Dressings failing tests must be decontaminated and retested.
Discussions are in progress with industry to develop permanent control mechanisms.

Although goods manufactured in Australia are not subject to import controls, it is understood that local manufacturers are voluntarily carrying out such testing before release of their goods for sale.
The National Biological Standards Laboratory is continuing to test goods as is considered to be necessary.
I have arranged for a copy of the Guidelines (referred to above) to be forwarded to the honourable senator for his information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question, upon notice, on 18 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: When is it likely that Telecom Australia will install a telephone call charge system which will itemise accounts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from information furnished by the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator will be aware no doubt that Telecom is progressively introducing a system known as call charge recording (CCR) for international calls, which will enable subscribers to be given details of ISD calls made from their services. Already, ISD/CCR has been provided on about 1.2 million services . Plans have also been announced for the provision of a CCR system for STD calls . This is a major undertaking and it is proposed that this service be offered on an optional basis. It is expected to be made available progressively from metropolitan exchanges commencing in 1984-85 and extended to some country areas from 1986.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:
