QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 18 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the advertisement on page 12 of the journal, Livestock and Grain Producer May 1982, inserted by Farmers and Graziers Co-operative Ltd, and specifically to a mention of a liquid arsenic dip in that advertisement.
(2) When was liquid arsenic registered for use for this purpose, are any restrictions attendant upon this registration and if so, what are the details.
(3) What quantities of this preparation have been used in Australia, in which States, in each year from 1965-66 to the date of preparation of the answer to this question.

(4) What role did the Department of Primary Industry play in the registration of this dip and what role does the Department play on (a) advising primary producers about the potential toxic hazards from the use of this dip; and (b) monitoring the use of this dip to ensure the safety precautions are rigidly observed.
(5) Is this product (a) manufactured in Australia; and/or (b) imported, and what companies have been involved in marketing it, during the period referred to in part 3 of this question.

(6) Is arsenic registered for other agricultural purposes, and/or domestic use in Australia, and if so, what (a) uses; (b) restrictions are attendant on those registrations; (c) companies produce products for these purposes; (d) are the trade names of those products; and (e) Federal and/or State programs are in existence for monitoring the safe use of these products.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) It is difficult to determine the history of arsenic dipping in Australia with great accuracy. It is known that dips based on sodium arsenite have been used in Queensland for control of cattle tick from about the turn of the century . Initially these were prepared by the cattlemen themselves, at first it seems on their own initiative, but later guided by recipes published by the State Department of Primary Industries. Proprietary dips began to apppear during the 30s and records show that 43 concentrates were registered for use on cattle in 1938. Forty of these were liquid arsenic dipping concentrates. Records prior to 1938 are no longer available .

Report No. 1 of the Joint Blowfly Committee was published in 1933 and gave a recipe for home-made arsenical jetting fluid. It suggested that one of the proprietary arsenical sheep dips could be used as an alternative. This shows that proprietary arsenical sheep dips were marketed prior to the creation of registration authorities.

The New South Wales Agricultural Gazette contained recipes for home-made calcium arsenite and sodium arsenite jetting mixtures as recently as 1947. Home- made jetting fluids were recommended by the Department of Agriculture on the grounds of economy.

When the New South Wales Stock Medicines Board was created in 1940 arsenic sheep dips were by far the most popular products for control of lice on sheep. Unfortunately, the early records of the Board are not readily available.

It is safe to assume that existing arsenical sheep dips were registered as the various stock medicines boards were established. That was 1933 in Queensland, 1938 in Victoria and Tasmania, 1940 in New South Wales and South Australia, and 1953 in Western Australia.

Sheep dips and all other stock medicines have to be registered under the relevant legislation in each State where they are offered for sale. Registration is a complex process in which the efficacy and safety are evaluated, the claims and directions are judged and appropriate labelling is laid down. Registrations have to be renewed either annually or every three years, depending on the State.

(3) There are no official statistics from which to determine the quantities of liquid arsenic sheep dips used in Australia. Australian Bureau of Statistics have published information which shows that factory door value of arsenical sheep and cattle dips (which include liquid arsenic dips) produced in Australia ranged from $1,391,000 in 1963 to $2,045,000 in 1978 (the latest figures available). Unofficial estimates indicate that much less than 10 per cent of the sheep population would be treated in liquid arsenical dip.

(4) Registration of agricultural chemicals and veterinary drugs is a legislative responsibility of State governments. The Department of Primary Industry has no statutory authority in this area. However, since 1967 the Department has been contributing in a co-ordinating capacity by virtue of its participation in the Technical Committee on Veterinary Drugs, a subsidiary of the Australian Agricultural Council. This has not called for any great input into the regulatory control of arsenical dips or other products registered and in use prior to 1967.

The Department of Primary Industry does not advise primary producers about potential toxic hazards from dipping nor does it monitor dips. Contact with individual farmers and provision of extension and other services at farm level is a State function.
(5) Liquid arsenical sheep dips are formulated in Australia from ingredients which are largely imported.

A variety of companies have marketed liquid arsenical sheep dips over the past 15-20 years but currently only Merck Sharpe and Dohme, Robert Young and Company and Western Stock Development Company market liquid arsenic dips.
(6) Apart from liquid and powder arsenic sheep dips and one or two liquid arsenic cattle dips there are a number of other arsenic products registered as agricultural chemicals:

(a) Lead arsenate is registered as an insecticide. Sodium arsenite, arsenic pentoxide, arsenic trioxide and DSMA (organic) are registered as herbicides. Copper, chrome, arsenic mixtures are registered as fungicides for timber preservation. Sodium arsenite is registered as a skin and hide preservative.
(b) All such products for use in agriculture must comply with the requirements of State Poisons Acts, which specify the labelling and packaging appropriate to the hazard involved.

(c) Roche Maag Limited, Ramsay and Treganowan Ltd, Kendon Chemical and Mfg Co. Pty Ltd, and Koppers Australia Pty are some of the companies producing arsenical products other than sheep and cattle dips.

(d) R&T Arsenate of Lead Power Insecticide, Kendon Arsenate of Lead Insecticide , Lane Arzeen Herbicide, Lane Camellia Weed Killer (Arsenical), Lane Hide and Skin Preservative, Tanalith CP Wood Preservative Paste and Tanalith AG Wood Preservative Paste
are some of the trade names of arsenical products other than sheep and cattle dips.

(e) The ultimate responsibility for monitoring safe use of agricultural chemicals rests with State health and agricultural authorities. Through the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Australian Agricultural Council and a number of their subsidiary committees however, the Commonwealth is enabled to co-ordinate the State activities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 18 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Primary Industry received any representations from (a) the Australian Chemical Industry Council; (b) any other organisations; or (c) any individuals, regarding the need for uniform national legislation to control the importation, manufacture, distribution, transport, use, and disposal of agricultural chemicals; if so, how many representations has the Minister received, and when.
(2) Did any of these representations refer to the need for national uniform labelling requirements, for agricultural chemical products.
(3) Has the Australian Agricultural Council (AAC) considered any proposals for this purpose; if so, (a) when; and (b) what was the outcome.
(4) Will the proposals be placed before the AAC; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no record or recollection of any representation from the Australian Chemical Industry Council on these matters.

(b) Representations were received by Mr Adermann, the then Minister for Primary Industry, from the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association (AVCA) in November 1964 requesting consideration by Standing Committee on Agriculture of procedures to harmonise State legislation under which agricultural chemicals are registered and regulated. This single representation initiated continuing negotiations subsequently carried out at Departmental level.
(c) There is no record of representations about these matters by individuals.

(2) The basic discussions and subsequent submission from AVCA paid special attention to the need for uniform labelling of agricultural chemical products and the desirability of standardising such labelling to the maximum degree possible.

(3) The issues raised by AVCA were considered by Standing Committee on Agriculture in February 1965, July 1965 and February 1966. They were considered by Australian Agricultural Council in February 1966.

(b) The outcome of Australian Agricultural Council's deliberations was the establishment in 1967 of a section within the Department of Primary Industry charged with the responsibility of co-ordinating the many diverse and complex features of agricultural chemical usage in Australia. The Technical Committee on Agricultural Chemicals and the Technical Committee on Veterinary Drugs have been established to evaluate new products and to make recommendations to State registration authorities.
(4) There does not seem to be any need for review of present arrangements at this time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that, although there has been no announced decision or official recommendation for decision by the Reagan Administration in relation to using nuclear waste from civilian reactors as fuel for nuclear weapons, the idea has been widely canvassed in the Reagan Administration.

(2) Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs confirm that United States Secretary of Energy, James Edwards, believes the use of reprocessed civilian reactor waste as fuel for nuclear weapons is unquestionably a good way to proceed, as evidenced in a press briefing he gave in Washington on 8 October 1981.

(3) Can the Minister confirm that on every occasion the United States Congress has debated the use of civilian reactor waste for weapons, Administration officials have testified against the proposals because of the limitations they would impose on United States Defence policy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The concept that plutonium separated from spent fuel from civilian nuclear reactors might be used for nuclear weapons has been identified within the United States Administration as only one of a number of possibilities for overcoming a potential shortfall later this decade of plutonium for the United States nuclear weapons program.

On 8 April 1982, in response to an Australian approach on this matter, the United States advised that it is the United States Department of Energy's policy to meet the military authorities' special nuclear materials requirements through the use of dedicated government production facilities-not by extracting fissile products from the civil fuel cycle.

The United States reply continued that, for the future, the United States Government has no plans to employ material generated in the civil nuclear sector in the United States military program. Given the importance of maintaining a clear distinction between the peaceful and the military uses of nuclear energy, as well as the serious domestic and non-proliferation implications of such a step, the United States Government would consider such an action only if absolutely essential for national security. Moreover, such a measure would have to be approached at the highest levels of the government, and the views of Congress would be sought and carefully weighted in the decision-making process. The United States response also confirmed that the agreement between Australia and the United States concerning peaceful uses of nuclear energy clearly and specifically limits the use of Australia-origin material to peaceful, non- explosive uses.

(2) See the text of the extract from the press briefing given on 8 October 1981 by the United States Secretary of Energy, Dr James Edwards, quoted in the paper incorporated in Hansard by the Minister for National Development and Energy on 28 April 1982 (Senate Hansard, pp. 1580-2).

(3) No United States Administration official has given Congressional testimony in favour of the idea of using civil spent fuel for nuclear weapons purposes. Some officials have, however, testified against specific Congressional proposals to outlaw the use of civil spent fuel for weapons purposes, but such testimony was based on the general argument against limiting the future freedom of action of the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 27 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has employment in Australian motion picture film laboratories deteriorated by 28 per cent over the last six years.

(4) Does this significantly disadvantage Australian motion picture film laboratories.
(5) What regulative measures could the Government bring in to relieve this situation.
(6) Will the Minister for Industry and Commerce consider taking action to ensure a fair share of the film print market for Australian motion picture film laboratories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Construction, upon notice, on 27 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have major changes been made to the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory building without reference to the Parliamentary Public Works Committee.
(2) Has the size of the workshop area been reduced without reference to the Public Works Committee or the client, CSIRO.
(3) Has the administrative office area been significantly reduced without reference to the Public Works Committee.
(4) Has one of the seven floors been effectively eliminated without reference to the PWC.
(5) Can the Minister guarantee that the facility will not be officially handed over to the CSIRO before completion and commissioning.
(6) Does the Minister agree that the handover will not occur before 1984.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works (PWC) examined the project in September 1974. In April 1978 the Committee was advised of, and concurred with, significant design changes which were subsequently implemented and which resulted in cost savings in the order of $14m. Design and construction activities are being overlapped and routine design refinements which do not affect the nature, scope or functions of the laboratory are incorporated where savings or more efficient performance can be achieved. Design refinements of this type are not normally referred to the PWC after construction has commenced.

(2) No change has been made to the size of the workshop. The associated machine hall has been reduced in length by one bay following detailed sizing of equipment to be accommodated. All such design decisions are taken in consultation with, and the concurrence of, CSIRO.
(3) During the development of design detail and with the agreement of CSIRO, economies were achieved by reducing the length of the administration and scientific support building by one bay.

(4) A plant room floor initially allocated to house ducts and air filters has been deleted with the agreement of CSIRO and these services have been accommodated in other upper level mechanical plant rooms. Savings in the order of $4m were achieved.

(5) Both the Department of Transport and Construction and CSIRO participate and co-operate in the design, construction, testing and commissioning phases of the project. The timing of handover on completion of commissioning will be jointly agreed between the Department and CSIRO.
(6) The laboratory is expected to be completed and the services commissioned about March 1983, one year in advance of the original program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 27 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will commercial user companies of the Australian satellite be eligible to become shareholders in the satellite; if so, what precautions will be taken to prevent conflict of interest between companies as users and companies as shareholders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: AUSSAT Pty Ltd is to be converted to a public listed company with up to 49 per cent of its shares being held by the private sector. No decision has yet been made on whether restrictions will be imposed on shareholding.
Telecom Australia: Viewdata System

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1362) Senator Button asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister to the statement made on Friday last by the Minister for Communications in which he directed that Telecom Australia was not to proceed with the development of a viewdata system. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether it is correct that of all the countries which have now introduced viewdata systems, Australia is the first in which the system will be provided by private enterprise and not by the common telecommunications carrier of the nation concerned? Is it not a fact that Australia will be the first country in which the technical equipment will be provided by one or two sources and the information to be displayed on the system will be provided by the same sources? In other words, is it not a fact that in all other countries there is separation of the equipment itself from the sources of information? As the Minister has said in his statement that the decision was made to help Telecom with its cash flow problems, can he give the Senate the total projected cost to Telecom of viewdata and at the same time the annual capital investment figure by Telecom?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Videotex systems are provided by both private enterprise, and Government telecommunications carriers in overseas countries. My Department does not have access to detailed information as to ownership of the component parts but there would appear to be no particular pattern, or trend, which suggests that the technical equipment component should be separated from the sources of information.
The capital cost to Telecom of the videotex proposal submitted in 1980 was $3, 878,300. Telecom's capital investment program in 1981-82 is $1285m.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1811) Senator Thomas asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: It has been brought to my notice that procedures to react to the dumping of manufactured goods in Australia are so complicated that nine months or even twelve months can elapse between when a complaint is received and when action can be taken. This must be of considerable concern to some local manufacturers. Will the Government investigate ways of streamlining procedures even to the extent, which I believe to be possible, of establishing a system which can stop goods entering this country even if there is a chance at all of their contravening anti-dumping laws?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Australia's anti-dumping legislation accords with the principles and practices for anti-dumping action that have been agreed in the GATT. Australia is currently a member of the GATT Anti-Dumping Code and has announced its intention to accede to the revised GATT Code which arose from the Multilateral Trade Negotiations. The codes are designed to prevent anti-dumping practices forming an unjustifiable barrier to trade and ensure the effective and equitable resolution of dumping disputes.

The Department maintains offices in London, New York, Tokyo, Auckland and Hong Kong. Their major role is to assist in anti-dumping investigations by carrying out the essential task of ascertaining normal values in the country of export, whether by suitably adjusted open market price or by cost of production. Their location in the major centres of trade to Australia is designed to speed up enquiries by carrying out investigations of overseas exporters in relation to the price in the country of export. The location of the offices in the major centres of trade to Australia is of considerable benefit in obtaining such information quickly.

The general downturn in the world economy has contributed to an increase in dumping complaints over recent months. Such downturns are usually characterised by very competitive international marketing, including the practice of dumping, as overseas producers find it difficult to maintain traditional market shares and consequently redirect their activities to newer markets.

The Department has recently allocated 5 extra staff to the dumping area, imposed target date discipline on all new cases and extended the time taken for the holding of cash securities to 120 days. These actions should ensure that Australian industry will obtain speedy coverage under the anti-dumping legislation. In addition information seminars on dumping legislation and procedures are being held so that the commercial community is made fully aware of what protective measures are available against dumped imports.

In the past there have been occasions when dumping investigations were delayed due to workload peaks or when technical difficulties emerged in borderline cases. In general however they took much less than the nine to twelve months suggested.

However, where sufficient justification in the way of dumping and injury is evident, local industry receives immediate relief by the imposition of cash securities on imports of the suspected dumped goods until the investigation is completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1982 (Hansard, page 700) Senator Button asked the then Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to reports of long delays in Customs clearance at Sydney Airport and minimal checks for prohibited imports due to Government imposed staff ceilings? Is it true that some Customs officers are working up to 16 hours a day for six days a week and are earning $1000 a week including overtime payments? Is it also a fact that the present staff ceiling of 123 officers was established eight years ago and that it is estimated that at least twice as many people would be needed to handle traffic at the airport? I might say that I have seen examples of this with women accompanied by up to three young children waiting for three and a half hours to get through Customs. Is this another example of inefficiency because of the imposition of arbitrary staff ceilings without examining the particular functions to be performed?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is a fact that delays do occur during Immigration and Customs clearance. Within the restraints upon manpower resources, staff rosters must be designed with a view to minimising waste during periods of minimal activity but also applying maximum effort in times of peak traffic. The situation is exacerbated when workload peaks are further extended by factors such as the arrival of aircraft off-schedule which are outside the control of the Customs.

Whilst it is true that some officers have worked 16 hour days on occasions when they have voluntarily changed shifts with other officers and thereby performed a double shift, no recorded instance has been found of any officer working 16 hours a day for 6 days. Also, there is no recorded instance of an officer consistently earning in excess of $1000 per week.

There were, however, four cases of significant earnings by Preventive Officers at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport during the last Christmas period when other officers were on leave and when the officers involved were paid double time for extensive overtime worked on public holidays and rostered days off.

Eight years ago, there were 117 Customs Preventive staff at Sydney (Kingsford- Smith) Airport. Since May 1981 there have been 120. Some minor variations at different ranks have occurred within that total. However, selective examination techniques have been developed to cater for increased passenger traffic.

It is not accepted that only minimal checks are carried out. Every effort is made to utilise available Customs staff resources to the best advantage whilst ensuring that essential controls are maintained. Further, the Department is in the process of restructuring the Australian Customs Service with a view to increasing the skills of its officers and obtaining more flexible use of staff resources to respond to changing priorities based on risk assessment.

The need to maintain these Customs controls is balanced by the desire to facilitate the movement of passengers through airport terminals. There exists within the present processing procedures a system to assist the early clearance of the elderly, the infirm and passengers with young children. These procedures rely on airline personnel, however, to identify and bring such instances to the notice of the Customs supervisor.

The passenger processing system is currently the subject of a comprehensive joint review by the Department of Industry and Commerce and other affected Departments. As an example of this review a trial has already been undertaken at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) and Brisbane airports to stream Australian and New Zealand passport holders away from other passengers arriving at the Primary Immigration and Customs clearance barrier.
Other methods of speeding up passenger clearance procedures are continually being explored.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 March 1982 (Hansard, page 861) Senator Mason asked me a question without notice seeking information on conditional approval for the development of the Jabiluka uranium deposit.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Mason stated that the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, had said in regard to Jabiluka that although the minimum requirement of 75 per cent of Australian equity and control had not yet been met, that condition would be satisfied before commercial production began, and he sought further information on how this could be achieved and on current equity arrangements. He also sought an assurance that production at Jabiluka would not begin until satisfactory arrangements had been agreed to by the Northern Land Council.

I refer Senator Mason to the Minister for Trade and Resources' statement of 16 March on the Jabiluka uranium project. He will note that the Minister in fact said that the Treasurer had approved the foreign investment arrangements for the Jabiluka project subject to a number of conditions accepted by the project partners which will ensure that the Government's policy of a minimum of 75 per cent Australian equity and Australian control in new uranium projects will be met by the time commercial production commences.

The arrangements for the development of the Jabiluka uranium project were examined by the Foreign Investment Review Board in August last year. As a result of this examination the Government decided to give foreign investment approval for the project on the basis of undertakings by the participants that the project will be 75 per cent Australian owned and Australian controlled by the time production commences.

At present, Jabiluka is 65 per cent owned by Pancontinental Mining Limited, an Australian controlled public company, and 35 per cent owned by Getty Oil Development Company Limited of the United States. Pancontinental operates and controls the project. Accordingly, the project already satisfied the Government 's policy requirement that new uranium projects be Australian controlled.

However, in order to satisfy the Government's Australian equity guidelines, Getty Oil is required to divest 10 per cent of its equity in the project to Australians. It has given an unequivocal undertaking to the Government that it will do so as soon as possible and, at the latest, before production from the mine begins. Regular discussions are being held with the Foreign Investment Review Board to ensure that satisfactory progress is made in this regard.

In relation to arrangements with the Northern Land Council, the Minister for Trade and Resources' statement of 16 March 1982 indicated that approval of the project was conditional upon the project partners concluding an agreement with the Northern Land Council on the terms and conditions under which development might proceed. Agreement between the parties was reached on 29 June, and a formal agreement is being prepared for consideration by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in accordance with the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April (Hansard, page 1352) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Is there any substance in allegations that work that could be performed at the Launceston Railway Workshops by the Australian National Railways Commission is being transferred interstate?
(2) Are Tasmanian employees of ANR being overlooked in promotional advances in Tasmania in favour of staff from South Australia?
The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:
(1) There is no substance in these allegations. The Launceston Railway Workshops are fully committed to maintenance and conversion work.
(2) No. All employees of the Commission are treated equally with regard to promotional opportunities within the Commission irrespective of their location.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1442) Senator Jessop asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer to a recent article in the Adelaide Advertiser which indicated that Adelaide could run out of vacant top quality office space in major city buildings by the end of the year. Is the Minister aware that it was also suggested that the shortage of accommodation will result in rapidly increased rentals? In light of this, can the Minister inform the Senate, firstly, of the amount of floor space occupied by Federal Government departments and instrumentalities in Adelaide? Secondly, can he inform the Senate of the annual rental bill for this accommodation? I would also appreciate it if he could tell me when the rental for such accommodation is due for review. In light of the acute shortage of office space in Adelaide, will the Government re-examine the decision with respect to the construction of a Commonwealth office block in Adelaide, thereby enabling accommodation to be more readily available and also providing a much needed boost to the construction industry in South Australia?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am advised that in 1981 there was a record supply of new office space in Adelaide Central Business District and although absorption of this space was in excess of previous years there was a carryover of office space in 1982.

I am also advised that although the amount of new top quality office space is considered to be limited at the present time, this does not reflect the overall office accommodation situation in Adelaide. There is currently a significant surplus of office space in Adelaide and major refurbishments of several buildings are scheduled for completion later this year.

Commonwealth departments and authorities, excluding those exempt from the Lands Acquisition Act, occupy a combination of Commonwealth-owned and leased accommodation in Adelaide and its suburbs. The breakup between owned and leased accommodation and the gross annual rental of the leased accommodation is set out below:

With reference to rental reviews, these vary between leases. In general the rentals for the various leases included in the foregoing table will fall due for review between now and the end of 1984.

The decision by the Government to defer the construction of a Commonwealth Office Block in Adelaide was taken as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions and with regard to the total capital works commitment throughout Australia. The aim of the Government to establish a Commonwealth Centre in Adelaide remains. However, it should be noted that not all of the Commonwealth employees occupying the accommodation included in the above table would be moved to the proposed Commonwealth Centre.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1660) Senator Button asked me, as the Minister representing the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in the Senate, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question refers to a statement made by the Minister in the Senate last night that on 22 April the former Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, paid duty on a television set which he brought into Australia in October last year. I ask the Minister: Is it not a fact that duty and penalty under the Customs Act and Regulations are payable within 24 hours of the transhipment through the point of entry of the goods in question? Is it not the normal procedure that if such duty and penalty are not paid within 24 hours the person is proceeded against by way of summons? Would the Minister advise the Senate whether there are any exceptions to that procedure provided by the Act and Regulations.
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
No. It is not a fact that duty and penalty under the Customs Act and Regulations are payable within 24 hours of delivery of the goods for home consumption.
It is not a fact that normal procedures are that, if such duty and penalty are not paid within 24 hours, the person is proceeded against by way of summons.

The only provisions relating to payment of duty and penalty in combination with one another are those contained in section 209 of the Customs Act. Where pursuant to those provisions goods have been impounded and the requisite notice given, the person has 21 days within which to pay the duty and penalty.

If in those circumstances, duty and penalty are not paid within the prescribed time, the impounded goods are deemed to have been seized and forfeited to the Crown. Where goods are so deemed to have been seized, it would not be usual to institute prosecution proceedings.
Section 209 has no application where goods on which duty is payable have been delivered without duty having been paid.

Mr MacKellar tendered to the Department an amount calculated on the basis of the provisions in Section 209. This money has been accepted by the Department, and the payment has been treated as resolving the matter finally, on the advice of the Attorney-General's Department that this course of action was appropriate .

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Minister for Communications: Use of VIP Aircraft

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1768) Senator Jones asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the Minister for Communications asked for a VIP aircraft to fly him from Tamworth to Canberra yesterday morning and that the aircraft developed a malfunction at Tamworth? Did a second VIP aircraft that was sent to Tamworth with a maintenance crew then fly the Minister back to Canberra? It is also a fact that two commercial flights were available from Tamworth at the time of the VIP incidents?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 3 May 1982, a RAAF Mystere 20 aircraft, en route to Canberra, with the Minister for Communications on board, developed a hydraulic malfunction during take-off at Tamworth. The take-off was aborted safely, without incident, and the aircraft returned to the airport terminal.

In accordance with the normal procedures for unserviceable RAAF aircraft, the captain of the Mystere requested technical personnel assistance from 34 Squadron, Canberra. As the most expeditious means of providing the assistance, a second RAAF Mystere was asked to fly the maintenance personnel to Tamworth. This aircraft arrived at Tamworth two hours after the initial incident.
The maintenance personnel remained at Tamworth to repair the unserviceable aircraft, while the second Mystere returned to Canberra with the Minister for Communications on board.

The first available flight out of Tamworth that day was scheduled to leave at 2.30 p.m. to arrive in Canberra at 4.45 p.m. the next one was at 5.15 p.m. due to arrive in Canberra at 8.15 p.m. Neither of these was a direct flight.
The arrangements as pursued by 34 Squadron enabled the Minister to leave Tamworth in the replacement aircraft at 1.50 p.m., arriving in Canberra at 2.40 p.m.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2323) Senator Evans asked me, as Minister representing the Prime Minister in the Senate, a question without notice concerning the Prime Minister's discussions in the Republic of Korea on the question of human rights. The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I cannot accept the honourable senator's assertion that I failed to press the issue of human rights during my visit to South Korea. As the Age article to which he refers reports, I raised the issue on more than one occasion. I discussed the question in formal talks with both the President and the Prime Minister, and in my address at the dinner hosted by Prime Minister Yoo on 24 May, I made the point that there is strength in tolerance and diversity and that the wider the opportunity for minorities to give free expression to their views, the greater the security for any nation.

I do not agree with the senator that the record of the Government in the South is almost indistinguishable from that of its Northern neighbour. The closed and totalitarian political system in North Korea permits no degree of personal freedom and indeed, its belligerence towards the Government in Seoul has been a major factor in influencing that Government's attitude towards domestic dissent . In spite of the pressures that the hostility of North Korea has placed on Seoul to maintain massive defence expenditure, South Korea has enjoyed remarkable economic progress and its Government has done much to improve the standard of life of its people.

I have no doubt that a lessening of tensions between the two Koreas would have a beneficial impact on both the economy and the human rights situation in South Korea. For this to occur, however, there would need to be a marked change in the attitude of the Government in Pyongyang which has consistently rejected proposals for improving relations put to it by the Republic of Korea.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2494) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning relics at the North Head quarantine station.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following answer:

Following the allegations in the Manly Daily of theft of items from the station, the Department of Health asked the Australian Federal Police to investigate the matter. A report from the Officer-in-Charge of the Federal Police, Eastern Division, states that an investigation was undertaken and revealed that there was no substance to the allegations. A complete stocktake of items revealed no discrepancy between those currently at the station and those that have been in stock for the last 10 years.

The former Minister for Health, Mr MacKellar, was very interested in the future of the relics held at the station and was concerned to see that they are safeguarded after the station land is handed over to New South Wales. I share this concern. To this end, both my Department and I are willing to co-operate in appropriate arrangements to ensure the future safety of the collection. However, an aspect of this matter that has not received much publicity is the fact that the station is a fully operational human quarantine station. About eighty persons each year are quarantined at the station and must be isolated from any visitors. Care must therefore be taken to ensure that visits to the station are kept to a minimum and that numbers of visitors are restricted. Within this essential constraint, I will continue to co-operate fully with the New South Wales authorities.

I am informed that restricted access to the station has already been granted on a number of occasions and properly authorised persons will continue to be admitted to the station while on official business. A most co-operative attitude has already been adopted towards the future managers of the station and the honourable senator may be assured that this spirit of co-operation will continue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2501) Senator Watson asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned leaving the ban on steroid-type hormones until their long term effects on human or animal health is examined.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:

While both Australian Agricultural Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council have had policies recommending against the use of hormonal growth promotants, it is not entirely accurate to describe them as a ban.

These policies were introduced to prevent the growth promotant use of stilbene compounds such as diethylstilboestrol and hexoestrol in the interests of overseas trade in meat and dairy products and this objective has been achieved during the past two decades. Curently, the State authorities refuse to register any stilbenes for growth promotion of food producing animals.

The Senate may be assured that no hormonal growth promotants, steroidal or otherwise, will be approved for use on Australian livestock until all regulatory authorities are completely satisfied regarding their safety for consumers of meat from treated animals and for the safety of the animals themselves.
The only hormonal-type chemical so far approved for limited growth promotant use on cattle in Australia is the non-steroidal compound zeranol.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Attorney-General reconsider his answer to Question No. 460 dated 12 June 1981. (See Senate Hansard, page 3296).

(2) Does the Attorney-General still consider that, in relation to the document inquired after in Question No. 460, there is a potential for its use in foreign proceedings; if so, which proceedings; and if not, will the Attorney-General now secure the release of the document.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I have reconsidered my answer to Question No. 460 dated 12 June 1981 (Senate Hansard, page 3296). I am satisfied that there is still a potential for the document referred to by the honourable senator to be used in foreign proceedings. That potential exists in relation to any such proceedings, whether now pending or instituted in the future, in which the arrangements for the exportation of uranium to which the document relates are alleged to be contrary to the laws of another country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In the areas that private contractors have replaced Commonwealth employees in the carrying out of functions of the Department of Administrative Services:
(a) has a cost benefit analysis been made to show the savings or added costs that have resulted; and
(b) what has been the additional savings or cost in which areas.

(2) Has any assurance been given that services contracted out to the private sector will not contribute to inflation or the Federal deficit by costing the government more than would the same services provided from within the public service by salaried officers; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) As the Prime Minister said in his statement in the House on 30 April 1981 concerning the Review of Commonwealth Functions, that Review was much more than an expenditure review exercise. He pointed out that many of the decisions, such as those involving contracting out to the private sector, do not have immediate expenditure savings as their principal objective.
The Prime Minister went on to say, however, that the Government had regarded the Review as making an important contribution to the objective of further reining in government spending.

The stated immediate aims of the Review were to streamline and fine down Commonwealth operations, including by withdrawing from functions more appropriately handled by private enterprise. Activities of a commercial kind were seen as generally best performed in the private sector.
The Government took the view that we would all be better off in a material sense by establishing a more limited, a more realistic, role for government, giving room for private sector growth.

The Prime Minister also indicated that the decisions flowing from the Review would contribute to the further pursuit by the Government of a number of economic objectives including lower inflation. He emphasised that the Government had given high priority to reducing the Commonwealth deficit.
Attention of the honourable senator is also drawn to the answers already given to Questions 723, 1258, 1714 and 1741.

Against this background I would add only the following comments. Cost/benefit analyses are, on appropriate occasions, a useful part of the decision-making processes of government, which must necessarily take account of a wide range of considerations. Secondly, it is of course a continuing responsibility of governments to review departmental operations in the light of on-going expenditures and other relevant factors. And thirdly, the use of competitive processes inherent in contracting-out to the private sector should contribute to locating the best value contractor.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What functions of the Department under the Minister's supervision are now performed on a regular basis by private contractors and have been taken over from Commonwealth employees since-
(a) the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions;
(b) January 1981;
(c) January 1980; and
(d) January 1979.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: Significant work is already undertaken by private contractors on the provision and maintenance of airports and all airways equipment is provided by private industry. While no functions relating to the responsibilities of the Department of Aviation have been transferred to the private sector since January 1979, increased emphasis has been given to the practice of offering them work wherever practicable. Following the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, further avenues to extend the use of consultants are being investigated in regard to administrative and support activities, with respect to the possibilities of private ownership and operation of domestic air terminals and with a view to seeking greater private sector involvement in particular works, especially airport maintenance and the installation of airways facilities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the ANZUS Treaty apply to:
(a) the Indian Ocean littoral of Australia;
(b) Australia's Indian Ocean island possessions; and
(c) the Australian Antarctic Territory;
If not, will the Treaty be renegotiated to extend its application to the above.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) to (c) It is clear that the Treaty is intended to apply without distinction to the whole of Australia. This view has been reiterated by the Government on a number of occasions and I draw the honourable senator's particular attention to a reply to that effect by the then Minister for Foreign Affairs to a question upon notice by Mr Holding on 30 April 1980 (House of Representatives, Hansard 1980, Vol. 118, page 2879). The Minister went on to conclude that 'while the Treaty expresses concerns, objectives and commitments of the parties in broad terms, determination of specific action to be taken is a matter to be decided by governments from time to time'. This remains the Government's view.

With regard to the Australian Antarctic Territory it should be noted that Article I of the Antarctic Treaty (Aust. T.S. 1961, No. 12) expressly prohibits, inter alia, 'any measures of a military nature' in the Antarctic.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: On what date and by what means were (a) New South Wales; (b) Queensland; and (c ) the Northern Territory informed that a review by the Department of Industrial Relations had revealed the existence of a number of provisions in their legislation which were inconsistent with International Labour Organisation Convention No. 65-Penal Sanctions (Indigenous Workers), 1939. (See House of Representatives Hansard, 4 October 1977, page 1607 and 18 November 1981, page 3098).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a), (b) and (c) The review conducted by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations in 1977, to which the honourable senator refers, confirmed the existence of penal provisions in certain pieces of legislation in the States and Territories of Australia. New South Wales provided written information on 2 August 1977 and verbal confirmation of the existence of penal provisions in its legislation on 12 September 1977, Queensland provided written confirmation on 20 June 1977 and the Department of the Northern Territory provided written confirmation on 21 October 1977. However, the existence of obligations which might be applicable to Australia under the Convention depends on there being a ' dependent indigenous population' in Australia within the meaning of that term as used in the Convention. A more recent review by the then Department of Industrial Relations has shown that there is agreement in both State and Commonwealth jurisdictions that while Aboriginals are 'indigenous' they do not as a group constitute a 'dependent indigenous population' within the meaning of the Convention as opined by the appropriate supervisory body within the International Labour Organisation.
Given the above, the question of penal sanctions in Australia does not arise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have any cases in which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) has found for the appellant against the Department of Social Security been taken to the Federal Court; if any, could details of each case be provided.
(2) What cases of this nature have been decided in the Federal Court.
(3) What departmental guidelines have been changed as a result of AAT decisions .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. As at 28 July 1982 the Department of Social Security has lodged appeals to the Federal Court of Australia in six such cases. The first involved the issue of whether a person was unemployed (and therefore qualified to receive unemployment benefit) while attending a course at a college of advanced education. Four further appeals relate to the recovery of overpayments of pension or benefit. Of these, one has been heard by the Court and decision has been reserved; another was abandoned when the respondent agreed to repay the amount calculated by the Department as properly overpaid and recoverable; a third is to be heard in Brisbane on 4 August 1982; the fourth has not yet been listed for hearing. The remaining appeal concerns the date from which a pension is payable and also awaits listing by the Court.
(2) Only in the first of the six cases referred to in (1) has the Federal Court decided the matter. In that case, the Court dismissed the appeal.

(3) As a result of AAT decisions, changes have been made to existing departmental instructions in a number of areas such as the pensions income test for certain married couples; eligibility for special benefit; the payment of arrears in certain sickness benefit cases.
Additionally, existing manuals of instruction have been amended to reflect changes of a less substantial nature and current practices which have been confirmed by decisions of the Tribunal.

Further changes to guidelines may be required depending upon the outcome of appeals referred to in answer (1) above. As AAT decisions are handed down, the Department will continue to have regard to their implications for its practices and will change its guidelines and instructions as necessary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Telecom Australia decided to close the operations centre at Korumburra in Victoria and merge it with an en- larged centre at Leongatha; if so, in making this decision did Telecom take into account the adverse economic and social repercussions on the community at Korumburra.
(2) Has similar action been taken at other rural and provincial centres in Victoria.
(3) Will the economic and social effects be taken into account by Telecom before such decisions are taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from advice furnished by the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telecom has two operations units in Korumburra, a technician district based on the communication centre and a lines sub-area based on the line depot. No change is contemplated to the staffing of the communications centre and it is assumed the question relates to the line depot.

The amount of line work required to be done in and around Korumburra has reduced to a level where retention of a separate sub-area cannot be justified. Telecom has therefore initiated the normal process followed in such circumstances by considering the abolition of the sub-area as a discrete management unit and the closing of the line depot on which it is based. The steps in this process are:
No further staff will be recruited at the Korumburra depot.

When the lines officer-in-charge position becomes vacant because of promotion, transfer or separation the situation will be reviewed. If at that time the amount of line work available or in prospect is still inadequate, the sub-area will be abolished and merged with Leongatha sub-area based on Leongatha line depot. In the unlikely event of a strong increase in demand the Korumburra sub- area will be retained.
Lines staff currently at the Korumburra line depot will continue to be based there until they are promoted, transferred or separated. When the line depot is no longer required it will be closed.
This procedure is designed to minimise any adverse social and economic effects on the community in the affected area.
(2) Yes. Lines sub-areas are created and abolished to accord with the changing workload.
(3) Yes. The process described for Korumburra aims to minimise adverse social and economic effects.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Parents and Teachers Against Violence in Education

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the application made by Parents and Teachers Against Violence in Education for gifts to it to be tax deductible (see Senate Hansard, 27 April, 1982, page 1563) ask that tax deductibility be granted under an existing part of section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act or was the request that the organisation be specifically listed in an amendment to section 78.
(2) What criteria must be fulfilled by Parents and Teachers Against Violence in Education before gifts to it may be tax deductible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that the application was in general terms. The organisation did not seek recognition in terms of a specific provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act nor was an amendment to the existing provisions sought.

(2) The question of income tax deductibility for gifts is governed by the specific provisions of section 78(1)(a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act which authorises the allowance of deductions for donations of the value of $2 and upwards to various funds, authorities or institutions in Australia which are specified by class or by name in the section.

The Commissioner informed me that the only provision relevant to the application lodged on behalf of the organisation Parents and Teachers Against Violence in Education is that which authorises the allowance of deductions for gifts to a public benevolent institution. He explained that such an institution has been judicially described as one which is established for the relief of poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune, destitution or helpessness.

In determining whether a particular organisation is a public benevolent institution the Commissioner is required to take into account not only its objects as set out in its constituent documents but also its actual activities which must be wholly or predominantly the provision of relief of the type described.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General upon notice on 18 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many invalid pension appeals are currently before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in each State?
(2) What are the average waiting times in each State?
(3) What is the earliest date in each State of an invalid pension appeal which was still waiting to be heard on 1 May 1982?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) At 1 June 1982 the number of invalid pension appeals before the Tribunal in each State and internal Territory was: Victoria 276 Queensland 136 New South Wales 84 South Australia 14 Tasmania 6 Western Australia 2 Australian Capital Territory 2 Northern Territory 1
(2) Information is not readily available to enable a full answer to be given covering the several hundreds of applications that have been made.

When an application for review of an invalid pension decision is lodged with the Tribunal, the first step is for the Tribunal's staff to serve notice of the application on the Department of Social Security. That Department is then required, pursuant to section 37 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, to furnish the Tribunal with a statement and documents relating to its decision. In my answer to Senate Question No. 1326 (Hansard, 27 May 1982, page 2607) I provided information concerning the time taken to comply with these requirements .

The next step is for the Tribunal to convene a preliminary conference of the parties, pursuant to section 34 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. The Tribunal is at present able to set down a preliminary conference within one month of the receipt by the Tribunal of the documents provided pursuant to section 37. Many cases are finalised as a result of the preliminary conference, either because the applicant withdraws his application or because the Department agrees to confer the benefit that is being sought.

After the preliminary conference, the Tribunal is usually in a position to set a case down for hearing within one month, provided the parties are ready to proceed. (In the case of a country applicant, it may take a little longer to set a case down for hearing where a hearing in a country locality is thought appropriate). The Tribunal is able to arrange a hearing at very short notice where there are special circumstances.

However, delays in setting matters down for hearing are often experienced because the parties are not ready to go ahead. For example, an applicant may become aware, as a result of the preliminary conference, that he will need further medical evidence if his case is to have any prospect of success. Delays are also occasioned by the unavailability of witnesses, particularly medical witnesses.
(3) The earliest date in each State and internal Territory of an invalid pension appeal which was still waiting to be heard on 1 May 1982 is:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Taxation Office announce its intention to compulsorily transfer 67 positions from regional centres to capital cities.
(2) When was this announcement made; where are the positions to be transferred from, and to where will they be transferred.
(3) How many positions have been transferred and when will the process be completed for all positions.
(4) With what functions was each officer/office involved.
(5) Has the Commissioner of Taxation made an assessment of any revenue losses as a consequence of the transfer of these positions because of reduction in income tax and sales tax investigation work.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Taxation Office is in the process of transferring over a five-year period a total of 43 positions from regional centres to capital cities .
(2) All affected staff and relevant staff associations were advised of the decision in June 1981.
The 43 positions involved are as follows:

Wagga Wagga-3 positions to Sydney. Newcastle-3 positions to Sydney. Wollongong- 3 positions to Sydney. Tamworth-3 positions to Sydney. Lismore-3 positions to Sydney. Orange-3 positions to Parramatta. Ballarat-3 positions to Melbourne. Bendigo-3 positions to Melbourne. Warrnambool-2 positions to Melbourne. Geelong- 3 positions to Melbourne. Horsham-2 positions to Melbourne. Cairns-2 positions to Brisbane. Rockhampton-2 positions to Brisbane. Toowoomba-3 positions to Brisbane. Alice Springs-2 positions to Adelaide. Mount Gambier-2 positions to Adelaide. Launceston-1 position to Hobart.
(3) Eleven positions have been transferred to date. It is anticipated that the process will be completed by 30 June 1986.
(4) The positions in question comprise three categories with functions as follows:
Investigation Officer Grade 2 (8 positions) which carry out sales tax investigations;
Investigation Officer Grade 3 (22 positions) which carry out income tax investigations; and
Indoor Examiner (13 positions) which examine, for income tax purposes, the financial affairs of all classes of taxpayers other than companies.

(5) The decision to transfer the positions was made by the Commissioner of Taxation following a thorough review of staffing arrangements in regional offices to determine whether the most effective use was being made of manpower resources. This review established that more effective enforcement activity can be achieved by using the investigation staff located in regional offices as part of a flexible team operating from capital city offices. The Commissioner is therefore confident that an increase in revenue will flow from the transfers.

(2) How many taxpayers have similar unresolved claims to that of the respondent in the appeal lodged by the Commissioner of Taxation in the Federal Court of Australia, Queensland District registry on 14 April 1982; what total claims and possible deductions are involved and what were the political affiliations at the time of candidature of those involved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The case to which the honourable senator has referred involves the question of whether expenditure incurred by a taxpayer following endorsement by a political party as a candidate for a parliamentary election to be held on a future undetermined date was expenditure incurred 'in contesting an election' within the meaning of section 74 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Commissioner of Taxation has appealed to the Federal Court against a decision of the Supreme Court of Queensland which upheld the taxpayer's claim that such expenditure was an allowable deduction under that section. The appeal has been set down for hearing by the Federal Court on 3 August 1982.

The behaviourist learning principles on which the ACE English course is based stand in direct contradiction to well documented research findings.'

Each broad group of schools within these categories was reported on briefly in terms of background, development, doctrinal position, curriculum, and relative advantages and disadvantages within a Christian framework. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry , upon notice, on 20 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the implications of the Torres Strait Treaty for Australian fishermen.
(2) Is or has the Gulf of Carpentaria been closed to the fishing of tiger prawns; if so, on what scientific evidence has the closure been made.
(3) Has Princess Charlotte Bay been closed to the fishing of barramundi; if so, on what scientific evidence has the closure been made.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the Torres Strait Treaty, Australia and Papua New Guinea will jointly share and manage the fisheries resources of the Torres Strait Protected Zone. Scientific research programs will be undertaken by both Governments in order to develop management regimes which will have as their objectives the conservation of the resources as well as the promotion of commercial development of fisheries in Torres Strait, while providing due protection to the continuation of traditional fishing activities.

Traditional fishing by traditional inhabitants will be a right preserved by legislation and will be subject only to those restrictions that are necessary to conserve living resources. The Torres Strait Treaty requires traditional inhabitants to be consulted from time to time regarding licensing arrangements for commercial fishing in the Protected Zone.

It is intended that commercial fishermen will be licensed to operate in Torres Strait in accordance with management regimes developed in consultation with industry, the Queensland government and, where appropriate, with Papua New Guinea. It will be necessary to regulate commercial fishing activities to give effect to obligations under the Torres Strait Treaty to protect traditional fishing and to implement catch sharing arrangements with PNG.

During the first five years after the Treaty enters into force, the Australian commercial catch in waters under Australian jurisdiction shall not be reduced below the level of catch taken prior to the Treaty entering into force provided the catch remains within the agreed total allowable catch for the fishery. Australian fishermen may seek access to surplus catch not exploited by PNG fishermen in waters under PNG jurisdiction during this peiod. Similarly, PNG fishermen may seek access to resources not fully exploited by Australian fishermen in waters under our jurisdiction.

During the second five year period, catch levels by Australia and PNG will be altered progressively if necessary in order to implement the catch sharing arrangements specified under the Treaty. The catch sharing arrangements are relatively complex and involve sharing of the resources on the basis of each country having the right to 75 per cent of the resources in waters under its own jurisdiction with at least 25 per cent to be allocated to the other country. Opportunities also will exist for Australia to enter into joint ventures with PNG fishing interests.

(2) This year, for the first time, a seasonal closure of waters in the western Gulf of Carpentaria from 1 January-15 March was implemented at the request of, and in consultation with, industry. The scientific evidence upon which the closure was based is the result of extensive sampling and biological examination of the commercial catch which showed that significant quantities of small tiger prawns were being taken during that period in the area that was subsequently closed. The ban was implemented in order to allow small prawns to grow to a preferred commercial size.
(3) This matter does not fall within the responsibilities of the Commonwealth Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Role of Women in Third World Countries

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affaris, upon notice, on 27 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the role of women in Third World countries a crucial factor in the development of these countries.

(2) Does the rate of change in the position of women in these countries and in particular social and economic circumstances vary considerably and is development assistance related to the role of women likely to be ineffective and wasteful unless it is provided on the basis of careful and individual assessment and unless it is accompanied by continuing support and consultation.

(3) In these circumstances and in view of the fact that the women in Development Unit have carried out valuable work to meet these requirements will the Minister advise whether it is still intended to abolish this unit as recommended by the Review of Commonwealth Functions, and if so would the Minister be prepared to revise the decision and ensure that the unit is enabled to continue and expand its work on behalf of women in Third World countries and in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Women in most Third World countries play a crucial role in their countries' development. In many developing countries women comprise more than half the rural labour force, working in agriculture, animal husbandry and other income raising activities. In addition they are responsible for caring for the upbringing and welfare of their families, particularly for the health and nutrition and early education of their children.

(2) The importance of women's contribution to development is now generally recognised by both developing countries and donors. Development assistance programs must ensure that women receive appropriate assistance to increase their capacity to contribute more effectively to development, and seek to ensure that they share equally in the benefits of that development. Indeed if the role of women is not considered in the planning and implementation of assistance proposals, projects may be less effective. The consideration of these issues requires careful appraisal of the role of women in each major project area and monitoring of the effects of the project as it is implemented.

(3) Implementation of decisions concerning the Australian Development Assistance Bureau taken in the context of the Government's Review of Commonwealth Functions has not yet been concluded. Meanwhile, the full duties and responsibilities of the Women in Development position within the Bureau continue to be performed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the practice of parallel scheduling, whereby the departure times of Ansett Airlines and Trans Australia Airlines from locations throughout Australia are virtually identical, be halted so that the interest of passengers becomes paramount over the interests of the airlines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The scheduling of services by Ansett and TAA has developed similar characteristics primarily because the airlines have traditionally operated identical equipment over a similar network with equal capacity. In addition, airline schedules are designed around definite daily peaks which occur in terms of passengers' preferred departure times. As a consequence, there is a compromise on all routes between passengers' preferences in departure times, levels of demand, aircraft and aircrew availability and optimum utilisation by the airlines of their equipment throughout their networks.
The actual scheduling of flights is determined by the airlines on this basis and is a matter for their respective commercial judgments.

Although the airlines are required to submit their time- tables for approval by the Secretary to the Department of Aviation under Air Navigation Regulation 106C , those schedules can only be disallowed on operational or safety grounds. The Commonwealth is therefore not able to consider airline schedules on the basis of public interest.

Nevertheless, the Government is aware of the inconvenience which this feature of trunk route operations can cause travellers and has actively encouraged the airlines to reduce the extent of parallel scheduling. In this regard, the decisions by TAA and Ansett to re-equip with aircraft with different seating capacities are expected to result in moves towards a reduction of parallel scheduling which will be to the public's benefit.

These costs are for existing beneficiaries only and are based on the estimated average number of unemployment and special beneficiaries in 1981-82 and their estimated income distribution.
Adoption of this proposal would have the effect of making persons currently excluded by the income test eligible for a part rate benefit.

It is not possible to estimate with accuracy the cost in respect of these new beneficiaries due to the lack of appropriate data on the income distribution of unemployed persons and the impact of such a proposal on labour force participation.
