QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Deed of Assignment and Associated Government Agreement, as amended, under which the Government disposed of its interest in the Ranger Project provide for a price of $229,306,767.70 to be paid to the Government by ERA.
(2) Did this same agreement provide for cash share and shares to the total value of approximately $322m.
(3) If the answer to (1) and (2) is yes, how can the Government claim to have been 'obtaining the best deal possible' as the Minister claimed on 20 November 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) No. Payments to Peko Wallsend Operations Ltd and Electrolytic Zinc Company of Australasia Ltd were the subject of separate arrangements between those companies and ERA and the Government was not a party to those arrangements.

(3) It should be noted that ERA, in purchasing the Government's share also assumed all of the obligations of the Commonwealth relating to that share. These included obligations to pay proportionately larger shares of capital costs for the project and of royalty payable to the Aboriginal Benefits Trust Account, as well as to make payments to the Northern Territory Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 27 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which parties have made confidential submissions to the Davidson Inquiry on Telecommunications Services in Australia.
(2) Which of these confidential submissions has been followed by confidential hearings.
(3) Has the committee had confidential sessions with any other parties and if so, with whom.
(4) Has the committee had formal or informal discussions with any other group/s which have made submissions to the Inquiry; if so, who.
(5) What date was the submission by the Department of Communications completed and submitted to the Davidson Inquiry.
(6) What was the reason for the significant delay in the preparation of this submission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from information furnished by the Davidson Inquiry and his Department:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Because of prior, public assurances as to confidentiality, the Committee of Inquiry feels unable to disclose the names of persons and organisations which made confidential submissions or subsequently have given evidence in camera to the Committee.

(4) As at 13 May, the Committee has had formal or informal public discussions with 53 other groups of whom all but 5 had previously made submissions to the Committee. The Secretary of the Inquiry will provide details of these groups to you by letter.
(5) The Department of Communications submission was sent to the Inquiry on 21 April 1982.
(6) My Department lodged its submission as early as practicable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Invalid Car Parks: Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many specifically designated invalid car parks are there in the ACT, and where are they located.
(2) Is the Minister aware that car parks designated in this manner are in fact frequently used by the general public and that as a result invalids are prevented from using them.
(3) What measures does the Minister intend to take to overcome these difficulties.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following response to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are at present 307 spaces set aside for the disabled in the ACT located at major employment, medical and shopping centres and other places where there is a demonstrated need. The Department has published a pamphlet 'Car Parking Spaces for the Disabled in Canberra' showing the location of each space.
(2) Yes. This has been the case in the past.

(3) The penalty for parking in such spaces was increased from $4 to $25 in July 1982. At the same time an amendment to the Motor Traffic Ordinance has been proclaimed to make it easier to prosecute offenders who park in spaces reserved for disabled drivers. The Department has revised its parking patrols and priority is being given to surveillance of car parks reserved for disabled drivers. More parking inspectors are being recruited and arrangements have been made to have more Court time available to hear cases.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: John Curtin School of Medical Research

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 26 May 1982 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When is the John Curtin School of Medical Research Clinical Research Committee expected to have completed its consideration of Dr Lafferty's work.
(2) How often does the Committee meet.
(3) How widely has the Committee sought opinions on Dr Lafferty's work.
(4) Does Dr Lafferty use parts of human foetuses for his work if he does not use 'whole human foetuses' (see Answer to Question No. 1240).
(5) In view of the fact approval has not yet been given for the research protocol for Dr Lafferty's work, has there been at any stage research on such tissue at the Australian National University.
(6) To whom is Dr Lafferty now responsible.
(7) Is his research project still under the control of the Department of Immunology and where is it located.
(8) How many staff members are involved in this project (see Questions on Notice Nos 1240 and 1952).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Secretary of the Australian National University has advised me as follows:

(1) The John Curtin School of Medical Research Clinical Research Committee has been awaiting certification of ethical approval for the provision of foetal tissues from the ethics committees in hospitals in Victoria. Completion of the consideration of Dr Lafferty's proposal for future work must await this certification.
(2) The Committee meets as required to examine proposals referred to it. It last met on 21 January 1982.

(3) In addition to its own deliberation, the Committee has examined the ethical issues in the context of guidelines that have been accepted in the United Kingdon and New Zealand. It is not the function of the Committee to evaluate research proposals. Dr Lafferty's scientific work is highly regarded internationally.
(4) Dr Lafferty has used foetal pancreas in the past. Foetal tissue samples were studied in the laboratory. None of this tissue was supplied from ACT hospitals.

(5) During 1980 and 1981 foetal tissues samples from Melbourne were made available to Dr Lafferty and these were examined histologically (see also answer to No. 4 above). The University believes that as the tissue was used for scientific purposes there was no departure from the legal provisions for the ACT in the these matters.

At present there is no scientific work at all using human foetal tissue being done in the John Curtin School of Medical Research (JCSMR). In Dr Lafferty's project tissue transplantation in experimental animals is being studied.
(6) The Director of the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

(7) No. The original studies were conducted in the Department on Immunology of JCSMR. The work is now located in the Transplantation Biology Unit of JCSMR which was established by the Council of the University on 14 May 1982. It is located in space occupied by JCSMR under a leasing arrangement with the Capital Territory Health Commission, in the Central Health Laboratories in the Woden Valley Hospital buildings.
(8) Dr Lafferty and a research assistant.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 February 1982, (Hansard, page 7) Senator MacGibbon asked me as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the pay increases granted last year to the armed Services will be of the order of $160m this financial year and over $250m next year? How is this increase going to be funded? Can the Minister assure the Senate that there will be no degradation of general conditions of service in the armed Services, such as food rations, that there will be no cuts in training programs or in fuel usage and that there will be no reductions in equipment acquisitions ?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Yes. Defence outlay provided for in the 1981-82 Additional Estimates amounts to $4,211m. This reflects full provision for changes in salaries and other conditions of service. There will be no degradation in any conditions of service. To accommodate the earlier-than-expected acquisition of HMS Invincible that was then planned, and new Orion aircraft, as well as wage and salary increases, it was necessary to vary priorities as outlined by my predecessor's statement to the House on 29 April 1982.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 February 1982 (Hansard, page 480) Senator Bonner asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware that, between April 1976 and June 1981, 27,000 square kilometres of Queensland rural land was involved in approval proposals for foreign investors and that this area represents 1.6 per cent of Queensland, which is more than 1.2 per cent presently being sought by my fellow Aborigines in that State? Is the Minister aware also of the grave concern that is being expressed by the rural population and other interested organisations such as the Returned Services League? Has the Commonwealth any powers to prevent this foreign takeover and in particular prevent certain foreign nationals from acquiring this land under the Queensland Government's patronage?

Following the provision of a preliminary answer by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the question was referred to the Treasurer who has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The honourable senator is correct in stating that foreign investors were given approval to acquire a total of 27,000 square kilometres of rural land in Queensland between April 1976 and June 1981. Over one-third of purchases were by intending migrants and other purchases involved Australians in partnership with foreign investors.

In the light of the increase in foreign investment in rural land the Government undertook a review of policy late in 1981. In conducting this review the Government had regard both to the attention directed to such investment by rural communities and other groups and to the benefits that can be derived in terms of additional income and employment from such investment. After consultation with the States and Northern Territory, on 20 January 1982 the Government announced a more restrictive approach towards foreign investment in rural properties. As before, a property to be acquired by a foreign interest must have been advertised or otherwise offered for sale in a way normal for the industry to ensure that Australians have been given adequate opportunity to bid for it. In addition, the Government decided that foreign investment approval would normally be restricted to proposals where the purchasers have firm plans to establish residence in Australia or which offer significant economic benefits. Where the economic benefits are small, approval would normally be forthcoming only where there is an effective partnership (normally at 50/50 partnership) between Australian investors and the foreign investors in the ownership and control of the property.

The Government pays particular attention to the advice of the State or Territory concerned in determinig whether or not a proposed acquisition would lead to significant economic benefits. Moreover, the assessment of economic benefits is made relative to the size of the proposed investment. Case by case examination enables conformity with the above criteria to be assessed in the light of individual circumstances and attention to be given to the opportunities and willingness of Australians to purchase on commercial terms.

The Treasurer has power under the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975 to prevent the purchase of a rural property (where that property constitutes a business for the purpose of the Act) when control passes to a foreign person and the Treasurer is satisfied that the takeover would be contrary to the national interest. In establishing whether a proposal is contrary to the national interest, the proposal is considered against the above criteria.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1277), Senator Archer asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, two questions without notice concerning arson investigation and claims by the insurance industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's questions:

I am aware of the concern expressed by the insurance industry about the cost of arson to the Australian community. If it were to appear that Commonwealth co -operation of one kind or another would be beneficial that would, of course, be considered. However, as indicated by the Minister representing the Treasurer on 20 April 1982 in answer to the honourable senator's questions, it would seem more appropriate for matters involving suspected fraud or arson that come to the notice of the insurance industry to be referred to the State authority concerned. I understand that the insurance industry has been active for some time in drawing the problems in this area to the attention of State Police Departments and that some States have established specialist arson squads.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1273) Senator Robertson asked the Minister representing the then Minister for Education a question without notice concerning Lieutenant-General Sarwo Ehdie Wibowo.

ANSWER.PARA: The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

I have seen the Press report of the visit to Australia of Lieutenant-General Sarwo Ehdie Wibowo. The Australian Embassy, Jakarta, has advised that the visit was for 'official' purposes according to the Lieutenant-General's application for a visa and an associated letter from the Indonesian Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

More than 300 Indonesian students in Australia receive Commonwealth Government funded awards. These students are supervised by the Australian Development Assistance Bureau, which is concerned with questions of academic progress and personal well-being. The students are not required to inform the Bureau of activities, whether political or otherwise, in which they may become involved and no information is therefore available as to the number of students who may have been addressed by the Lieutenant-General.
The Press reports state that course expenses were met by the Indonesian Government and I am not aware of any assistance provided by Australian universities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1275) Senator Collard asked me a question without notice where he referred to a British report of a process to recover heating oil from waste lubricant oil. In this part of his question he sought to know the relevance and viability of such a process being introduced in Australia in the hope of making Australia more energy independent . He also asked how much heating oil is used and how much waste lubricating oil is dumped each year in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to provided further detailed information for the honourable senator and now provide the following information:

(i) The process to which Senator Collard referred is the 'Flowen' process, developed by Robert Owen International Ltd of Poole, Dorset. The Flowen process treats a selected waste oil product within the broad fuel oil specification with an ash content higher than average fuel oil. Therefore if the product is used as a boiler fuel, the boiler must be capable of handling efficiently the ash produced. Flowen fuel oil does not approach in quality the product known in Australia as 'heating oil' and could not be used as a substitute for it.

As I indicated in my response on 20 April 1982 the waste oil that is being re- used in Australia is in the main being blended with fuel oil for subsequent burning as a fuel. Under these circumstances I can see no purpose in asking the National Energy Research Development and Demonstration Council to look into the relevance and viability of the 'Flowen' process.
(ii) The sales of heating oil for the last three financial years for which records are complete were

(iii) In my response on 20 April 1982 I gave estimates of the quantities of waste lubricating oil potentially available for collection and recycling in 1980, the quantities being recycled and unaccounted for.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1353) Senator Button asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I take it that the Minister representing the Minister for Communications is aware that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal ruled that television commercials promoting Federal Government housing policies before the recent elections were electoral matter within the meaning of the Broadcasting and Television Act. In view of this ruling, what action is now being taken to recoup from the Victorian branch of the Australian Liberal Party the costs of producing and broadcasting these commercials?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from advice furnished by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal:

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal advised television stations in Victoria that although they were shown in all States, the television commercials authorised by the then Federal Minister for Housing and Construction informing the public of the Government's Help for Home Buyers Plan contained 'election matter' as defined by section 116 (6) (c) of the Broadcasting and Television Act. There is no provision in the Act for action regarding costs of production or broadcasting of 'election matter'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1354) Senator Townley asked me , as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction, a question without notice relating to the road rule in New South Wales which permits vehicles to turn left through a red light after stopping (left-turn-on- red).

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport and Construction has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The advocacy of left-turn-on-red in Australia began after a similar rule was introduced in the United States as a fuel-conservation measure, most traffic signals there operating on a fixed-time basis with very long cycle times. By contrast, a good number of Australian traffic signals are vehicle-actuated with inductive loops below the road surface detecting the passage of vehicles and adjusting the signals accordingly. In off-peak times a driver may receive a green signal almost as soon as he reaches the stop line even if the signal is red as he approaches it. Moreover, some intersections with traffic signals have left-turn slip lanes through which left turns may be made at any time with care .

I am informed that the Traffic Authority of New South Wales has undertaken a trial of left-turn-on-red at some 30 selected sites and decided to proceed with a cautious extension of it. In all cases, however, there will be signs indicating that turns may be made after stopping, that is, the practice will continue to be sign-permissive at particular locations, not a general rule.
The New South Wales experience will be considered by the Australian Transport Advisory Council's Committee on Road User Performance and Traffic Code.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1346) Senator Mason asked me a question without notice concerning incentives for the manufacture of solar collectors. I undertook to look into the whole matter and give a more detailed reply. The following information is now provided:

ANSWER.PARA: The National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Program provides funding for energy research, development and demonstration projects. Support through the program for solar energy projects totals $7m. This includes the funding of 31 projects totalling $2m in the field of solar collector technology . Demonstration and testing in practical applications of the vacuum insulated solar absorber tube developed by Sydney University is being supported under three of these NERDDP projects at a cost of $272,340.
These are:

A recent grant of $185,000 to Bitupave Ltd for a period of two years. The aim of the project is the conversion of the heating system for a 318,200 litre bitumen tank from oil heating to solar heating. It is proposed to insulate the tank and maintain the working temperature by supplying solar heat from an array of approximately 200 m2 of concentrating collectors developed by the University of New South Wales, which utilises the University of Sydney designed vacuum insulated tube.

A grant of $59,687 to the Solar Energy Research Centre, University of Queensland, in 1981 for a period of three years. The objective of the project is to produce a solar powered air conditioning system and demonstrate its technical viability. The project includes evaluation of the Sydney University designed vacuum insulated absorber tube to drive an absorption chiller air- conditioning system.

A grant of $27,653 to the University of New South Wales in 1980 to test various prototype, non-tracking solar concentrators. Some included the vacuum insulated absorber tube supplied by the University of Sydney, while others were fitted with tubes either selectively coated or coated with matt black paint. Results indicated that vacuum insulated tubes of the University of Sydney design outperformed the other prototypes.

Further funding by the Commonwealth Government to industry for solar research is provided through the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme which is administered by the Department of Science and Technology. Research and development of solar energy is also being undertaken by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation.

It is Government policy that the commercialisation of new energy technologies is primarily the responsibility of the private sector. Consistent with this policy, the Government has, through a variety of measures, created an economic climate designed to assist the development of solar energy technologies. Exemption from sales tax applies to solar appliances for all uses and to certain classes of goods connected with the use of solar energy. These exemptions have provided added financial incentive to people wishing to instal solar water heaters in their homes.

The Commonwealth Government has also provided taxation concessions which encourage commercial and industrial users of oil-fired and liquefied petroleum- fired equipment to convert or replace their equipment with plant utilising other energy sources including solar energy.

Assistance is also currently available to aid local manufacture by way of a tariff of 35 per cent applicable to the importation of photovoltaics, flat plate collectors and solar arrays and panels. Solar generator systems, consisting of panels with storage batteries are dutiable at the rate of 25 per cent.

These measures, together with the support of research through the NERDD program and other Commonwealth funding schemes, have given a substantial stimulus to the expansion of the solar industry in Australia. The cost of further Commonwealth Government assistance would need to be considered in the context of the overall level of assistance already being received by the solar energy industry which has a turnover of approximately $25m per annum.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1764) Senator Coleman asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice concerning the computerisation of the telephone communications system.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to obtain an answer to the part of the honourable senator's question that related to the provision for additional availability of telephone lines for the '000' emergency service.
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer from advice furnished by the Australian Telecommunications Commission:

Where the Manual Assistance Plan requires that '000' calls for a particular area are to be answered at a distant manual assistance centre to retain 24-hour service, the circuit needs are assessed and appropriate provision is made. The method of circuit provision depends on the availability and location of State Government emergency services and the arrangements they have for after-hours rostering and location of staff.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Friends of the Earth: Anti-Uranium Activities

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2014) Senator Kilgariff asked me the following questions without notice in relation to the occupation of the Honeymoon uranium deposit in South Australia by anti-nuclear groups.

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Government confirm reports that a training course to determine tactics for that occupation was conducted by the Communist Party's Camp Eureka outside Melbourne?
Can the Government confirm also that the group Friends of the Earth conducted the course?
Does the group account for its expenditure associated with the grant received from the Commonwealth in the 1981-82 financial year?

I undertook to seek information in respect of the above parts of the honourable senator's question. With regard to the first two matters, I believe that the reports are based on the fact that the Friends of the Earth Australia group held its national meeting at Camp Eureka from 20-24 January. I am also aware that a pamphlet subsequently issued by the group carried a report on the national meeting and quoted a spokesperson as saying: 'We intend organising an occupation of the Honeymoon uranium mine in South Australia in early May.'

In my earlier reply I said that the Friends of the Earth received a Commonwealth grant of $5,000 in the 1981-82 financial year. In relation to the last aspect of the honourable senator's question, I am advised that this grant was for the purposes of assisting with administrative costs-office accommodation, printing and telephone expenses-and for approved technical assistance and research projects. The grant is subject to the provision of an annual audited financial statement demonstrating that the purposes for which the grant was made have been met.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2312) Senator Watson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware that currently the world steel industry is characterised by a gross over-capacity which is being supported by extensive use of subsidies, export incentives and protection measures-many of a non-tariff nature? Does the recent statement by the Minister for Industry and Commerce that the Australian steel industry is one of the few steel industries in the world open to import competition shed any light on the rising imports of steel and on the announcement that the Tasmanian Electro Metallurgical Co Pty Ltd plant near Launceston has retrenched 63 employees? Is the steel industry's distinctive position in being so open to import competition an inhibiting factor so far as local employment is concerned ?

In a supplementary question regarding the 45-day and 12-month periods respectively for the Temporary Assistance Authority and the Industries Assistance Commission to complete reports regarding certain steel products, Senator Watson asked:
In the light of the retrenchments that are currently occurring in the industry , particularly in may State of Tasmania, does not the Minister consider that these time intervals are far too long?
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following supplementary information in response to the honourable senator's question:

The Tasmanian Electro Metallurgical Company Pty Ltd (TEMCO) produces a range of ferro alloys which are used in steelmaking. The parent company, The Broken Hill Proprietary Company Limited accounts for the bulk of local sales, whilst up to 50 per cent of production has in the past been sold on export markets.

The management of TEMCO has recently conducted an extensive review of its operations and its market potential. As a result of that review, the company has found it necessary to shut down one furnace and to carry out substantial rationalisation elsewhere in its operations.

TEMCO's difficulties have arisen due to reduced domestic demand and to unremunerative export markets. These problems are directly attributable to the depressed state of the world steel industry, which was also a major element in the situation which led to the reference of certain steel products to the Temporary Assistance Authority and the Industries Assistance Commission. TEMCO' s products are not covered by these references but there is an indirect relationship through ferro alloy production being largely determined by the level of steel output.

The 45 days allowed for the Temporary Assistance Authority inquiry is the period prescribed by legislation. Prior to the existing provision the specified period was 30 days but experience proved this to be insufficient. For the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry, 12 months was seen as being about the minimum period for an adequate review of the long term assistance appropriate to an industry as extensive as that under reference. There is, however, always scope for the Government to request the Commission to submit an interim report should this be warranted by changed circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1982 (Hansard, Page 2378) Senator Gietzelt asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does the announcement by the Minister for Administrative Services that the Government has set a target of 40 per cent to 45 per cent of survey work to be contracted out to the private sector signify a running down of the work of the Australian Survey Office? Is this particularly so given that currently some 10 per cent to 15 per cent of government survey work already goes to the private sector? Further, can the Minister give an assurance that the Australian Survey Office will remain a strong viable unit with career opportunities within the Office, and that staff surveyors will not face the prospect of redeployment or redundancy as a result of the razor gang decisions to transfer survey services to the private sector?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Following, the Review of Commonwealth Functions, a target of 40 to 45 per cent of Commonwealth survey work has been set as the amount to be contracted out. The decision was taken because the Government believes it should not be doing work which can be done as well by the private sector.
The decision was not intended to reduce the viability of the Australian Survey Office. Accordingly, the organisation will continue to provide career opportunities for its staff.

The staffing levels agreed to by my Department in consultation with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Finance and the Public Service Board are to be reached by June 1986. These should be attained through normal wastage and surveyors are not expected to face the prospect of redeployment or redundancy. Any significant organisational changes resulting from the decision will be discussed with the unions concerned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1982 (Hansard, page 2380) Senator Thomas asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Minister ask the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to consider clarifying the position of sales tax exemption for four-wheel drive vehicles used for primary production? I have received several submissions from Western Australian pastoralists which make the point that two almost identical vehicles are treated totally differently with regard to the application of this tax.
As the matter raised by the honourable senator falls within the Treasurer's portfolio I have obtained the following advice from the Treasurer in response to the question:

There is a provision in the sales tax law that exempts machinery, implements and apparatus for use in agricultural industry if, in the opinion of the Commissioner, they are goods of a kind used exclusively, or primarily and principally, in that industry. The Commissioner of Taxation advises that certain types of four-wheel drive vehicles can qualify for exemption under this provision when purchased for use in agricultural industry. The Commissioner added that without full details of the particular circumstances involved and the types of vehicles he is unable to offer any comment on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 February 1982:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: It is a fact that last week a Rear Admiral and four senior public servants proceeded overseas to examine the staffing levels of our diplomatic missions in Washington, London and Paris? What is the estimated cost of this mission? Why was it not possible for such a staffing review to be carried out without the need for the physical presence of such a team in these places overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) The Government asked the Public Service Board to undertake a review of the staffing levels of a number of Australia's diplomatic missions including Washington, London and Paris. As part of this review, two officers of the Public Service Board proceeded overseas in February/March 1982 to visit those missions and the Brussels mission.

In view of the particular interests of the Department of Foreign Affairs, which is the administering department at each of these missions, the Department sent two of it's Canberra-based officers to assist the Board's officers in their review. Similarly, in the light of the significant representation of defence and armed services personnel, an officer of the Department of Defence (a Rear Admiral) assisted in the review of defence staffing.
At the same time two defence staff carried out an inspection of defence activities and establishments in Washington, London and Paris as part of the normal defence establishment review process.
(ii) The cost of fares and allowances for the two officers of the Public Service Board was $20,432.33.
The costs of fares and allowances for those officers assisting in the review were $32,205. (This does not include the travel costs for the two Defence staff) .

(iii) Australia's missions in Washington, London, Paris and Brussels contain several hundred staff, consisting of both Australian officials and locally engaged personnel. Many Commonwealth departments are represented. It is difficult to examine functions and staffing levels without an appreciation of the way in which missions are organised and the implications which changes in one aspect of a mission's operations will have on others. Such an appreciation is best gained through an on-the-spot examination in close consultation with the Head of Mission and other senior officers. It should be noted that staff reductions which will result from the review are expected to provide annual savings much greater than the costs detailed above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do many single mothers in the 40-50 year age group face severe financial and emotional anguish after losing their supporting parent's benefit or widows' pensions when their youngest child reaches 16, or leaves school.
(2) Do women in this age group have difficulty in finding employment after years outside the workforce raising their children, even though most would prefer to be working again.
(3) Do many of these women eventually qualify for sickness benefits due to the seeming hopelessness of their financial situation.

(4) Would this increasing problem be checked by: (a) re-defining the Class B widows' pension to include women who are between 40 and 50 years of age; and (b) developing re-training schemes for unskilled, mature women who wish to re-enter the workforce.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) I am aware from personal representations to me that some women who lose entitlement to a Class A widows pension or supporting parent's benefit in these circumstances state that they experience difficulties such as those outlined. However, a widow pensioner aged between 45 and 49 years may be eligible for a Class B widow's pension once she ceases to have a qualifying child.

(4) The question of whether entitlement for a Class B widow's pension should be widened to provide pensions to younger women without dependants is a complex one . I appreciate that Class A widows who lose their pension before age 45 may see their exclusion as anomalous; on the other hand, many such women may have had work force experience and might be expected to maintain themselves without taxpayer support. Unemployment benefit is available to a person meeting the relevant qualifications while seeking employment.

Assistance is provided for unskilled women who seek to re-enter the work force under the General Training Assistance Program, administered by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations (DEIR). Under this program they may be assisted:
(i) through on-the-job training with the Government subsidising part of the trainee's wages for the training period.

(ii) through formal training in an occupation which DEIR assesses will be in demand at completion of training. In this case, eligible trainees receive weekly allowances for the period of training, in addition to compulsory fees and a books allowance.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Would the Treasurer advise the names of the foreign company and the private hospital, together with the amount of investment involved, noted in the 1981 Report of the Foreign Investment Review Board which stated that: 'One proposal by a foreign company to invest in a private hospital was approved during 1980-81 '.
(2) Has National Medical Enterprises Inc. of the United States of America now acquired the Australian private hospitals owned by Hospital Affiliates Australia Pty Ltd.
(3) What role does the Foreign Investment Review Board play in a transaction of this kind.

(4) Have all American companies now operating private hospitals in Australia fulfilled their 'local equity' requirements according to the timetables laid down by the Foreign Investment Review Board, and have any variations in the timetables been permitted; if so, why.

(5) Is the Treasurer aware of any American hospital company such as Hospital Corporation of Australia, National Medical Enterprises etc., which owns any Australian businesses other than private hospitals; if so, can the Treasurer name these businesses and provide details of their ownership.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In 1980-81 Hospital Affiliates Australia Pty Ltd was given foreign investment policy approval to acquire the Bundoora and District Private Hospital in Victoria. Details concerning the amount of investment involved are regarded as confidential by both the Government and the parties.

(2) A proposal by National Medical Enterprises Inc. of the United States of America to acquire the private hospitals owned by Hospitals Affiliates was approved by the Government in the second half of 1981. I am informed that the proposal did not proceed for commercial reasons.

(3) Proposals by foreign interests to acquire Australian businesses, irrespective of their ownership, are subject to the provisions of the Foreign Takeovers Act. In takeovers of the type referred to by the honourable senator, the Foreign Investment Review Board, after consultation with the Commonwealth Department of Health and the relevant State health authorities, recommends to the Government whether the takeovers of the businness should be approved or not and also whether conditions whould be attached to approvals.

(4) Three US-owned companies operating private hospitals have received approval to acquire private hospitals in Australia, subject to their admitting not less than 35 per cent local equity. The three companies are Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd and Hospital Affiliates Australia Pty Ltd.

Hospital Corporation Australia Pty Ltd, which traded at a loss for the first three years of its operations, made unsuccessful attempts to introduce local equity and was granted an extension until September 1982 to fulfil its obligations in this regard.

American Medical International (Australia) Pty Ltd has yet to introduce the required level of local equity and has not sought any variation to the terms of the equity condition. The company is, however, pursuing a number of options in relation to its local equity obligations and is keeping the Foreign Investment Review Board advised in this regard.

INA Corporation, which received approval to invest in Australia through Hospital Affiliates, has now sold its five Australian hospitals to local interests. The equity condition applied to this company's Australian operations is therefore no longer applicable.

(5) INA Corporation has advised that it owns three companies in Australia engaged in insurance and related activities. These are Insurance Company of North America (Australia) Limited, which is a general insurance company, International Rehabilitation Associates Pty Limited, which provides consultancy services concerned with rehabilitation of injured workers, and Esis International Inc. which provides services to the insurance industry as claims adjusters, marine technical specialists, loss control experts and claims subrogation services. The two United States owned hospital companies operating in Australia have advised that they do not have any other businesses activities in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

(4) Were any Australian people of European descent accompanying the group; if so, who were they and what salaries were they paid.
(5) Did the Australian Government pay all passenger and other transport costs for the group to travel to America; if so, what was the amount expended.
(6) What was the amount of salary received by each of the 28 dancers and the six administrators.
(7) Was the American tour successful.
(8) Is the troupe still overseas or have they returned to Australia and did the Australian Government pay salaries or any other expenses to the American organisers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 28 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is 4GG the only locally-based radio station on the Queensland Gold Coast.
(2) Is 4GG finding it difficult to meet demands of advertisers for air time, thus disadvantaging businessmen.
(3) In such a situation, does the Minister recognise the urgency of allocating another Gold Coast radio station licence; if so, when will applications be called for the licence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 4GG is the only commercial radio station licensed to serve the Queensland Gold Coast area.

(2) The advertising content of 4GG's programs was analysed over one week in August 1981 by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in connection with 4GG's licence renewal. Compared with the allowable limit of 18 minutes per hour, 4GG's advertising content averaged 9 minutes per hour.

(3) Current policy provides for the introduction of commercial FM radio services (independent or supplemantary) to non-metropolitan areas through the supplementary licence scheme. However, I am currently reviewing this policy and will announce soon how the Government will proceed with the introduction of FM radio to non-metropolitan areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 4 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) still employ Agroprom Singapore Pty Ltd as a consultant; if so, are the terms of employment the same as those which applied in the contract for the period 1 December 1979 to 30 November 1981; if not, what changes have occurred.
(2) Is Agroprom Singapore Pty Ltd a wholly or partly owned subsidiary of Agroprom S.A. a company registered in Geneva Switzerland; if a partly owned subsidiary who are the other shareholders.

(3) Does Agroprom Singapore Pty Ltd or Agroprom S.A. or any other subsidiary of Agroprom Singapore Ltd act for any other marketing board whose product requires the issue of an export licence for the export of its products; if so, what are the Boards for which Agroprom or any of its related companies operate.

(4) Has the AWB sought, or Agroprom supplied, details of other companies or corporations or individuals in and outside Australia either at the time of executing the contract which operates from 1 December 1979 or at any other time. If so, what are the names of the companies or corporations or individuals.

(5) Are or have the actions of any of the companies, corporations or individuals for which Agroprom acts either as agent or adviser been subject to litigation or threatened litigation in any court in Australia or elsewhere; if so, what are the details of the threatened or actual litigation.

(6) Is the AWB satisfied, and if so on what grounds, that Agroprom and any of its associated companies have conformed to the business practices ethics and standards which would be regarded as acceptable in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Wheat Board (AWB) has advised that it no longer employs Agroprom Singapore Pty Ltd as a consultant. The contract between the AWB and Agroprom Singapore Pty Ltd was extended to cover the period 1 December 1981 to 31 March 1982, on the same terms and conditions as the original contract, except that the fee was reduced. For the period 1 April 1982 to 30 November 1982, the AWB contract with Agroprom Trading Ltd, London, on the same terms and conditions as those with Agroprom Singapore Pty Ltd except as regards the fee.

(2) The AWB advised that it is not aware of the shareholdings of Agroprom Singapore Pty Ltd , Agroprom Trading Ltd, London, or Agroprom S.A., Geneva, although the former two companies are associated with the latter. The AWB has also been informed that there is no legal and/or financial connection between Agroprom Trading Ltd, London, and Agroprom S.A., Geneva.
(3) The other Commonwealth marketing boards whose product requires the issue of an export licence advise that the Agroprom companies do not act for them.

(4) Agroprom Trading Ltd, London, and associated companies, have covenanted in their contract with the AWB not to act for other than certain specified organisations without the prior written consent of the AWB. On grounds of commercial confidentiality I am not prepared to reveal the names of those organisations. The AWB has not given consent for Agroprom to provide consultancy services to other organisations.
(5) No act or action of the AWB in relation to its consultancy arrangement with Agroprom has been subject to litigation or threatened litigation in any court in Australia or elsewhere.

(6) The AWB has indicated that it is not aware of any departures by Agroprom and any of its associated companies from business practices, ethics and standards which would be regarded as acceptable in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Federal Government provide a definition or measure of 'need of such assistance'; with reference to Schedule 1 of the Housing Assistance Act 1981, part X-rental housing assistance-item 32, which states: 'The conditions of eligibility of persons for rental housing assistance shall be determined by the State and shall ensure assistance is directed to those applicants most in need of assistance'; if not, how is it possible to ensure that this condition is complied with by the relevant State governments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. In Recital (E) (g) to the 1981 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, Commonwealth and State Housing Ministers affirmed that the States would be able to exercise maximum autonomy and flexibility in the administrative arrangements necessary to achieve the other principles contained in Recital E. These included the principle that Housing assistance will provide adequate rental housing for those of the community who are deemed to be in need of government assistance at a price that is within their capacity to pay.

Part of the rationale for Recital E(g) is that each State is in the best position to determine criteria most suited to the circumstances in their State. In practice each State has various specific needs test criteria.

While a definition or measure of 'need of such assistance' is not provided, the Agreement contains several provisions (such as movements to market related rents and provision of rent rebates to those unable to afford such rents) which have the effect of directing assistance to those in need. The Commonwealth Government is also able to evaluate the effectiveness with which assistance is directed to those in need from data provided by the the States, for example, data on the household income of households assisted (see Table 9 on page 61 of annual report for 1980-81 on Housing Assistance Act 1978).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Why has the position of social worker, in the Cockburn area of Western Australia, funded under the Family Support Services Scheme, been abolished.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Applications for assistance under the extended Family Support Services Scheme ( FSSS) were examined initially by a joint Commonwealth/State Management Committee . This Committee examined the operation of all projects funded under the pilot FSSS, including the one sponsored by the City of Cockburn.

The Management Committee considered that this service was in direct contact with only part of the local community. In addition there are many social workers and community groups offering similar services in the area. The Committee, therefore, recommended that funding of this project should not be extended. This view was supported by the Honourable W. R. B. Hassell (the then Western Australian Minister for Community Welfare) and endorsed by me.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: In how many cases since June 1980 has the Director-General of Social Security or his delegate granted an invalid pension to a person whose medical incapacity has been assessed at less than 85 % by the Commonwealth Medical Officer or Department of Health.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows.

ANSWER.PARA: The information requested does not form a part of the regular statistical collections of my Department and it could not be obtained without an unreasonable amount of work which I am not prepared to authorise.

There have been cases since June 1980 where a person, whose medical incapacity has been assessed at less than 85 per cent by a Commonwealth Medical Officer, has been granted an invalid pension. In these cases a delegate of the Director- General has determined that factors of a non-medical nature combined with medical factors are such that the person is permanently incapacitated for work within the meaning of the Social Security Act.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the present unemployment benefit form introduced within the Department of Social Security;

(4) When will the new unemployment benefit form be available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The current form 'Claim for Unemployment Benefit' (Form SU2) was introduced in July 1981.
(2) There is no evidence available of complaints of this nature.

(3) and (4) The current form is the result of the simplification process referred to in my answers to Senate Questions No. 803 (weekly Hansard, 12 June 1981, page 3288) and No. 1140 (Hansard, 21 October 1981, page 1502).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property, which was adopted on 10 December 1970 and came into force on 24 April 1972, cover Aboriginal artifacts.
(2) What steps has Australia taken to ratify the convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Convention is expressed in such terms as would include Aboriginal artifacts. However, since Australia has not ratified the Convention it is not bound by it.

(2) The Government has the question of ratification of the Convention under consideration. It is one of the matters which an Interdepartmental Working Group on Measures to Preserve and Protect Australia's Cultural Property has under examination. This body is expected to report to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment soon. The Working Group called for submissions from interested parties and the general public through advertisements placed in the major metropolitan newspapers on 18 and 19 July 1981.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Social Security received representations on behalf of the Kings Cross Youth Refuge for the maintaining of the Commonwealth's contribution to the re-opening of the Refuge.
(2) Is the Kings Cross Refuge a magnet for young people from all over New South Wales and indeed Australia.
(3) What other alternatives to such a refuge are available for youth in Kings Cross.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) My Department has no information about the previous residences of the young people who used this refuge.
(3) Alternative services are provided by other refuges and a variety of agencies that offer counselling and support to homeless young people. A number of these services are funded by my Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government decided to cut real funds available to the Family Support Services Scheme.
(2) Does the allocation to New South Wales for 1982-84 of $2m represent a fall in per capita terms.
(3) How many existing New South Wales projects will have to be closed down because of lack of funds.
(4) Did the Office of Child Care begin a review of the Family Support Services Scheme; if so when will the results of the review be released.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government has agreed to provide $10m for an extension of the Family Support Services Scheme for a three-year period from 1 January 1982 to 31 December 1984. This is the same amount as for the pilot scheme during the previous three years. It should be noted that these service types are more closely aligned to State Government interests and functions and the Family Support Services Scheme, which is 100 per cent Commonwealth funded, should therefore be seen as complementing what the States provided in this area.
(2) New South Wales allocation of the $10m for 1982-84 is $2.7m, compared with $2.25m under the pilot scheme; this represents an increase in per capita terms.

(3) Projects were approved for continued funding on the recommendation of the New South Wales Minister for Youth and Community Services. Because of the limit on the funds available 16 projects, approved under the pilot scheme, were not recommended for continued funding.

(4) Provision was made under the initial pilot scheme for an evaluation of projects funded. In New South Wales, this evaluation was conducted by an independent group, Social Research and Evaluation Ltd. The final report on the Scheme's operation in New South Wales is still in preparation, but information from reviews of each project was available to assist in the preparation of recommendations for the continued funding of projects under the extended scheme.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Mail Service Centenary: Brisbane to London

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the date of the centenary of the first Royal Mail Service by sea from Brisbane to London.
(2) On what dates were the Union Jack flown in front of the Brisbane General Post Office during the latter part of 1981.

(3) Were the dates of the flying of the Union Jack and the centenary of the first Royal Mail Service the same; if not, for what reason did the dates differ (with reference to the answer to Question on Notice No. 1762-see Hansard, page 2074 of 18 May 1982).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from advice furnished by the Australian Postal Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) From 25 September 1981 to 4 December 1981.

(3) No. Two additional flag poles were erected, in front of the Brisbane GPO, in September 1981 as part of the decoration of the building for the 1981 Warana Festival. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 March 1982 (Hansard, page 569) Senator Robertson asked Senator Sir John Carrick a question without notice concerning students in the Northern Territory who are undertaking university study externally:

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Government has accepted a recommendation of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for the establishment of an External Studies Centre at the Darwin Community College. The purpose of the Centre is to provide tutorial and other assistance for residents of the Northern Territory who are enrolled as external students in Australian universities and colleges of advanced education . Grants up to $90,000 in 1982, $140,000 in 1983, and $180,000 in 1984, will be available in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act for this purpose.

It is also significant that following consultations with the Northern Territory Minister for Education, the Hon. J. M. Robertson, MLA, the Darwin Community College will introduce its own Bachelor of Arts course during the 1982-84 triennium. I am satisfied that the introduction of this course will widen opportunities for residents of the Territory to undertake tertiary studies.

The possibility of the Commonwealth Government providing assistance towards travel and accommodation cost for students in the Territory who are undertaking university study externally and who are required to attend on-campus lectures, tutorials and seminars at the university where they are enrolled involves a question of direct financial aid to students. Commonwealth financial assistance for tertiary students is provided by the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme ( TEAS). The Student Assistance Act 1973, which provides the legislative basis for the scheme, requires that TEAS allowances will be available only to students who are studying on a full-time basis. Consequently, if the student is enrolled externally on a full-time basis, assistance under TEAS would be available and the allowance, though not designed specifically to cover costs of travel and accommodation as outlined, could be used for such. Should the student be studying externally on a part-time basis, assistance under TEAS would not be applicable.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Effect of Television Advertisements and Programs on Epileptics

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 April 1982 (Hansard, page 1506) Senator Hearn asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications or possibly the Minister for Health aware that during the last year flashing lights, numbers and letters have been used and are still being used in many television advertisements and programs? Is it an established fact that flashing lights are harmful to people suffering from epilepsy and can induce seizures? Has any research been done in this area? In view of the number of hours that some children are reported to be watching television, what steps will the Minister take to prevent such health hazards?
The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following response to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has information to the effect that photoepileptic fits can be triggered by television in a small number of epileptics. However, no action has been taken so far to restrict the use of such techniques in the absence of positive identification of the particular physical features of television presentations which are likely to trigger fits in susceptible individuals. At present the Tribunal is not aware of any specifications which provide guidelines as to the type of stimuli which need to be avoided and this would appear to be a matter about which expert medical/bio- physical advice should be sought as a prelude to the possible introduction of standards. Accordingly, advice is being sought on this matter from the Minister for Health.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 26 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures have been taken to implement each decision arising from the Report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, under the heading of ' Administrative Services' up to the date of preparation of this answer.
(2) What measures are planned to implement fully each decision.
(3) In what areas have employees of the Department of Administrative Services been affected, either in terms of redeployment or redundancy, by the decisions of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The position at 30 June 1982 was a follows:
Government decision
Measures taken or proposed
Increased use to be made of private surveyors so that the private sector obtains an agreed target proportion of Commonwealth survey work within 5 years.
Implemented. A reduction of 50 staff (level of reduction set for year 1) has been reached. A target proportion of Commonwealth survey work to be contracted out to the private sector has been set.
Overseas property activities of statutory authorities to be transferred to the Overseas Property Office of the Department of Administrative Services.
Implemented. Legislation to effect the transfer was enacted in June 1981.
Department of Administrative Services to assume policy control for all aspects of domestic property.

Policy guidelines are being developed and implemented. Specific items already covered include an energy program for Commonwealth-owned buildings, a program to modify Commonwealth buildings to facilitate access by disabled people and a general policy of not leasing buildings with inadequate access for disabled people, and programs of inspection and maintenance or remedial work in Commonwealth buildings to prevent the exposure of Commonwealth employees to Legionnaire's disease or asbestos.
Surplus Commonwealth land to be sold or leased.
A 3 year program of review of Commonwealth property holdings has commenced. Revenue from property sales over this period is expected to be about $70 million .
Capacity of Government Printer to be limited to that required for Parliament and the urgent and confidential needs of Government. Remaining work to be transferred to the private sector.
The question of the appropriate capacity is under consideration; work in excess of present capacity is being undertaken by the private sector.
Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops to be leased to private sector.
Following the seeking of expressions of interest in leasing the bookshops, tenders are expected to be invited in the near future.
Departments to identify and dispose of surplus goods.
Identification of surplus goods has been substantially completed; disposal through public auction is in progress.
Establishment of Departmental bulk stores to be controlled.
Revised procedures and guidelines are being developed to control establishment of bulk stores. These are expected to be issued around the end of August 1982.
Storage costs to be recovered.

The bases for recovering storage costs have been established following detailed investigations. Systems are being developed and progressively introduced; it is planned that charging for storage services commence at the beginning of the 1983 -84 financial year.
Contracting out to private sector of routine disposal of goods to be increased.

Auction sales to dispose of Commonwealth goods are conducted by private auctioneers and my Department is examining options for transferring further elements of its disposal function to the private sector.
Role of Purchasing Division to be extended to purchases by statutory authorities and departments over the Regulation 52 limit to achieve greater purchasing economies.
Role being reviewed particularly to take account of the transfer, as recommended by the Defence Review Committee, of the defence purchasing role to the Department of Defence Support.
Resources devoted to the Technical Services Section of the Purchasing Division to be reduced.
A reduction of 10 positions implemented.

Management support services for Australian Government Publishing Service, Transport and Storage Division and Australian Electoral Office to be centralised with Management Services Division of Department.
Options are being examined.
Circulation of daily compilation of Ministerial Statements to be limited to essential users.
Implemented.
Cleaning and watching of Commonwealth properties to be undertaken by private sector.
Contracts have been arranged or varied for transfers of the cleaning and watching function to the private sector commencing 1 July 1982.
Non-departmental food and other services provided by Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services to be transfered to the private sector.
Six of the 9 services have been transferred to the private sector. Disposal action is proceeding in respect of the remainder.
Departmental services to be subject to further review.
Review completed. Expressions of interest from the private sector in taking over the services have been sought.
Havelock House to be placed on market.

Expressions of interest received were assessed but a decision on them deferred pending a decision on the relocation of the Australian Police College. Following agreement at the Premiers' Conference in June 1982 to locate the College in Perth, the way is now clear for the disposal of Havelock House to proceed.
Future of remaining ACT non-migrant guesthouses to be reviewed.
An inter-departmental report is under consideration.
Preference to be given to firms that use Australian-made hire cars.

Following a subsequent decision to restrict the Government's policy of preference to Australian-made goods to certain purchases from defence-strategic and high technology industries, this decision is being implemented only in relation to the provision of hire cars for Ministerial use.
Migrant hostel management to be transferred to the private sector on a management fee arrangement.
Expressions of interest have been sought and discussions had with those organisations assessed as suitable tenderers. Formal tenders are expected to be invited in August 1982.

(3) At 30 June 1982 only employees of the technical services area of the Purchasing Division have been redeployed. In relation to the cleaning and watching function, arrangements are well advanced in contracting out the work and offers of employment have been made to existing employees. Every effort will be made to redeploy within the Australian Public Service employees who do not wish to work for the contractor. It is also expected that staff who work in the Australian Government Publishing Service Bookshops will be offered employment by the successful contractor and again, every effort will be made to redeploy within the Australian Public Service those staff who do not accept such an offer .

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Treasury, or the Foreign Investment Review Board, have figures to indicate the total area of freehold land held by foreign nationals in Queensland ; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The subject of foreign investment in rural land, which has attracted a good deal of attention over the past 2 years or so, was discussed at the meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council last year. It was then agreed that there would be further consultations between Federal and State Governments on measures to obtain additional information on the overall level of foreign ownership of rural land and on policies that might apply in relation to new investment proposals.

The Government then undertook a comprehensive review of its foreign investment policy, which included detailed consideration of the guidelines as they apply to foreign investment in rural properties. As a result of this review and as I announced on 20 January 1982, the Government decided that a more restrictive approach should be adopted towards foreign acquisitions of rural properties, primarily by way of strengthening the test of benefits from a proposal before approval is given.

In its review, the Government also considered what measures might be taken to obtain comprehensive information on foreign ownership of rural land, and in particular the possibility of establishing a register of foreign ownership of rural land. After giving very careful attention to this issue, the Government decided that, as responsibility for land titles and usage rests with States and Territories, it would be more appropriate that any establishment of land ownership registers be left to the States, should they wish to do so.

Nevertheless, the Foreign Investment Review Board has compiled statistics on proposals submitted for approval under the Government's foreign investment policy. These statistics indicate that over the period 1 April 1976 to 30 June 1982, 90 proposals were allowed to proceed involving some 3,280,000 hectares of rural land (freehold and leasehold) in Queensland. Thirty-four of the 90 proposals involved persons intending to come and live in Australia. A further 18 proposals involved Australian participation and some of the properties were already foreign owned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 23 March 1982:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 20 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Australia Post planning to abolish the Travelling Post Office in New South Wales as part of the New South Wales Mail Network Plan; if so, what were the factors that led to this decision.
(2) Have the Postal Unions and Travelling Post Office staff been consulted on proposed changes; if so, what were the details of such consultation, if any.
(3) What are the cost advantages to Australia Post of abolishing the Travelling Post Office.
(4) Will the abolition of the Travelling Post Office result in delays in sorting and delivering mail to country areas from city centres and vice versa.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from information furnished by the Australian Postal Commission:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia Post has no immediate program for withdrawal of the travelling post offices (TPOs) in New South Wales. Justification for their retention will be reviewed once implementation of the changes associated with the decentralisation of the New South Wales mail network nears completion.

(2) Yes. Staff and staff associations have been advised that the future requirements for TPOs will be reviewed as the decentralised network operations are consolidated, and that the TPO facility will continue to operate at least until after this review is completed and full consultation with staff and community groups has taken place.

(3) If TPOs were to be abolished, on present estimates annual fees paid to the State Rail Authority of about $1.3m (1980-81 prices) would be saved together with savings of staff costs of about the same order.
(4) There would be no degradation of Australia Post's current advertised standard of service for mail between metropolitan and country areas of New South Wales if the TPOs were withdrawn.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications , upon notice, on 27 April 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Can it take up to one week for an air mail letter posted from the Central Brisbane area to reach its destination in Sydney; if so, is Australia Post attempting to improve this service in view of the effect that these delays have on businesses, particularly since the high cost of using 'priority paid' makes this an unacceptable alternative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question from information furnished by the Australian Postal Commission:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 4 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are counter staff of the Minister's Department permitted to smoke whilst interviewing clients.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
