QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 4 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Are counter staff of the Minister's Department permitted to smoke whilst interviewing clients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed by my Department that on 21 November 1980 the Public Service Board issued a Memorandum (No. 77/1178) to all departments and statutory authorities on the subject of smoking in Commonwealth Government offices. This memorandum included a circular issued by the Department of Health on 20 November 1980 drawing attention to the Government's policy on the subject as expressed in the terms of the Government's response to the Report from the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare 'Drug Problems in Australia-An Intoxicated Society'. The circular prepared by the Department of Health sets out the guidelines for the application of Government policy and the action to be taken by departments and statutory authorities. The circular states, inter alia, 'it is recognised, that at this stage, there can be no general ban on smoking in Commonwealth Government offices either for the public or Government employees' but such steps should be taken as may be practical along the following lines:

(i) with the agreement of any staff amenity or other committees that may be concerned, to prohibit or limit smoking in recreational areas, staff restaurants , etc; to set aside separate smoking areas where desired and possible (this is meant to be interpreted as segregation rather than provision of separate facilities); and to limit or prohibit the sale of cigarettes on Commonwealth Government premises;
(ii) to prohibit smoking in lifts or other enclosed confined spaces;

(iii) where this can be achieved without significant additional cost, accommodation or manpower, and with no loss of efficiency, to consider sympathetically any proposal for segregating smokers and non-smokers;
(iv) to discourage smoking by the public by displaying suitable request notices ;
(v) to discourage smoking at conferences, meetings, training courses or other gatherings at which non-smokers might be put to discomfort;
(vi) to make known in the organisation a policy attitude on this matter.

The circular further states 'It is envisaged that problems which arise would be resolved by departmental management. The development of specific arrangements within individual workplaces is seen, however, as a matter primarily to be resolved at each workplace, having regard to the general policy and to practicability'.

My Department has distributed the Public Service Board memorandum and the Department of Health circular to staff with the request for smokers not to smoke in the workplace or in recreational facilities provided within the Department's premises. If this causes hardship to any smoker then the officer is invited to report that to the supervisor who is to refer the case to management.

There have been no complaints received by management from the staff or the public about smoking by officers and the observations by management indicate a general acceptance by the staff of the recognition of the objections of some people to others smoking in their presence. There may be isolated cases of officers smoking at public counters but these have not come under notice as a consequence of any complaint.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that all property and liability policies taken out with insurance companies in Australia exclude cover for loss, damage or liability attributable to nuclear weapons material, nuclear fuel or nuclear waste from nuclear fuel.

(2) Is the Minister aware that this is because the insurance industry considers that the liability for such loss, damage or liability lies at present with the Government because the nuclear industry in Australia is currently exclusively under Federal Government control.

(3) Have any claims been made against the Federal Government with regard to loss, damage or liability attributable to nuclear weapons material, nuclear fuel or nuclear waste from nuclear fuel; if so, how have these been dealt with.
(4) Do guidelines exist for dealing with any such claims? If so, what are these guidelines; if not, will the Government draw up guidelines as soon as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware that it has been established practice for many years for property and liability policies taken out with insurance companies in Australia to exclude cover for loss, damage or liability attributable to nuclear weapons material, nuclear fuel or nuclear waste from nuclear fuel.

(2) The Insurance Council of Australia Limited has stated that the nuclear exclusion clauses represent the insurance industry's assessment that, with regard to any nuclear accident to which the exclusions apply, liability remains the sole responsibility of the Commonwealth Government. However, whether the Commonwealth would be liable for any loss resulting from nuclear damage would depend on the facts of each particular case. Broadly, where the Commonwealth uses radioactive materials or is directly responsible for their use, any Commonwealth liability would depend on general principles of liability that would apply equally to private persons or corporations.

(3) A small number of claims relating to the effects of radiation have been made against the Commonwealth under workers' compensation legislation on behalf of former employees of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission who worked at Lucas Heights. Also, a number of workers' compensation claims against the Commonwealth have been made recently by employees who worked at former nuclear weapons test sites in Australia in the 1950's. Most of these latter claims are still being considered but some have already been determined. At least two individuals have sought further damages against the Commonwealth under common law. Their cases have not yet been heard.

(4) Apart from claims involving workers' compensation legislation, any claims of the kind addressed in the honourable Senator's question would presently have to be pursued under common law. In this connection, I refer the honourable senator to the information contained in part (3) of the Treasurer's answer to House of Representatives Question No. 3676.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to ''new'' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper for the Minister's Department recycled; if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department's bulk paper supplies are purchased through relevant Government contracts and it cannot determine whether any of this is manufactured from recycled paper. Paper is reused where it is cost effective. Obsolete forms and letterhead are converted to scrap writing pads and also used in copying machines where practical.
(2) Used paper in the Department's Central Office is shredded and then recycled . The availability of such facilities in other offices is being investigated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to 'new' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled; if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Where the content of the original printed matter allows, paper is reused in the form of note pads and the like.
(2) Yes, where possible. Exceptions are paper destroyed under security arrangements and paper from leased offices where waste is removed by cleaning contractors.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 5 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is recycled paper used in the Minister's Department; if so, in what capacity is it used; if not, will the Minister consider using recycled paper in preference to ''new'' paper wherever possible.
(2) Is paper from the Minister's Department recycled; if not, will the Minister consider having this done.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following response to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the sense that recycled paper is intended to mean repulped paper no details are available as all paper appears in new condition when delivered.

Currently obsolete letterhead paper is converted to re-use for drafting correspondence and as copying paper in photocopy machines. Computer printouts no longer required are used in the Department as rough working papers and, where the information contained thereon is not classified or sensitive, are made available to child care centres for use as drawing paper, scribblers, etc.
(2) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 6 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: Why are there not any Northern Territory representatives on the Australia Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Appointments to the Australia Council are made after careful consideration of the persons available in the light of the criteria contained in the Australia Council Act 1975. No significance attaches to the fact that the Northern Territory is not represented at the present time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 18 May 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many persons have been questioned at Customs barriers since 1969 when it has been discovered that they are attempting to import a still.
(2) How many such persons have been charged with an offence of importing an item prohibited under Customs regulations.
(3) How many persons have been allowed to keep the stills.
(4) In what years were these persons charged and in what years were these persons allowed to keep the stills.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As far as can be ascertained from available departmental records the following information is supplied:
(1) Two.
(2) None.
(3) One.
(4) No persons were charged and the approval to allow the retention of the still was given in 1972.
